description: As one of the cornerstones of the Office suite, Word is a powerful word processor that allows users to create both simple and sophisticated documents. This series explores the essentials to getting started with Word 2016 on a Macintosh operating system. We begin with basic skills such as navigating a document, selecting text, inputting basic text, and proofing a document. The series also explores all aspects of character and paragraph formatting as well as page formatting and layout. While this series is designed for beginner users, it has lots of great tips and tricks for experienced users as well.

name: Word 2016 Essentials for Mac
subtitle: Document and word processing software

episodes.description: As one of the cornerstones of the Office suite, Word is a powerful word processor that allows users to create both simple and sophisticated documents. This series explores the essentials to getting started with Word 2016 on a Macintosh operating system. We begin with basic skills such as navigating a document, selecting text, inputting basic text, and proofing a document. The series also explores all aspects of character and paragraph formatting as well as page formatting and layout. While this series is designed for beginner users, it has lots of great tips and tricks for experienced users as well.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.315
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.315 --> 00:00:10.305
Hello everyone, and
welcome to Word 2016 Essentials for Mac.

3
00:00:10.305 --> 00:00:13.545
My name is Vonne Smith, and
in this course overview,

4
00:00:13.545 --> 00:00:17.217
we're going to be reviewing
what exactly is in this series.

5
00:00:17.217 --> 00:00:21.347
Who is our target audience and who should
be watching this, any prerequisites that

6
00:00:21.347 --> 00:00:25.800
we need to know before we get started,
and a little extra tidbits along the way.

7
00:00:25.800 --> 00:00:28.718
So what are we covering in this series?

8
00:00:28.718 --> 00:00:31.186
This is broken up into three main topics.

9
00:00:31.186 --> 00:00:34.800
We have Introduction,
Text Formatting and Page Layout.

10
00:00:34.800 --> 00:00:37.369
In the introduction, well,
it's an introduction to Word.

11
00:00:37.369 --> 00:00:40.240
We get started with what is Word?

12
00:00:40.240 --> 00:00:42.350
What about the interface of Word?

13
00:00:42.350 --> 00:00:46.560
We know where we're going so
it's always important to understand.

14
00:00:46.560 --> 00:00:48.904
When I say go to the ribbon,
you know where the ribbon is.

15
00:00:48.904 --> 00:00:52.270
Or look at the status bar,
the status bar is down at the bottom.

16
00:00:52.270 --> 00:00:55.909
We talk about the interface
of the Word environment.

17
00:00:55.909 --> 00:01:00.070
Then we also get into
navigating a Word document.

18
00:01:00.070 --> 00:01:03.398
Do you know that Ctrl-Home will always
take you to the very beginning of your

19
00:01:03.398 --> 00:01:03.923
document?

20
00:01:03.923 --> 00:01:06.883
We go over that and
a lot of other cool tips and

21
00:01:06.883 --> 00:01:10.563
tricks of getting around
a document to make it easier,

22
00:01:10.563 --> 00:01:15.299
to be a little bit more efficient and
faster with typing up a document.

23
00:01:15.299 --> 00:01:17.794
We're gonna be selecting text.

24
00:01:17.794 --> 00:01:19.580
You think, that's just click,
hold and drag, right?

25
00:01:19.580 --> 00:01:24.475
There's a lot of cool shortcuts that we
can do to make you more efficient there

26
00:01:24.475 --> 00:01:25.994
when selecting a text.

27
00:01:25.994 --> 00:01:30.010
We go over the different auto-correct and
the proofing.

28
00:01:30.010 --> 00:01:33.636
We also talk about the all important cut,
copy and paste, and

29
00:01:33.636 --> 00:01:35.671
knowing about our paste options.

30
00:01:35.671 --> 00:01:39.867
And then Find and replace and some
different things within Find and replace

31
00:01:39.867 --> 00:01:44.680
with the finding special characters and
how that can really benefit you.

32
00:01:44.680 --> 00:01:46.848
Then we move into formatting your text.

33
00:01:46.848 --> 00:01:51.280
How do you make things look bigger,
bolder, different colors, different fonts?

34
00:01:51.280 --> 00:01:55.886
So we go into the world of character
formatting and paragraph formatting.

35
00:01:55.886 --> 00:02:00.168
We also talk about formatting text
in lists, either a bulleted list or

36
00:02:00.168 --> 00:02:01.901
a numbered list.

37
00:02:01.901 --> 00:02:03.908
Tabs, I love some tabs.

38
00:02:03.908 --> 00:02:07.287
In tab stops,
we learned about left inline tab stops,

39
00:02:07.287 --> 00:02:11.660
center inline tab stops, what is a leader,
all of those fun things.

40
00:02:11.660 --> 00:02:15.419
And then my all-time favorite
which would be styles.

41
00:02:15.419 --> 00:02:20.568
We introduced what is a style, why you
want to use them, how important they are,

42
00:02:20.568 --> 00:02:26.110
and actually really how easy they
are to implement into your document.

43
00:02:26.110 --> 00:02:28.454
Then we end with our topic of page layout.

44
00:02:28.454 --> 00:02:32.050
This would be how the text
flows within your document.

45
00:02:32.050 --> 00:02:34.755
How do you do the different pagination,
and

46
00:02:34.755 --> 00:02:37.911
really what they normally
would say is page setup.

47
00:02:37.911 --> 00:02:42.560
Things like margins,
our breaks, our keep options.

48
00:02:42.560 --> 00:02:44.496
What is a widow and orphan control?

49
00:02:44.496 --> 00:02:46.750
We have section breaks.

50
00:02:46.750 --> 00:02:49.378
Sections are so important in a document,

51
00:02:49.378 --> 00:02:54.197
understanding them can just open up
a whole new world of how you can use Word.

52
00:02:54.197 --> 00:02:55.857
We talk about columns,

53
00:02:55.857 --> 00:03:00.910
we insert some blank cover pages
which are really easy to do.

54
00:03:00.910 --> 00:03:04.951
And then we talk about our headers and
footers within our margins, and

55
00:03:04.951 --> 00:03:06.606
how we can add page numbers.

56
00:03:06.606 --> 00:03:09.169
That can always be a little tricky,
so we go ahead and

57
00:03:09.169 --> 00:03:11.310
dedicated an entire episode to that.

58
00:03:11.310 --> 00:03:13.835
And then we end on some decoration.

59
00:03:13.835 --> 00:03:17.996
Adding some borders and some shading,
and some different watermarks and

60
00:03:17.996 --> 00:03:19.130
things like that.

61
00:03:19.130 --> 00:03:22.615
So that would be the end
of that particular topic.

62
00:03:22.615 --> 00:03:26.526
Now, that's the wrong way,
how about we go this way?

63
00:03:26.526 --> 00:03:31.390
[LAUGH] Our target audience, man,
I'm getting all tripped up here.

64
00:03:31.390 --> 00:03:38.262
All Office users, now that means Office
with a capital O, as in the Office Suite.

65
00:03:38.262 --> 00:03:41.980
Not necessarily that you
work in a physical office.

66
00:03:41.980 --> 00:03:45.484
Which maybe a lot of you do, but
this could be your small business,

67
00:03:45.484 --> 00:03:48.128
home business, school,
work, whichever way.

68
00:03:48.128 --> 00:03:49.734
But Microsoft Office and

69
00:03:49.734 --> 00:03:54.290
Word is one of the main programs
within that particular suite.

70
00:03:54.290 --> 00:03:59.741
This is an Essentials course, which
means it starts from the very beginning,

71
00:03:59.741 --> 00:04:03.125
so this would be anybody
that is a basic user, and

72
00:04:03.125 --> 00:04:08.178
then may try to get up into an
intermediate level of understanding Word.

73
00:04:08.178 --> 00:04:12.844
That being said, you do not have
to have any prior knowledge of

74
00:04:12.844 --> 00:04:15.553
Word before starting this course.

75
00:04:15.553 --> 00:04:18.140
You maybe not even know what it does.

76
00:04:18.140 --> 00:04:19.599
Well, we start from there.

77
00:04:19.599 --> 00:04:21.415
We talked about, what is the Enter key?

78
00:04:21.415 --> 00:04:23.020
Like, really we're gonna
talk about the Enter key?

79
00:04:23.020 --> 00:04:24.339
You'll be surprised.

80
00:04:24.339 --> 00:04:29.645
And really some other tricks, like if you
hold Command and Enter what does that do?

81
00:04:29.645 --> 00:04:34.165
And just I mean some basic understanding
of your MAC operating systems is going

82
00:04:34.165 --> 00:04:35.337
to be very helpful.

83
00:04:35.337 --> 00:04:40.947
Understand that we find, we do cover some
of those basics within the introduction

84
00:04:40.947 --> 00:04:45.848
of just understanding, how to do
a File New, how to close the program.

85
00:04:45.848 --> 00:04:50.039
And if you have any familiarity
with other Office products,

86
00:04:50.039 --> 00:04:53.420
that would be helpful for
you getting into Word.

87
00:04:54.780 --> 00:04:59.011
In these series, or
in these episodes, we have files and

88
00:04:59.011 --> 00:05:01.493
notes that are for each episode.

89
00:05:01.493 --> 00:05:05.368
Those are my notes that I use to help
guide us along within the episode, and

90
00:05:05.368 --> 00:05:07.350
those are available to you.

91
00:05:07.350 --> 00:05:12.017
And more often than not, there is a file,
a Word file that we're using for

92
00:05:12.017 --> 00:05:15.646
demonstration purposes, and
that is available to you.

93
00:05:15.646 --> 00:05:19.000
Now you can download all of them for
the entire series right

94
00:05:19.000 --> 00:05:23.770
here in this course overview or
they are available on individual episodes.

95
00:05:23.770 --> 00:05:26.811
And if for any reason we miss something,
maybe it's the wrong file,

96
00:05:26.811 --> 00:05:29.074
it's attached to the wrong episode,
let us know.

97
00:05:29.074 --> 00:05:31.579
Contact us and we'll go ahead and
get that fixed.

98
00:05:32.950 --> 00:05:37.570
Here's some extra tidbits to end this
overview is that there are always

99
00:05:37.570 --> 00:05:40.115
multiple options to do things in Word.

100
00:05:40.115 --> 00:05:43.611
And I might cover three of them,
and not cover the other two.

101
00:05:43.611 --> 00:05:45.970
And you're like,
well I know you could do it this way.

102
00:05:45.970 --> 00:05:46.540
Totally fine.

103
00:05:46.540 --> 00:05:49.332
There's many,
many options of how to use Word and

104
00:05:49.332 --> 00:05:51.869
the different commands that are available.

105
00:05:51.869 --> 00:05:53.701
And really in any Office product.

106
00:05:53.701 --> 00:05:54.981
Updates.

107
00:05:54.981 --> 00:05:57.198
Updates do happen.

108
00:05:57.198 --> 00:06:01.929
And that's where you might have,
there might be a major update that

109
00:06:01.929 --> 00:06:05.415
has happened with
the Office Suite that makes my,

110
00:06:05.415 --> 00:06:09.540
at this time of recording,
Word different than yours.

111
00:06:09.540 --> 00:06:14.523
So just be aware of that, and it will
change things in there from time to time.

112
00:06:14.523 --> 00:06:17.961
And in any of your Office products,
if you go to the Help menu,

113
00:06:17.961 --> 00:06:21.120
there is an option for check for updates.

114
00:06:21.120 --> 00:06:25.286
And it will run to see if you need
updates and then go ahead and install.

115
00:06:25.286 --> 00:06:29.295
A lot of times, if you have your
preferences in the auto-update to

116
00:06:29.295 --> 00:06:32.374
do automatically,
it will a lot of times prompt you

117
00:06:32.374 --> 00:06:37.450
maybe when you open one of your Office
products to say Hey, there's an update.

118
00:06:37.450 --> 00:06:39.587
And you can go ahead and run that.

119
00:06:39.587 --> 00:06:45.647
And that's also where you can check your
different versions in your Word menu.

120
00:06:45.647 --> 00:06:47.754
And I cover that in
the introduction to Word and

121
00:06:47.754 --> 00:06:49.980
showing you where you can go ahead and
find that.

122
00:06:51.080 --> 00:06:54.815
There's always lots of answers online,
searching for

123
00:06:54.815 --> 00:06:59.990
answers either in the Microsoft Help
files or just in what we call the Oracle.

124
00:06:59.990 --> 00:07:03.241
Just go to any of your
favorite search engines and

125
00:07:03.241 --> 00:07:05.780
just type in what you want to find.

126
00:07:05.780 --> 00:07:09.633
And there's the world of the Internet
to help find the answers for

127
00:07:09.633 --> 00:07:11.044
any of your questions.

128
00:07:11.044 --> 00:07:15.160
And everybody uses these products for
different reasons.

129
00:07:15.160 --> 00:07:18.794
The way I use Word may not be
the same as the way you use Word, or

130
00:07:18.794 --> 00:07:20.521
the person down the street.

131
00:07:20.521 --> 00:07:25.580
So everybody has a different way that
they function within the product.

132
00:07:25.580 --> 00:07:30.617
So just be aware of that, and
everybody has different reasons for it.

133
00:07:30.617 --> 00:07:33.180
And most of all have fun with this.

134
00:07:33.180 --> 00:07:36.803
I know that it can be really frustrating
sometimes when you're trying to make Word

135
00:07:36.803 --> 00:07:37.494
do something.

136
00:07:37.494 --> 00:07:40.990
It's just not doing it,
I've been there, I totally understand.

137
00:07:40.990 --> 00:07:44.531
In these episodes we like to keep it
light, we like to keep it fun, and

138
00:07:44.531 --> 00:07:45.214
make jokes.

139
00:07:45.214 --> 00:07:49.222
And try to keep that when
you're off on your own and

140
00:07:49.222 --> 00:07:52.570
using Word is just try
to have fun with it.

141
00:07:52.570 --> 00:07:56.038
And so
I hope to see you in some future episodes,

142
00:07:56.038 --> 00:07:59.003
and let's go ahead and get on with Word.

143
00:07:59.003 --> 00:08:04.723
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Zac and Vonne introduce the Microsoft Word 2016 for Mac application. Vonne describes the product’s history, how to purchase and install, as well as her setup of the Word 2016 Essentials for Mac show. This provides some background information and context for the upcoming episodes.
episodes.title: Introduction to Word
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.088 --> 00:00:13.860
Thank you for choosing OfficeProTV,

3
00:00:13.860 --> 00:00:16.490
empowering the world
through engaging learning.

4
00:00:16.490 --> 00:00:20.480
I'm your host Zach Memos for
Word 2016 Essentials for Mac.

5
00:00:20.480 --> 00:00:23.540
This is introduction to Word and

6
00:00:23.540 --> 00:00:25.680
who's bringing us the information
we need this day?

7
00:00:25.680 --> 00:00:28.160
Well I can't think of no one else but
Vonne Smith.

8
00:00:28.160 --> 00:00:29.264
Von, thank you for having us.

9
00:00:29.264 --> 00:00:30.926
>> Thank you so much for having me.

10
00:00:30.926 --> 00:00:34.561
I love to talk about Word and
I love Word for Mac and so

11
00:00:34.561 --> 00:00:38.213
that's why we're having
our very first episode.

12
00:00:38.213 --> 00:00:39.680
Well, I guess this is the overview.

13
00:00:39.680 --> 00:00:41.157
So I mean-
>> Okay.

14
00:00:41.157 --> 00:00:43.608
>> But then, the overview more's
like introducing the whole show-

15
00:00:43.608 --> 00:00:44.553
>> Very good.

16
00:00:44.553 --> 00:00:46.642
>> Altogether this is introducing Word,

17
00:00:46.642 --> 00:00:50.577
the actual product that we're going
to be learning about in this series.

18
00:00:50.577 --> 00:00:53.975
So I like to always start
from the very beginning and

19
00:00:53.975 --> 00:00:56.828
get you familiar with like, what is Word?

20
00:00:56.828 --> 00:00:59.066
So guess what,
I have a PowerPoint presentation for that.

21
00:00:59.066 --> 00:01:01.658
>> So I do have a question for
you, what is Word?

22
00:01:01.658 --> 00:01:04.047
>> Well, why don't I show you?

23
00:01:04.047 --> 00:01:07.273
How about we go ahead and
jump down into my Powerpoint presentation?

24
00:01:07.273 --> 00:01:13.149
I just kept it in PowerPoint the program,
not going into presentation mode.

25
00:01:13.149 --> 00:01:14.936
Just because, you know what?

26
00:01:14.936 --> 00:01:15.711
Just because.

27
00:01:15.711 --> 00:01:16.305
>> Just because.

28
00:01:16.305 --> 00:01:16.990
>> Why not?

29
00:01:16.990 --> 00:01:22.568
Cuz it's really just kinda helping us
guide me through introducing it to you.

30
00:01:22.568 --> 00:01:28.296
So Word is a Word processing [LAUGH],
one of those use the same

31
00:01:28.296 --> 00:01:33.922
Word in the definition as the term so
it's a little weird.

32
00:01:33.922 --> 00:01:38.005
But what that means is you're
going to type things in there.

33
00:01:38.005 --> 00:01:40.664
You're going to be creating documents.

34
00:01:40.664 --> 00:01:44.351
You could be writing a letter,
you could be writing notes.

35
00:01:44.351 --> 00:01:46.745
You could be writing a script,
you could be writing a book.

36
00:01:46.745 --> 00:01:48.670
You could be creating a manual,

37
00:01:48.670 --> 00:01:52.532
all sorts of different things
are why you would want to use Word.

38
00:01:52.532 --> 00:01:59.322
And it is the, I'll call it maybe
the main product in the Office Suite.

39
00:01:59.322 --> 00:02:02.520
Some people might say,
I think Outlook is the main product.

40
00:02:02.520 --> 00:02:04.219
Or Excel, they're all there.

41
00:02:04.219 --> 00:02:08.416
I would say the big three would be Word,
Excel, and Outlook,

42
00:02:08.416 --> 00:02:13.607
you know what we'll throw PowerPoint
in there, all of them are cool [LAUGH].

43
00:02:13.607 --> 00:02:18.224
But you can see you could be doing
short or long document processing and

44
00:02:18.224 --> 00:02:20.032
doing different layouts.

45
00:02:20.032 --> 00:02:24.997
I will say that sometimes
people want to use Word for

46
00:02:24.997 --> 00:02:31.130
more of a page layout program
such as InDesign or Illustrator.

47
00:02:31.130 --> 00:02:35.495
I've seen people make Word do things
where I'm like, wow that's impressive.

48
00:02:35.495 --> 00:02:42.412
[LAUGH] Cuz that's pretty hard
to make it do it but it can.

49
00:02:42.412 --> 00:02:44.457
There is another product called Publisher.

50
00:02:44.457 --> 00:02:47.104
Publisher's a pretty cool Office product.

51
00:02:47.104 --> 00:02:48.495
Is not available for Mac, though.

52
00:02:48.495 --> 00:02:50.163
It is a PC-only type thing.

53
00:02:50.163 --> 00:02:55.106
So just in case, I just realized
that we're in our Word for Mac show,

54
00:02:55.106 --> 00:02:58.782
and I'm talking about
a PC-only type of product.

55
00:02:58.782 --> 00:03:01.333
But anyways, I digress.

56
00:03:01.333 --> 00:03:05.271
We'll let's just go ahead and
keep on Word as Word, great product.

57
00:03:05.271 --> 00:03:12.480
So as I just mentioned, it is part of
the Office 365 suite of applications and

58
00:03:12.480 --> 00:03:18.192
you can purchase different
product plans with Office 365.

59
00:03:18.192 --> 00:03:20.418
And that, there are a bunch of them, okay?

60
00:03:20.418 --> 00:03:23.738
Now there is enterprise licenses.

61
00:03:23.738 --> 00:03:28.587
There's small business licenses
there's just a Home Office.

62
00:03:28.587 --> 00:03:32.186
And I have a link on this particular
slide that you guys have access to it,

63
00:03:32.186 --> 00:03:34.890
in a PDF format,
that you can go ahead and grab.

64
00:03:34.890 --> 00:03:38.510
And so if you're interested in
looking into other product plans,

65
00:03:38.510 --> 00:03:41.610
then you should definitely
consult the website.

66
00:03:41.610 --> 00:03:46.475
And what you buy within that particular
plan of how many of the products,

67
00:03:46.475 --> 00:03:51.603
that determines what level of subscription
that you're going to be using.

68
00:03:51.603 --> 00:03:55.028
And notice on this particular slide,
I do have that Access,

69
00:03:55.028 --> 00:03:58.867
while it is part of the Office Suite,
it is a PC only type of product.

70
00:03:58.867 --> 00:04:04.141
And so is Publisher, but the rest of them,
they should have Mac versions of it,

71
00:04:04.141 --> 00:04:07.074
but we're gonna be concentrating on Word.

72
00:04:07.074 --> 00:04:13.074
And then how you purchase your product
because the way that you purchase

73
00:04:13.074 --> 00:04:18.081
software, at least in the past,
you could get it on a disk.

74
00:04:18.081 --> 00:04:19.114

every video in our course library,

302
00:18:47.575 --> 00:18:49.669
is designed to help you achieve more.

303
00:18:49.669 --> 00:18:51.871
And tell everybody you
know about OfficeProTV.

304
00:18:51.871 --> 00:18:53.270
They'll be really glad you did.

305
00:18:53.270 --> 00:18:54.130
Thanks for watching.

306
00:18:54.130 --> 00:18:54.870
I'm Zach Memos.

307
00:18:54.870 --> 00:18:55.680
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

308
00:18:55.680 --> 00:18:56.713
>> And we will see you soon.

309
00:18:56.713 --> 00:19:02.479
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne demonstrate and explain the basic functionality of the Word 2016 application in the macOS environment. Here you will learn foundational options like open/close Word, start a new file, open an existing file, use the minimize/restore/maximize/full screen buttons, work with multiple files, save vs. save as, and understand keyboard layouts.
episodes.title: Word Basics
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:08.491
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.885 --> 00:00:15.837
Greetings everyone and welcome to
another exciting episode of OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:15.837 --> 00:00:17.480
I'm your host, Justin Dennison.

4
00:00:17.480 --> 00:00:19.461
And in today's episode, well,

2016 Essentials for Mac.

6
00:00:23.514 --> 00:00:26.099

but luckily for you,

actually learning is gonna be a whole lot
easier for our basic Word operations.

8

And here to help us in the studio is our
very own Word wizard, Ms. Vonne Smith.

9
00:00:34.550 --> 00:00:36.122

>> I'm doing great.

10

I love being called a wizard.

11
00:00:37.484 --> 00:00:39.615
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] [SOUND]

>> I know, [SOUND] now you know it.

13

[LAUGH] But you're right,
we are starting super basic right now.

14
00:00:45.490 --> 00:00:49.070
We're gonna start at the foundations,
even throw in a little bit of just the Mac

00:00:49.070 --> 00:00:53.600
operating system, just kinda getting used
to like, well, how do I even start Word?

16
00:00:53.600 --> 00:00:55.075
That's step number one.

17
00:00:55.075 --> 00:00:58.580
[LAUGH] And then what can I do
with some basic file news, and

We've already talked about our

what is Word, and we have our locally

21
00:01:09.350 --> 00:01:12.340
And so that's where we're gonna go ahead

22

So why don't we go ahead and

23
00:01:15.130 --> 00:01:18.565
You can see that I have my

00:01:18.565 --> 00:01:21.790
it makes me feel very spacey.

25
00:01:21.790 --> 00:01:24.085
Well, I usually feel
spacey a lot of times.

26
00:01:24.085 --> 00:01:26.342
[LAUGH]
>> I was getting ready to say,

27
00:01:26.342 --> 00:01:28.795
I'm not sure if that's
an appropriately good adjective.

28
00:01:28.795 --> 00:01:32.005
[LAUGH] We're like,
what are we doing again?

29
00:01:32.005 --> 00:01:32.902
I don't know.

30
00:01:32.902 --> 00:01:34.041
[LAUGHTER]
>> I feel like I say that a lot actually.

31
00:01:34.041 --> 00:01:35.421
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

32
00:01:35.421 --> 00:01:37.204
>> [LAUGH] So it's a perfect way to start.

33
00:01:37.204 --> 00:01:40.060
[LAUGH] Yeah, story of my life.

34

So we've got our desktop ready to go, and
like I said, we have it locally installed.

35
00:01:43.460 --> 00:01:46.600
So how can we open up this program?

36
00:01:46.600 --> 00:01:48.445
Well in Mac, just like anything,

00:01:48.445 --> 00:01:51.570
it's really a lot of
different ways we can go to.

38
00:01:51.570 --> 00:01:54.729
We can always start down by our Launchpad,
and Justin, I don't know,

40
00:01:56.110 --> 00:01:57.860
>> By accident sometimes.

41
00:01:57.860 --> 00:02:02.800
There's some keyboard shortcuts on the top
part of your keyboard that'll actually

42
00:02:02.800 --> 00:02:05.274
launch the Launchpad,
launch the Launchpad.

43
00:02:05.274 --> 00:02:06.540
>> [LAUGH]
>> And every once in a while I'm like,

00:02:06.540 --> 00:02:08.730
well, it's already there,
I'll go ahead and click.

45
00:02:08.730 --> 00:02:13.110
But it wasn't actually my actual intention
to access it through that capability.

46
00:02:13.110 --> 00:02:14.010
>> Yeah, I usually do that to.

47
00:02:14.010 --> 00:02:16.390
So, [LAUGH] but
I figured I'd just go ahead and

49
00:02:19.220 --> 00:02:21.580
We go ahead and open up the launchpad.

00:02:21.580 --> 00:02:23.740
Now I can see that I do

But sometimes you gotta

00:02:25.590 --> 00:02:27.290
it might be on one

So if I was on this screen,

Well then you just go ahead and

00:02:35.340 --> 00:02:37.250
I love me a magic mouse.

57
00:02:37.250 --> 00:02:39.710
I don't know about y'all, but man.

58
00:02:39.710 --> 00:02:40.630
I'm definitely down with it.

00:02:40.630 --> 00:02:43.650

00:02:43.650 --> 00:02:46.390

Again I don't normally

It's right over here in

You gotta go Command first then Space Bar,

And then you can go ahead and

00:03:34.300 --> 00:03:38.154

If you've recently

00:03:59.660 --> 00:04:03.160
But behind the scenes, I'm going to leave

00:04:03.160 --> 00:04:06.090

89
00:04:06.090 --> 00:04:09.490
So there are times where I have installed

00:04:09.490 --> 00:04:12.040

sometimes it takes a little bit.

00:04:12.040 --> 00:04:16.230
And maybe even a reboot depending on what

92
00:04:16.230 --> 00:04:17.430
So just keep that in mind.

93
00:04:17.430 --> 00:04:20.236
>> I was about to say, did you try

00:04:20.236 --> 00:04:21.400
>> [LAUGH]
>> Good old restart's

00:04:21.400 --> 00:04:24.480
always gonna fix things,
pretty much anything in computers.

96
00:04:24.480 --> 00:04:26.296
But that's actually a really good point.

00:04:26.296 --> 00:04:29.780
Because yeah, I'm not sure if I
have experienced it first hand but

00:04:29.780 --> 00:04:32.950
I totally understand what you're saying,

Especially if you've just went ahead and

So that's a good point to make.

So I'm just gonna go ahead,

You can see over on the left hand side,

00:06:20.720 --> 00:06:25.520

My off stuff?

[LAUGH] My freelance.

Things that I shared with you.

And then of course Open goes

00:06:53.420 --> 00:06:56.620

00:06:56.620 --> 00:07:00.110

00:07:00.110 --> 00:07:01.920

That's okay.

150
00:07:02.740 --> 00:07:04.700
You're all, you're okay.

00:07:04.700 --> 00:07:06.010
It's still open.

Those things you need to get used to

So you can see down on here on

00:07:26.720 --> 00:07:27.505
It's the dottom.

159

>> [LAUGH] Exactly.

160

161
00:07:30.480 --> 00:07:32.520
>> Yup, you totally read my mind.

Exactly where we're going.

163
00:07:34.150 --> 00:07:38.060
Down to the dock bar

00:07:38.060 --> 00:07:41.180
Notice down here you can see

If you ever wondered what those were, like

00:07:50.727 --> 00:07:52.971
And also notice that up here at the top,

00:07:52.971 --> 00:07:55.972

the menu bar across the top.

00:07:55.972 --> 00:07:58.062
That's the nice thing about, that I like.

170
00:07:58.062 --> 00:08:02.384
About Mac version Office products
is that it kinda combines,

00:08:02.384 --> 00:08:05.707
like you still have the old
school menus that you

172
00:08:05.707 --> 00:08:10.210

version got rid of it all.

173
00:08:10.210 --> 00:08:11.480
Now you only have it in the ribbon.

174
00:08:11.480 --> 00:08:12.370
So that's kinda cute.

175
00:08:12.370 --> 00:08:15.700
So you can always go
back to your File menu.

176
00:08:15.700 --> 00:08:20.560
Your File menu is where you get
things like File, New, File, Open.

177
00:08:20.560 --> 00:08:22.613
And I can actually say File, Open and

178
00:08:22.613 --> 00:08:25.760
File, New, and
actually have a menu to refer back to.

179
00:08:25.760 --> 00:08:29.250
Otherwise, when you just say, I really
meant the backstage view and everything,

180
00:08:29.250 --> 00:08:31.875
while I'm working and
often this for WIndows.

181
00:08:31.875 --> 00:08:34.865
So, it's, kind of,
nice that this is all here.

182
00:08:34.865 --> 00:08:39.135
So, this is another place that you
can go to, to start a new document.

183
00:08:39.135 --> 00:08:44.085
Just what we're going to do and
it brings up our document one.

184
00:08:44.085 --> 00:08:45.315
So, now I have this.

185
00:08:45.315 --> 00:08:49.235
My resolution is a little lower on my
screen, so it might not fully encompass

186
00:08:49.235 --> 00:08:52.415
the whole screen that you see
when you start a new document.

187
00:08:52.415 --> 00:08:59.390
This is a very mac like thing I work
in both platforms, I am bilingual.

188
00:08:59.390 --> 00:09:03.740
I do a lot of stuff, as you see in
the library, both for Windows and for Mac.

189
00:09:03.740 --> 00:09:08.630
So if you're a Mac person, you kind of get
used to the kind of free floating window

190
00:09:08.630 --> 00:09:14.020
like functionality of
the operating system.

191
00:09:14.020 --> 00:09:18.210
And you have your two pointed arrows on
any of your sides of your windows, or

192
00:09:18.210 --> 00:09:25.290
your corners of your windows that you can
go ahead and start resizing this down.

193
00:09:25.290 --> 00:09:30.130
Grabbing by that top bar which
is called the title bar here,

194
00:09:30.130 --> 00:09:32.750
as you can kinda start moving this around.

195
00:09:32.750 --> 00:09:35.630
And I'm gonna kinda,
well, move it over here.

196
00:09:35.630 --> 00:09:38.270
All right, so this is just basics.

197
00:09:38.270 --> 00:09:40.270
Right, we're just getting started and

198
00:09:40.270 --> 00:09:42.920
just kinda getting familiar
with this environment.

199
00:09:42.920 --> 00:09:46.530
Well, that we have a whole another
episode about the Word environment.

200
00:09:46.530 --> 00:09:52.680
This is again just the Windows, it's weird
when I say Windows, but I'm really a Mac.

201
00:09:52.680 --> 00:09:55.750
>> Technically,
it is a window-ing kind of engine.

202
00:09:55.750 --> 00:09:58.430
So we think of Windows as
synonymous with Microsoft,

203
00:09:58.430 --> 00:10:02.750
but a Windows Display Manager
is what we're seeing.

204
00:10:02.750 --> 00:10:05.990
And there are some nuanced
differences where you're like

205
00:10:05.990 --> 00:10:08.540
that doesn't work like I
thought it was going to.

206
00:10:08.540 --> 00:10:10.060
And I'm sure you're gonna cover this.

207
00:10:10.060 --> 00:10:14.530
>> Man that was a perfect lead-in and
that was not in the script by any means.

208
00:10:14.530 --> 00:10:19.062
There's no notes for him to say that so
I was just like that was good.

209
00:10:19.062 --> 00:10:24.140
[LAUGH] Yes, if you are bilingual
these buttons are gonna be different.

210
00:10:24.140 --> 00:10:26.370
Like, significantly different.

211
00:10:26.370 --> 00:10:30.090
Where one they're on the left hand side
besides being on the right hand side but

212
00:10:30.090 --> 00:10:32.970
these are your, the red,
yellow and green buttons.

213
00:10:32.970 --> 00:10:36.840
I know they have actual names, but
let's go with the colors, all right?

214
00:10:36.840 --> 00:10:39.770
Let's start with the yellow
button in the middle.

215
00:10:39.770 --> 00:10:42.620
The yellow button in the middle

00:22:54.770 --> 00:22:59.658
So I'm not making any changes
to my original document,

439
00:22:59.658 --> 00:23:02.470
that's what file save as does.

440
00:23:02.470 --> 00:23:07.270
And I still do it to this day, where I
just go ahead and commit the changes,

441
00:23:07.270 --> 00:23:11.660
like, whoops, no I didn't want to do it on
that file, I wanted to make it's own copy.

442
00:23:11.660 --> 00:23:16.900
Sometimes I'll even do a save as before
I even start making my modifications.

443
00:23:16.900 --> 00:23:20.880
Because I can tell you I've done that and
then made the changes to the wrong file

444
00:23:20.880 --> 00:23:24.920
and it just gets you all kinda
twirled around a little bit.

445
00:23:24.920 --> 00:23:28.840
But that is the basics
of save versus save as.

446
00:23:28.840 --> 00:23:33.090
And I can put it straight on my desktop,
let's go with there.

447
00:23:33.090 --> 00:23:36.190
If I change the name and the location,
and there's where I got it,

448
00:23:36.190 --> 00:23:38.350
You can even see it right on over there.

449
00:23:38.350 --> 00:23:42.020
And there you go so file save as and
save and there we go.

450
00:23:42.020 --> 00:23:46.530
Closing remember we talked about our red
x, this would go ahead and close the file.

451
00:23:46.530 --> 00:23:53.652
I could also do a Cmd+W to that
particular file, this one right here.

452
00:23:53.652 --> 00:23:57.683
If I started typing just to save
back on that save versus save as.

453
00:23:57.683 --> 00:24:02.739
The very first time that Save and
Save as are the same command is only when

454
00:24:02.739 --> 00:24:07.626
you start from a blank new document,
and if I tried to do File > Save or

455
00:24:07.626 --> 00:24:12.288
Cmd+S, it's gonna say, well,
I don't have a name and a home.

456
00:24:12.288 --> 00:24:15.870
I don't have that.
This is the only time it will say it.

457
00:24:15.870 --> 00:24:18.828
It always pulls that first line of
whatever you have, like [SOUND].

458
00:24:18.828 --> 00:24:20.290
[LAUGH] That's what it's
trying to name my file.

459
00:24:21.550 --> 00:24:22.110
And then you can do that.

460
00:24:22.110 --> 00:24:26.770
I'm gonna cancel this cuz I don't
need to save any of my changes.

461
00:24:26.770 --> 00:24:30.100
So when I close this,
I am gonna get the, hey, are you sure?

462
00:24:30.100 --> 00:24:33.740
Because you wanna save or you don't
wanna save, or do you want me to cancel?

463
00:24:33.740 --> 00:24:34.609
This point,

464
00:24:34.609 --> 00:24:39.755
I do not want to save my changes to this
document because I don't need a [SOUND].

465
00:24:39.755 --> 00:24:45.212
So, I'm good there, cuz that's what
it said, in case you were wondering.

466
00:24:45.212 --> 00:24:47.283
>> [LAUGH] [SOUND] Sounds very important,
you probably should have saved that.

467
00:24:47.283 --> 00:24:48.011
>> [LAUGH] Right?

468
00:24:48.011 --> 00:24:52.810
All right, so the last thing that
I wanna leave off with is just

00:24:52.810 --> 00:24:55.650
a little bit about the keyboard.

00:24:55.650 --> 00:24:57.180
This might sound like, really?

00:24:57.180 --> 00:24:59.460
We're gonna review the keys on a keyboard?

472
00:24:59.460 --> 00:25:01.830
Like, this is the letter A.
No, I'm not talking about that.

00:25:01.830 --> 00:25:06.380
I just wanna throw some things out there
because, well, it seems very simple,

474
00:25:06.380 --> 00:25:09.660
but I can tell you how many
times this trips up people,

475
00:25:09.660 --> 00:25:13.230
especially if you're going back and
forth between operating systems.

476
00:25:13.230 --> 00:25:16.560
And, well, the Mac keyboard,
it's a little different.

477
00:25:16.560 --> 00:25:19.850
So and I've actually brought
in my external keyboard.

478
00:25:19.850 --> 00:25:21.680
Let's go ahead and
take a look at my keyboard.

479
00:25:21.680 --> 00:25:24.270
I actually brought in both my keyboards,
like I said.

480
00:25:24.270 --> 00:25:26.350
This is the one from home that I use.

481
00:25:26.350 --> 00:25:30.600
The reason why we can't plug in,
Justin, you know this.

482
00:25:30.600 --> 00:25:36.930
USB 2.0 to not to USB 2.0,
cuz I have a fancy new laptop here.

483
00:25:36.930 --> 00:25:41.660
But on your laptop keyboard,
just know that for one thing,

484
00:25:41.660 --> 00:25:44.450
I don't have a function
key across the top.

485
00:25:44.450 --> 00:25:46.830
I do enough work that I
really want my function keys.

486
00:25:46.830 --> 00:25:49.810
And I know you can map things and do all
sorts of crazy stuff with your keyboard

487
00:25:49.810 --> 00:25:54.310
preferences, but
just know you have your Delete key here.

488
00:25:54.310 --> 00:25:58.913
It's one of those things where,
as a Mac person, you have Delete, but

489
00:25:58.913 --> 00:26:01.310
then that's not the Backspace key.

490
00:26:01.310 --> 00:26:05.540
People say, use the Backspace, because
that will go ahead and backspace over.

491
00:26:05.540 --> 00:26:10.220
Well, there's a forward Delete
key on a full-sized keyboard, and

492
00:26:10.220 --> 00:26:12.800
it also has my function keys.

493
00:26:12.800 --> 00:26:16.698
I have some ones like the Page Up,
Page Down, the Home, the End.

494
00:26:16.698 --> 00:26:20.760
And then my function key right here
that I can kinda do some stuff.

495
00:26:20.760 --> 00:26:23.790
I will tell you,
as somebody who does a lot of typesetting,

496
00:26:23.790 --> 00:26:26.520
like when I'm working in InDesign and
everything, I always have this plugged in.

497
00:26:26.520 --> 00:26:29.850
I just forgot my dongle,
[LAUGH] but we've got that.

498
00:26:29.850 --> 00:26:35.689
So, notice you don't have some of these
keys if you're working on a laptop here.

499
00:26:35.689 --> 00:26:39.743
So, we've got the Delete key, but
there's not the forward Delete key.

500
00:26:39.743 --> 00:26:44.189
But, a lot of times, if you, I don't know
if you know this, but I'm sure you do,

501
00:26:44.189 --> 00:26:48.572
but the Function Delete, that I'll
actually use, it has a forward Delete key,

502
00:26:48.572 --> 00:26:51.215
which [LAUGH] I didn't know for
the longest time so

503
00:26:51.215 --> 00:26:54.340
I'd have to move my mouse and
like go all over the places.

504
00:26:54.340 --> 00:26:58.090
But just be aware that
your keyboard does kinda

505
00:26:58.090 --> 00:27:00.240
have some things that
might be a little weird.

506
00:27:00.240 --> 00:27:04.590
If I'm using my laptop and
I wanna do Page Up and Page Down,

507
00:27:04.590 --> 00:27:09.250
I don't have that unless I specifically
program the Page Up, Page Down.

508
00:27:09.250 --> 00:27:14.670
And these particular hot keys right here
are, call hot keys, you can combine them

509
00:27:14.670 --> 00:27:19.010

to be able to help you navigate around.

510
00:27:19.010 --> 00:27:20.680
And I really like to use this.

511
00:27:20.680 --> 00:27:24.804
So if I'm going in a couple of
the episodes where you don't have these,

512
00:27:24.804 --> 00:27:25.709
that's okay.

513
00:27:25.709 --> 00:27:29.390
I'll always give you alternative
ways of moving around your document.

514
00:27:29.390 --> 00:27:30.820
But I just wanted to throw that out there,
and

515
00:27:30.820 --> 00:27:33.580
also that you have your
Cmd key right here.

516
00:27:33.580 --> 00:27:35.630
You also have your Option.

517
00:27:35.630 --> 00:27:37.715
I might call that an Alt key.

518
00:27:37.715 --> 00:27:40.922
Because, well,
it says Alt right there, [LAUGH].

519
00:27:40.922 --> 00:27:42.550
And then you also have your Ctrl.

520
00:27:42.550 --> 00:27:46.625
Cmd and Ctrl are different than, well,

521
00:27:46.625 --> 00:27:50.707
each other, when you're using keyboard

522
00:27:50.707 --> 00:27:53.437
Cuz I had already thrown

523
00:27:53.437 --> 00:27:58.157
like using your keyboard shortcuts

524
00:27:58.157 --> 00:28:02.472
I always have to remind myself like,
which one, like the arrow, I think,

525
00:28:02.472 --> 00:28:06.737
is the Ctrl, and the little infinity
sign or whatever is the Cmd, right?

526
00:28:06.737 --> 00:28:08.535
>> Yeah, I always mess those up as well.

527
00:28:08.535 --> 00:28:12.894
And do keep in mind a lot of the times
what'll happen between Mac and Windows,

528
00:28:12.894 --> 00:28:15.847
if you're coming from

529
00:28:15.847 --> 00:28:20.006
Ctrl on a Windows-based platform is
most of the time, not exclusively,

530
00:28:20.006 --> 00:28:23.652
most of the time, well,
it's replaced by the Cmd key, right?

00:28:23.652 --> 00:28:26.942

00:28:26.942 --> 00:28:30.442

it was available on Windows,

533
00:28:30.442 --> 00:28:33.317
a lot of times you can just
replace Cmd with Ctrl.

534
00:28:33.317 --> 00:28:36.430
Not always, though, so
your mileage may vary.

535
00:28:36.430 --> 00:28:41.130
>> Yeah, and
you might even hear me say Ctrl+S.

536
00:28:41.130 --> 00:28:42.560
I really mean Cmd, okay?

537
00:28:42.560 --> 00:28:44.610
Because, like I said, I work on both.

538
00:28:44.610 --> 00:28:45.740
Just one quick little thing.

Let me just jump back

I have a File > New, and just to show
you those things that Justin and

I are talking about.

00:28:50.940 --> 00:28:55.481
You can see over on the right-hand side,

00:28:55.481 --> 00:28:57.420
But I'm pretty sure that's the Shift key.

544
00:28:57.420 --> 00:29:01.460
Okay, and then the View,

Pretty sure that's the Ctrl,

546
00:29:05.380 --> 00:29:08.600
Let me try it.

547
00:29:08.600 --> 00:29:10.600
Yep, that's it, okay [LAUGH].
So that's what it is.

548
00:29:10.600 --> 00:29:13.280
And there's also the one with

00:29:13.280 --> 00:29:16.570
Wow, it's really hard for

550
00:29:16.570 --> 00:29:18.480
That one, right there.

551
00:29:18.480 --> 00:29:20.425
That's the Option, I believe.

552
00:29:20.425 --> 00:29:24.163
>> Yeah, it looks like a dancer out of

00:29:24.163 --> 00:29:24.910
I don't know.

554
00:29:24.910 --> 00:29:27.921
>> [LAUGH] My god, that's totally it.

555
00:29:27.921 --> 00:29:31.035
>> [LAUGH]
>> Wow, now I've got the song in my head.

556
00:29:31.035 --> 00:29:33.340
[LAUGH] That's fantastic.

557
00:29:33.340 --> 00:29:33.870
>> You're welcome, you're welcome.

558
00:29:33.870 --> 00:29:35.000
>> Yes, thank you so much,

so, but yeah, just a couple

00:29:37.910 --> 00:29:41.500
Keyboard shortcuts, just knowing that

00:29:41.500 --> 00:29:43.490
I'm gonna just hit the Esc, and

00:29:46.890 --> 00:29:50.818

[LAUGH]
>> All right, Vonne, well,

570

Now, some of this was commingled,
so if you're familiar with,

00:30:09.740 --> 00:30:11.066
he's like, I already knew that, well,

I'd be careful because a lot of times

573
00:30:14.650 --> 00:30:19.630
And well, we do know more about Word in

574
00:30:19.630 --> 00:30:22.150
But it looks like we're out of time for
this episode, so we're gonna go ahead and

575
00:30:22.150 --> 00:30:23.180

576
00:30:23.180 --> 00:30:26.060
Signing off for OfficePro.TV,
I've been your host, Justin Dennison.

577
00:30:26.060 --> 00:30:26.596
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

578
00:30:26.596 --> 00:30:28.671
>> And we'll see you next time.

579
00:30:28.671 --> 00:30:35.050
[NOISE]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore the Word 2016 interface. They identify items such as the title bar, menu bar, ribbon, contextual tabs, quick access toolbar, status bar, views, zoom, and find. They also demonstrate how to customize the quick access toolbar.
episodes.title: Word Interface

And maybe throughout this series you

Welcome to Word, that is my title bar.

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne demonstrate the different document views and zoom options available in Word 2016 for Mac. Here you will see how to work with the focus, web layout, outline, draft, and print layout views. They also cover single and multi-page view, the ruler, and zoom functions.
episodes.title: Document Views and Zoom

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne illustrate one of the core Microsoft Word 2016 for Mac foundations – navigating a document. They explain the different mouse cursor icons that you'll encounter, show keyboard navigation shortcuts, explore the navigation pane, and discuss status bar options.
episodes.title: Navigate a Document

00:16:18.160 --> 00:16:23.080
Watch, jump, jump, jump,
it's jumping by paragraphs.

302
00:16:23.080 --> 00:16:27.570
So that's where you can go up and down,
just kinda of an easier way to go by using

303
00:16:27.570 --> 00:16:32.250
that Alt key in correlation with your
arrows to get where you need by word or

304
00:16:32.250 --> 00:16:34.900
by paragraph depending if you are going
up and down or left and right.

305
00:16:36.040 --> 00:16:37.180
The other one that you can do,

306
00:16:37.180 --> 00:16:40.980
let's get my cursor in front of dark
here in this particular sentence.

307
00:16:40.980 --> 00:16:45.690
The Command key, the Command key if
you hold it and use your right arrow,

308
00:16:45.690 --> 00:16:47.685
go to the other side of the page.

309
00:16:47.685 --> 00:16:52.030
See it stops over on the end
of the line which is hurrying.

310
00:16:54.610 --> 00:16:58.747
In Windows it's the Control key will
jump you by word, it's not Alt.

311
00:16:58.747 --> 00:17:00.837
So it's weird, I know, right.

312
00:17:00.837 --> 00:17:05.370
It's like, come on,
we can not have any continuity at all.

313
00:17:05.370 --> 00:17:08.908
[SOUND] Okay, that's why I keep
emphasizing this for you guys.

314
00:17:08.908 --> 00:17:11.651
So hopefully you can be
as frustrated as me.

315
00:17:11.651 --> 00:17:15.980
[LAUGH] But really just to illuminate
the fact that it does that.

316
00:17:17.030 --> 00:17:21.890
And that's where we got, all right,
so now I'm going to grab my prop.

317
00:17:21.890 --> 00:17:23.465
Grab my keyboard over here,

318
00:17:23.465 --> 00:17:27.960
okay, cuz there's some other keys that
are really nice to be able to use.

319
00:17:27.960 --> 00:17:32.090
I'm using my mouse right here to
put my cursor in front of Alice.

320
00:17:32.090 --> 00:17:34.090
Page up, page down.

321
00:17:34.090 --> 00:17:35.490
Love that.

322
00:17:35.490 --> 00:17:38.890
When I do this,
if I hit the page down key on my keyboard,

323
00:17:38.890 --> 00:17:43.930
notice it's jumping like full screenshots,
if we want to call that.

324
00:17:43.930 --> 00:17:47.980
So it's kind of taking this either
chapter two, Through The Looking Glass.

325
00:17:47.980 --> 00:17:50.238
So you can see that it's
barely up at that the top now.

326
00:17:50.238 --> 00:17:54.760
So it's jumping with your cursor,
cursor's still there,

327
00:17:54.760 --> 00:17:59.330
by screens not by pages all together.

328
00:17:59.330 --> 00:18:01.400
So just be careful about that.

329
00:18:01.400 --> 00:18:06.622
But if I scroll out,
you might not be able to see this

00:18:06.622 --> 00:18:11.724
very clearly, but
if I hold my Command key down and

331
00:18:11.724 --> 00:18:16.851
use my Page Down,
now I'm jumping by full pages.

332
00:18:16.851 --> 00:18:21.190
That's a true page,
if you wanna say, up and page down.

333
00:18:21.190 --> 00:18:24.280
So jump up, holding the Command and
the Page Up and

334
00:18:24.280 --> 00:18:28.500
Page Down button will get you
to the top of every page.

335
00:18:28.500 --> 00:18:31.585
Let's zoom in a little bit more.

336
00:18:31.585 --> 00:18:37.166
Your Home and End keys, e n d,
if you have those on those keyboard,

00:18:37.166 --> 00:18:41.370
the End by itself will take
you to the end of a line.

338
00:18:41.370 --> 00:18:44.750
The Home will take you to
the beginning of the line.

339
00:18:44.750 --> 00:18:48.910
That's the way most programs work,
if you have homes and ends.

340
00:18:50.750 --> 00:18:55.160
This is probably my super fave,
I'm using my scroll wheel down here.

341
00:18:55.160 --> 00:18:57.500
How do I get to the very
beginning of my document?

342
00:18:57.500 --> 00:19:00.630
How do I get to the very
end of my document?

343
00:19:00.630 --> 00:19:02.420
My fave, Command Home.

344
00:19:03.420 --> 00:19:05.336
Hold the Command, click the Home key.

345
00:19:05.336 --> 00:19:10.086
It doesn't matter if you have 185
pages and you're on page 183,

346
00:19:10.086 --> 00:19:14.280
you hold Ctrl or sorry, sorry,
doing the Windows thing.

347
00:19:14.280 --> 00:19:16.170
Hold Command, click the Home key,

348
00:19:16.170 --> 00:19:20.160
you will always go to the very
beginning of the document.

349
00:19:20.160 --> 00:19:20.690
Love that.

350
00:19:21.870 --> 00:19:26.480
In reverse, if you wanna say or
the opposite, hold the Command key,

351
00:19:26.480 --> 00:19:29.490
click the End, e n d, key,
takes it to the end of the document.

352
00:19:29.490 --> 00:19:33.900
You're writing your novel, right, you
want to get to the very end, Command End,

353
00:19:33.900 --> 00:19:35.098
[SOUND] keep on typing.

354
00:19:35.098 --> 00:19:36.272
Want to get to the beginning?

355
00:19:36.272 --> 00:19:38.274
Command Home.

356
00:19:38.274 --> 00:19:41.026
Those are my favorites,
I super super love those.

357
00:19:41.026 --> 00:19:43.460
[LAUGH] So that's what we've got there.

358
00:19:43.460 --> 00:19:48.380
And then the only other thing I wanted to
go with, cuz these are, kind of ends my

00:19:48.380 --> 00:19:55.060
shortcuts from navigating, it's really

360
00:19:55.060 --> 00:20:00.180
Down here I have page 1 of 7, but
this is section one of this document.

361
00:20:00.180 --> 00:20:04.221
I know that there are sections,
cuz remember, I made this.

362
00:20:04.221 --> 00:20:06.422
So, two things.

00:20:06.422 --> 00:20:06.983
Two things.

00:20:06.983 --> 00:20:13.040
[LAUGH] One is having your status
bar be able to show sections.

365
00:20:13.040 --> 00:20:17.330
If you right click down anywhere in this
kind of blank area of your status bar,

366
00:20:17.330 --> 00:20:21.710
you can get into all the different things
that you can show on the status bar.

367
00:20:21.710 --> 00:20:24.120
This is the same in all of your
Office products, by the way.

368
00:20:24.120 --> 00:20:27.380
So this is definitely one that
I will go with is sections.

369
00:20:27.380 --> 00:20:29.470
And notice there is section one.

370
00:20:29.470 --> 00:20:31.700
If I scroll on down,

371
00:20:31.700 --> 00:20:34.530
I think if you get into, yep,
gotta get a little bit further down.

372
00:20:34.530 --> 00:20:36.000
There you go, see?

373
00:20:36.000 --> 00:20:37.421
Section two.

374
00:20:37.421 --> 00:20:41.650
I have made next page section breaks.

375
00:20:41.650 --> 00:20:43.040
Why do you want to do that?

376
00:20:43.040 --> 00:20:44.540
There's a variety of reasons, okay.

377
00:20:44.540 --> 00:20:49.840
But that's just to kind of let you know

378
00:20:49.840 --> 00:20:53.590
It could be about your sections and

379
00:20:53.590 --> 00:20:58.870
And then I'm also going to talk

00:20:58.870 --> 00:21:04.000
that I forgot I turned on in the last
episode, show all non printing characters,

381
00:21:04.000 --> 00:21:05.755
or I refer to it as the show hide button.

382
00:21:05.755 --> 00:21:10.750
If you click on this, it's gonna show you
all of those non printing characters,

383
00:21:10.750 --> 00:21:17.200
the enter marks, tabs, where I made,
right there, section breaks.

384
00:21:17.200 --> 00:21:22.067
Turning that on will let you know
about all the different things that is

385
00:21:22.067 --> 00:21:25.134
going on your document that you can't see.

386
00:21:25.134 --> 00:21:28.753
Maybe you've experienced this, Justin,
somebody gives you a file and you start

387
00:21:28.753 --> 00:21:32.319

then all of a sudden you scroll down and

388
00:21:32.319 --> 00:21:34.400
there's this big blank
paper in the middle.

389
00:21:34.400 --> 00:21:37.980
Why is there a blank page,
there wasn't a blank page there before?

390
00:21:37.980 --> 00:21:39.520
Be like I don't know what happened.

391
00:21:39.520 --> 00:21:46.150
It's cuz somebody or something, if you
want to say, put in a manual page break.

392
00:21:46.150 --> 00:21:47.730
Break the page.

393
00:21:47.730 --> 00:21:51.602
Well you start adding more,
well that's gonna move everything down and

394
00:21:51.602 --> 00:21:52.816
give you a blank page.

395
00:21:52.816 --> 00:21:56.595
And those are just things that I know I've
experience and people asked me about.

396
00:21:56.595 --> 00:21:59.453
And it's those things that
you can't really see, but

397
00:21:59.453 --> 00:22:02.540
if you turn that button on it
will let you show some stuff.

398
00:22:02.540 --> 00:22:06.270
And so I'm always in this mode,
but that's just me.

399
00:22:06.270 --> 00:22:10.040
You know where it's at, and you know
later when we get into more stuff of

400
00:22:10.040 --> 00:22:11.930
why you're going to want to keep that on.

401
00:22:11.930 --> 00:22:13.132
>> Well Vonne,
I've definitely encountered that.

402
00:22:13.132 --> 00:22:16.699
And to some extent, I add these breaks and
then sometimes I have to go find

I added some things to my own document and

404
00:22:20.444 --> 00:22:24.040
now the formatting is kind of weird and
not what I anticipated.

405
00:22:24.040 --> 00:22:28.304
So that show and
hide character button can be beneficial.

406
00:22:28.304 --> 00:22:30.910
It's kind of like a love
hate relationship with me.

407
00:22:30.910 --> 00:22:34.360
I'm like, I like that you're
showing me what I can't see but

408
00:22:34.360 --> 00:22:37.435
it kind of puts me on edge for
some reason.

409
00:22:37.435 --> 00:22:38.360
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm like, what is all

410
00:22:38.360 --> 00:22:39.670
this stuff-
>> [LAUGH]

411
00:22:39.670 --> 00:22:40.680
>> That I didn't type?

412
00:22:40.680 --> 00:22:43.050
But you kind of did, you set it up.

413
00:22:43.050 --> 00:22:43.720
And well Vonne,

414
00:22:43.720 --> 00:22:48.060
you've definitely shown us how to expedite
our navigation through a document.

415
00:22:48.060 --> 00:22:49.050
So thank you so much.

416
00:22:49.050 --> 00:22:50.830
And hopefully you learned something.

417
00:22:50.830 --> 00:22:54.230
Take a little bit of these and just
integrate them a little bit day by day

418
00:22:54.230 --> 00:22:57.350
as you learn more of these
navigation tips and tricks.

419
00:22:57.350 --> 00:23:01.680
But definitely stay tuned for more
Microsoft Word 2016 Essentials for Mac.

420
00:23:01.680 --> 00:23:03.040
We got more coming at you.

421
00:23:03.040 --> 00:23:04.800
But for now we're going to go ahead and
wrap this one up, so

422
00:23:04.800 --> 00:23:07.840
signing off for OfficeProTV,
I've been your host Justin Dennison.

423
00:23:07.840 --> 00:23:10.661
>> And I'm Vonne Smith
>> And I'll see you next time.

424
00:23:10.661 --> 00:23:16.190
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore the many ways that you can select text in Word 2016. Vonne demonstrates selecting text using both the mouse and keyboard to select words, paragraphs, ranges, and the entire document.
episodes.title: Select Text
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

[MUSIC]

2

Miss Vonne Smith,

how are you all doing today?

But, there's a lot of other

Keyboard shortcuts,
do you know that there's a selection

area that you can use to make

40
00:01:44.170 --> 00:01:45.955

>> Get there better, faster.

41
00:01:45.955 --> 00:01:46.960
>> [LAUGH] Nice,

well why don't we go ahead and jump on

This is the same file that we've been

this is document views and navigation.

45
00:01:56.790 --> 00:01:59.170
So we're going to learn
how to navigate around,

46
00:01:59.170 --> 00:02:01.540
not necessarily navigate,
that was the last episode.

47
00:02:01.540 --> 00:02:03.410
We're gonna select the text in here.

48
00:02:03.410 --> 00:02:07.770
But a lot of the techniques that I showed

49
00:02:07.770 --> 00:02:11.760
it's gonna come back into play a little
bit later down this episode because we're

50
00:02:11.760 --> 00:02:13.500

51
00:02:13.500 --> 00:02:18.210
All right, just to review a little
bit about the navigating,

00:02:18.210 --> 00:02:20.880
always looking at your
mouse cursor icon and

what does it look like,
because that's what it's gonna do.

54
00:02:24.510 --> 00:02:28.260
Right now, if I'm out here or if I'm down
in some text, I'm gonna get an I beam.

55
00:02:28.260 --> 00:02:33.080
The I beam indicates that you will
be able to click and be able to get

00:02:33.080 --> 00:02:37.450
that flashing cursor another key
component of what we need to look for,

57
00:02:37.450 --> 00:02:41.750
that flashing cursor right now is in

58
00:02:41.750 --> 00:02:45.830
Up at the top, we had this little hand
document thing, that's to indicate where

00:02:45.830 --> 00:02:50.160
you can, if you can click in there, I
should double click, just to let you know.

60
00:02:50.160 --> 00:02:53.020
That's gonna get you into the header and
footer sections, okay.

61
00:02:53.020 --> 00:02:54.980
So, just in case you get there,

62
00:02:54.980 --> 00:02:58.400
I'll should put this on the navigate

63
00:02:58.400 --> 00:02:59.660
Now.
So that's all good.

64
00:02:59.660 --> 00:03:04.113
Double clicking in the header, it will

65
00:03:04.113 --> 00:03:04.728

And notice your contextual tab also

00:03:09.146 --> 00:03:15.190

A lot of people get in here and

00:03:17.430 --> 00:03:19.525
It is nice they put this close in here.

70
00:03:19.525 --> 00:03:21.640
But I don't know if
it's always been there.

71
00:03:21.640 --> 00:03:24.260
But [LAUGH] you can double-click
to get into that area.

72
00:03:24.260 --> 00:03:29.290
You can double-click down in your normal

00:03:29.290 --> 00:03:32.760
So just in case you accidentally do

74
00:03:33.760 --> 00:03:37.110
And the other thing to notice
when you're in your document

75
00:03:37.110 --> 00:03:40.380

76
00:03:40.380 --> 00:03:46.480
This left hand side we get a black arrow

77
00:03:46.480 --> 00:03:48.560
just in case you want to know.

78
00:03:48.560 --> 00:03:52.550
And then notice that if I move up,
see how my, I got a black arrow again but

79
00:03:52.550 --> 00:03:54.300
it tilts to the left.

80
00:03:54.300 --> 00:03:58.490
So left arrow, right arrow,
or whatever way its leaning,

81
00:03:58.490 --> 00:04:02.170
the reason why you have this,
versus going to the right hand side,

82
00:04:02.170 --> 00:04:05.060
if I go to the right hand side of my page,
notice it's an I beam.

83
00:04:05.060 --> 00:04:10.110
Because this is that selection area
that I've been kind of mentioning

84
00:04:10.110 --> 00:04:12.460
at least a couple times here
in this little introduction.

85
00:04:13.600 --> 00:04:15.490
Cursors, always good.

86
00:04:15.490 --> 00:04:17.420
I beam, understand.

87
00:04:17.420 --> 00:04:19.750
I would like to select some text.

88
00:04:19.750 --> 00:04:23.310
I would like to select this down,
down, down.

89
00:04:23.310 --> 00:04:26.250
Why?
Because I want to format it or copy it.

90
00:04:26.250 --> 00:04:30.190
We're not getting into like what

91
00:04:30.190 --> 00:04:33.660
This episode is only
about Select to effect.

92
00:04:33.660 --> 00:04:36.290
I need to select this thing

93
00:04:36.290 --> 00:04:38.338
Click hold and drag.

94
00:04:38.338 --> 00:04:38.960
Get my I-beam,

95
00:04:38.960 --> 00:04:42.680
even though my flash encourages its way
over there, that's okay, that's fine.

96
00:04:42.680 --> 00:04:46.680
Because, when I'm going to select,
when I click, get the I-beam.

97
00:04:46.680 --> 00:04:48.580
Drag, hold down the mouse.

98
00:04:48.580 --> 00:04:51.860
Drag, as soon as I'm done,
I let go of the mouse and

00:04:51.860 --> 00:04:56.320

100
00:04:56.320 --> 00:04:57.320
Pull.

101
00:04:57.320 --> 00:05:01.070
Once you get something selected and
you now want to not have it selected,

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne demonstrate how to input text and explain special characters in Word 2016. They talk about adding basic text like letters, numbers, and symbols like \*/%/@. They also explain the difference between backspace and delete, paragraphs and line-breaks, and tabs. Finally, they explain the show non-printing characters button’s function and dive into some history about different character sets.
episodes.title: Input Text and Special Characters

episodes.description: In this episode, Zac and Vonne take a look at our well-intentioned friend known as AutoCorrect found in Word 2016 for Mac. Watch as they show you AutoCorrect features like automatic formatting of lists, bullets, URLs, borders, ordinals and fractions. They also demonstrate how Word fixes capitalization, common spelling mistakes, and a variety of other items.
episodes.title: Autocorrect Options

episodes.description: In this episode, Zac and Vonne introduce you to the revered options of cut, copy, and paste in Word 2016 for Mac. They will explain the difference between cut and copy, cut/copy from within the same document, copying from websites, and copying from PDFs and other file types. They will also discuss the different paste options for matching source, matching destination, and other options that arise from specific content.
episodes.title: Cut Copy Paste

2016, Essentials for Mac.

Vonne is doing amazing,

episodes.description: In this episode, Zac and Vonne continue with Word 2016 Essentials by exploring the find and replace functionality. They show you how to find desired text, the find dialog-box options, replace found text with desired text, replace formatting, and replacing special/non-printing characters.
episodes.title: Find and Replace
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

[MUSIC]

42

[LAUGH]

00:07:41.460 --> 00:07:42.200

I see, right.

177
00:07:42.200 --> 00:07:42.990
Okay.
>> Right?

00:07:42.990 --> 00:07:44.760
Let's just uncheck, ignore.

179
00:07:44.760 --> 00:07:45.260
>> Interesting.

180
00:07:47.340 --> 00:07:50.675
>> It's the same thing but it's just

00:07:50.675 --> 00:07:52.930
>> [LAUGH]
>> So you can see right here,

00:07:52.930 --> 00:07:54.570
rabbit lower case.

00:07:54.570 --> 00:07:55.070
Right?

184
00:07:56.160 --> 00:07:57.863
It's not highlighted in this one, why?

00:07:57.863 --> 00:07:59.695
Cuz that's not the same, okay.

186
00:07:59.695 --> 00:08:05.960
It needed to ignore the case So

187
00:08:05.960 --> 00:08:09.330

>> It's still backwards to me.

188
00:08:09.330 --> 00:08:12.190

189
00:08:12.190 --> 00:08:12.740

00:08:12.740 --> 00:08:13.540

191
00:08:13.540 --> 00:08:14.740

00:08:14.740 --> 00:08:17.270
Anyways but at least you know

193
00:08:17.270 --> 00:08:20.960
that if you ignore the case,
it's going to match the case.

194
00:08:20.960 --> 00:08:22.142
>> Yes, I got it.

195
00:08:22.142 --> 00:08:23.480
>> That's good.

196

The other one that we're looking at,

00:08:37.022 --> 00:08:38.845

00:08:44.100 --> 00:08:48.223
I want the word at,

203
00:08:48.223 --> 00:08:50.060
If I choose this-

204
00:08:50.060 --> 00:08:51.120

205
00:08:51.120 --> 00:08:53.785
>> Yes I do,
I get the gist of your jib now.

So some of these options that you have

The, oops, no, I do not wanna enable Siri.

The one that's a little

Like if I typed in fear because I was

It sounds like to Word Mac is very and

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explain proof and print functions. They cover topics such as spelling and grammar correction, readability options, thesaurus, and Smart Lookup. They also explain the different options for printing and introduce page setup functionality.
episodes.title: Proof and Print

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore character formatting in Microsoft Word 2016 for Mac. Specific topics covered here include: defining character formatting, fonts, typographical emphasis, change case, superscripts and subscripts, highlighter, font color, letter spacing, and clear formatting.
episodes.title: Character Formatting

And I guess you'd say our digital
paper cuz we're not really

on physical paper right now.

So I have a file called
characterformatting.docx that I've

I do have my show hide character

You have different levels of

Characters as in the text,

Paragraphs meaning, well,

Now, whether that paragraph is,

And up here on our home tab of our ribbon,

It's gonna be your

So we're gonna take these

So let's talk about, first of all,

You cannot change anything

Cuz right now with my cursor right here,

I drop this guy down right here

I choose Apple Chancery,
nothing's gonna happen.

Because nothing is selected.

58
00:03:22.350 --> 00:03:25.400
So do remember the select to effect.

Now, there's all of these buttons

00:03:31.140 --> 00:03:34.810
Let's select the word
Character Formatting.

Also gotta remember, just tell them that

When you have fonts, you have what

Now some programs we'll

72
00:04:07.560 --> 00:04:10.810
So they normally are separate but
just in case they are.

73
00:04:10.810 --> 00:04:13.210
But notice how like Apple Chancery or

74

Chauncery whatever how we're pronouncing

75
00:04:17.690 --> 00:04:22.130
So it doesn't have any like

76
00:04:23.170 --> 00:04:24.041
So just gonna,

77
00:04:24.041 --> 00:04:28.710
that's why you have these little triangles
off the side of some of your fonts.

78
00:04:28.710 --> 00:04:31.450
They have certain families
that you can use.

79
00:04:32.650 --> 00:04:36.346
Now, somebody will always ask me, well,
we have Arial of those Arial Bold and

80
00:04:36.346 --> 00:04:37.790
then there is Arial Italic.

81
00:04:37.790 --> 00:04:41.260
But wait a second you've got
these buttons right here.

82
00:04:41.260 --> 00:04:43.699
The Bold and the Italic and Underline.

83
00:04:44.770 --> 00:04:52.160
These are technically known as typographal

84
00:04:52.160 --> 00:04:55.870
If I was gonna get super technical on you,
all right, which I'm not, and

85
00:04:55.870 --> 00:04:57.020
it's gonna be okay.

86
00:04:57.020 --> 00:05:02.470
But if I chose Apple Chancery and

87
00:05:02.470 --> 00:05:05.650
And it's not actually really
italic cuz it's already italic.

88
00:05:05.650 --> 00:05:12.400
That doesn't really exist
in the real world of fonts.

89
00:05:12.400 --> 00:05:17.720
It's a, what's known as a local override,
and it's more of a visual

90
00:05:17.720 --> 00:05:23.110
rendering of making a font bold
when it's not really bold.

91
00:05:24.180 --> 00:05:27.580
If you feel like I'm talking in circles
right now, just nod your head and say,

92
00:05:27.580 --> 00:05:32.390
okay, [LAUGH] because that's
just the way Word does it, okay?

93
00:05:32.390 --> 00:05:37.000
It will kind of break some of
the rules of typography and fonts and

94
00:05:37.000 --> 00:05:40.610
font families,
just because that's what it does, okay?

95
00:05:40.610 --> 00:05:42.950
So I don't want you to
worry too much about it,

96
00:05:42.950 --> 00:05:45.231
like I can't make Apple Chancery bold.

97
00:05:45.231 --> 00:05:47.370
You can,
there's nothing wrong with that, okay?

98
00:05:47.370 --> 00:05:50.940
I'm just saying if you're
talking to a typesetter,

99
00:05:50.940 --> 00:05:54.590
a graphic designer, somebody that
works in other products like InDesign.

100
00:05:54.590 --> 00:05:58.540
InDesign would bark at me if this
document came in to InDesign, like nope,

101
00:05:58.540 --> 00:06:01.318
this font doesn't exist,
cuz it really doesn't.

102
00:06:01.318 --> 00:06:04.870
All right, I'll stop right there, because
I'm digressing a little bit too much.

103
00:06:04.870 --> 00:06:06.335
>> I'm glad you gave me
the permission to just go,

104
00:06:06.335 --> 00:06:09.210
cuz that's what I was
doing the whole time.

105
00:06:09.210 --> 00:06:13.020
The interesting thing is to,
not being a typesetter or

106
00:06:13.020 --> 00:06:14.540

107
00:06:14.540 --> 00:06:18.680
A lot of times I use those overrides
to provide either some kind of semantic

108
00:06:18.680 --> 00:06:22.005

the document that I'm writing.

109
00:06:22.005 --> 00:06:26.195
With total disregard to some of

111

>> And I want you all to do that.

112
00:06:31.343 --> 00:06:36.793
Don't go too far down the rabbit
hole with me but this is what I do.

113
00:06:36.793 --> 00:06:39.475
This is kinda my life in a sense so
