episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne explore paragraph formatting in Microsoft Word 2016. Specific topics covered here include: paragraph alignment/justification, line and paragraph spacing, normal paragraph style, indents, borders and shading, drop caps, and hyphenation.
episodes.title: Paragraph Formatting
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.562 --> 00:00:15.532
Greetings everyone and welcome to
another exciting episode of OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:15.532 --> 00:00:17.743
I'm your host, Justin Dennison, and

4
00:00:17.743 --> 00:00:22.236
we are continuing on in our Microsoft Word
2016 Essential for Mac series and

5
00:00:22.236 --> 00:00:26.410
in this episode we're gonna be
talking about paragraph formatting.

6
00:00:26.410 --> 00:00:31.042
And luckily, we have a paragraph phenom
in the studio today, Miss Vonne Smith,

7
00:00:31.042 --> 00:00:32.735
how you doing today Vonne?

8
00:00:32.735 --> 00:00:36.220
I like how you did that, paragraph
phenom even though its a P but as an F.

9
00:00:36.220 --> 00:00:38.096
Yeah, yeah.

10
00:00:38.096 --> 00:00:39.944
It's false alliteration, I guess.

11
00:00:39.944 --> 00:00:41.876
[LAUGH] I like that.

12
00:00:41.876 --> 00:00:44.010
[LAUGH] I think that's fantastic.

13
00:00:44.010 --> 00:00:46.630
So yes,
we are continuing on with formatting.

14
00:00:46.630 --> 00:00:49.125
We did a bunch of stuff with
character formatting, and

15
00:00:49.125 --> 00:00:51.458
we touched upon how character formatting,
well,

16
00:00:51.458 --> 00:00:54.130
we actually did a lot of stuff
with character formatting.

17
00:00:54.130 --> 00:00:56.480
But we touched upon paragraph formatting,

18
00:00:56.480 --> 00:01:01.430
different levels of where the formatting
is going to be applied to

19
00:01:01.430 --> 00:01:06.230
character formatting, to the characters,
paragraph formatting, to the paragraphs.

20
00:01:06.230 --> 00:01:07.336
And now we're done with the episode.

21
00:01:07.336 --> 00:01:14.105
[LAUGH] It's more than just that, but when
I say it out loud, it sounds so simple.

22
00:01:14.105 --> 00:01:18.773
But I'm going to show you all the nuances
of your paragraph formatting options

23
00:01:18.773 --> 00:01:19.360
in Word.

24
00:01:19.360 --> 00:01:21.043
So why don't we go ahead and get started.

25
00:01:21.043 --> 00:01:25.094
I have a file called
ParagraphFormatting.docx I have it opened

26
00:01:25.094 --> 00:01:29.148
already, did a little character
formatting on this first one.

27
00:01:29.148 --> 00:01:32.810
So now we're gonna concentrate
over on these buttons.

28
00:01:32.810 --> 00:01:35.975
We have our bullets and numbering.

29
00:01:35.975 --> 00:01:39.850
I'm just gonna tell you right now,
I saved that out for a different episode.

30
00:01:39.850 --> 00:01:43.320
So there's a whole episode on
just bullets and numberings, but

31
00:01:43.320 --> 00:01:45.900
it is a paragraph level formatting.

32
00:01:45.900 --> 00:01:49.780
So it's not that I'm skipping them,
I'm just separating it out.

33
00:01:49.780 --> 00:01:51.740
I'm compartmentalizing for you all.

34
00:01:51.740 --> 00:01:54.008
All right,
then we have the buttons at the bottom.

35
00:01:54.008 --> 00:01:58.450
These are the ones that most people,
I would say, are somewhat familiar with.

36
00:01:59.590 --> 00:02:01.550
These are your paragraph alignment.

37
00:02:01.550 --> 00:02:07.300
Align center, align right,
or justify your text.

38
00:02:07.300 --> 00:02:08.690
So, this is called alignment.

39
00:02:08.690 --> 00:02:11.840
This is also called justification
in some other products or

40
00:02:11.840 --> 00:02:17.070
maybe in some other spaces, if you wanna
say, that people will refer to as less,

41
00:02:17.070 --> 00:02:23.420
left justified, right justified,
center justified or fully justified text.

42
00:02:23.420 --> 00:02:26.282
So just throwing out
that terminology there.

43
00:02:26.282 --> 00:02:32.282
Well with paragraph level formatting,
as opposed to character level formatting,

44
00:02:32.282 --> 00:02:36.928
the thing is you just have to be
with your cursor in the paragraph,

45
00:02:36.928 --> 00:02:41.170
you do not have to select the whole
paragraph or words in it.

46
00:02:42.410 --> 00:02:46.711
Cursor in is all you need cuz
if I click on this button,

47
00:02:46.711 --> 00:02:51.299
the only thing this button is
gonna do is apply to the whole

48
00:02:51.299 --> 00:02:55.335
paragraph not one word
separately then another.

49
00:02:55.335 --> 00:02:58.460
There's actually a little trick
with formatting paragraphs.

50
00:02:58.460 --> 00:03:02.200
If I put this over to the right, then
it's gonna go to the right of the margin.

51
00:03:02.200 --> 00:03:05.230
This button is not gonna make any
difference right now because it's a single

52
00:03:05.230 --> 00:03:07.720
line of text within this paragraph.

53
00:03:07.720 --> 00:03:09.650
But centering, centering is good.

54
00:03:09.650 --> 00:03:15.126
I like a nice center for my title,
so we'll go ahead and use that.

55
00:03:15.126 --> 00:03:20.583
Now I want to point out the next
thing about line breaks versus

56
00:03:20.583 --> 00:03:25.516
hard breaks, or
character turns versus line breaks.

57
00:03:25.516 --> 00:03:27.510
We talked a little bit about
this in the input text.

58
00:03:27.510 --> 00:03:30.870
I'm gonna turn on that show
hide character button.

59
00:03:32.352 --> 00:03:35.880
Because if I didn't have this on,

60
00:03:35.880 --> 00:03:40.810
I wouldn't know that that
is not a hard return.

61
00:03:40.810 --> 00:03:42.820
It's not an Enter.

62
00:03:42.820 --> 00:03:47.590
All of these lines
are within one paragraph.

63
00:03:47.590 --> 00:03:52.327
So I cannot center one
separate than the other.

64
00:03:52.327 --> 00:03:55.814
If I click here and
select this one paragraph, or

65
00:03:55.814 --> 00:04:00.200
what I think is one paragraph,
it's actually doing both.

66
00:04:00.200 --> 00:04:02.750
And that's something that I
think can throw people off and

67
00:04:02.750 --> 00:04:06.000
like, I cannot get this
to center differently.

68
00:04:06.000 --> 00:04:08.420
I'm like well, that's because
it's not the same paragraphs.

69
00:04:08.420 --> 00:04:10.310
If this needs to be different than this,

70
00:04:10.310 --> 00:04:15.240
you have to turn this little guy
from a line break to a full enter.

71
00:04:15.240 --> 00:04:19.400
Because then,
you could left align this block,

72
00:04:19.400 --> 00:04:22.450
if you wanna say, and
this block, separately.

73
00:04:23.640 --> 00:04:27.910
That's the whole idea, paragraph,
formatting, bold paragraphs.

74
00:04:27.910 --> 00:04:31.400
Line breaks are not a paragraph.

75
00:04:31.400 --> 00:04:34.560
It's just a break in
a line within a paragraph.

76
00:04:34.560 --> 00:04:35.660
So keep that in mind and

77
00:04:35.660 --> 00:04:40.630
know why you wanna keep that show
hide button on at all times.

78
00:04:40.630 --> 00:04:43.990
Some other things that we're going to talk
about with paragraph level formatting

79
00:04:43.990 --> 00:04:45.430
would be this next button.

80
00:04:45.430 --> 00:04:49.432
Now this next button,
I love talking about.

81
00:04:49.432 --> 00:04:55.148
Need some line spacing and some
paragraph spacing because it's something

82
00:04:55.148 --> 00:05:01.420
that I think is a decently simple concept,
but it drives people crazy.

83
00:05:01.420 --> 00:05:04.150
Like me, right over here,
it drives me crazy and

84
00:05:04.150 --> 00:05:06.520
I'm sure it's probably
gonna drive you crazy.

85
00:05:06.520 --> 00:05:09.730
Look at these paragraphs, I'm gonna scroll
out a little bit more so you can see.

86
00:05:09.730 --> 00:05:15.890
These paragraphs versus these paragraphs,
right?

87
00:05:15.890 --> 00:05:20.810
This is a different in line spacing,
which is also referred to as letting.

88
00:05:20.810 --> 00:05:23.610
Letting is the space
between the base lines.

89
00:05:23.610 --> 00:05:26.970
It's line spacing, okay, but
the technical term is letting.

90
00:05:28.120 --> 00:05:31.460
And then the space after paragraph,
see right here,

91
00:05:31.460 --> 00:05:35.770
this guy after conversation,
that's the end of a paragraph right there,

92
00:05:35.770 --> 00:05:39.380
at the end of deep well that's
the end of a paragraph.

93
00:05:39.380 --> 00:05:44.668
Up on here same thing but look at how
much space is between the paragraphs,

94
00:05:44.668 --> 00:05:47.411
there are not double enters in there.

95
00:05:47.411 --> 00:05:54.186
The space that it's making is a paragraph
level formatting of saying space

96
00:05:54.186 --> 00:05:59.576
after paragraph is this amount
of measurement, perfect.

97
00:05:59.576 --> 00:06:02.110
That's how you should
space your paragraphs.

98
00:06:02.110 --> 00:06:04.656
Double enters no, don't do that.

99
00:06:04.656 --> 00:06:11.130
I am suggesting to you strongly that
you do not do double enters okay?

100
00:06:11.130 --> 00:06:13.340
You should format the spaces
of your paragraph.

101
00:06:14.630 --> 00:06:17.230
So those are the different
things that you can do here.

102
00:06:17.230 --> 00:06:21.710
But to remember, line spacing and
paragraph spacing are separate.

103
00:06:21.710 --> 00:06:26.130
When you start getting into
single lined paragraphs,

104
00:06:26.130 --> 00:06:30.910
like they don't span across more than one
line, sometimes it might look the same.

105
00:06:32.120 --> 00:06:34.050
But just know they're a little different.

106
00:06:34.050 --> 00:06:40.539
All right, how do I get these paragraphs
to look more like these paragraphs?

107
00:06:40.539 --> 00:06:43.540
I'm gonna select these paragraphs first.

108
00:06:43.540 --> 00:06:44.970
And you say but you don't have to select.

109
00:06:44.970 --> 00:06:49.306
When I'm doing multiple paragraph
formatting, yes, you do need to select all

110
00:06:49.306 --> 00:06:52.929
the text to say I want all three of
these paragraphs to be effected,

111
00:06:52.929 --> 00:06:54.109
not just one of them.

112
00:06:54.109 --> 00:06:59.521
And if I go into this button right here,
I could go ahead and choose the 1.5 or

113
00:06:59.521 --> 00:07:05.521
the 1.15 or 1.5 and do that, and that
would change the space between the lines.

114
00:07:05.521 --> 00:07:06.283
But look,

115
00:07:06.283 --> 00:07:11.204
the space between those paragraphs
are not the same are they, okay?

116
00:07:11.204 --> 00:07:12.325
One other side note,

117
00:07:12.325 --> 00:07:16.080
I actually didn't mention this in
the character formatting episode.

118
00:07:16.080 --> 00:07:20.690
If you are used to PC or
you have used word for

119
00:07:20.690 --> 00:07:26.150
PC in somewhere else,
you will get the live previewing,

120
00:07:26.150 --> 00:07:30.600
like if I'm hovering over this font,
it would normally show you

121
00:07:30.600 --> 00:07:34.810
on the screen like what it's doing as it's
changing, Apple doesn't have that, okay?

122
00:07:36.410 --> 00:07:40.791
Office for Mac products,
they don't have it.

123
00:07:40.791 --> 00:07:43.468
Well, we can live without it.

124
00:07:43.468 --> 00:07:45.010
I do like it though, so

125
00:07:45.010 --> 00:07:50.062
I do tend it to miss it from time to time
when I switch over to Office for Mac.

126
00:07:50.062 --> 00:07:54.809
So line spacing or
going into the line spacing options,

127
00:07:54.809 --> 00:07:59.254
that brings you into
the dialogue box of right here.

128
00:07:59.254 --> 00:08:01.333
The space after.

129
00:08:01.333 --> 00:08:06.600
Now you can have space before,
nothing wrong with it.

130
00:08:06.600 --> 00:08:10.400
Me, personally,
I like to have a space after.

131
00:08:10.400 --> 00:08:14.227
I try at all costs to not
have anything before,

132
00:08:14.227 --> 00:08:17.578
cuz I'm thinking it's just we go down.

133
00:08:17.578 --> 00:08:20.771
We progress down the page so
I don't like to think of

134
00:08:20.771 --> 00:08:25.940
having to think about space above it,
I always wanna think after it.

135
00:08:25.940 --> 00:08:30.720
Personal preference, but you can have
some of both or one or the other.

136
00:08:30.720 --> 00:08:34.590
So I'm gonna bump this space after
to 18 to really emphasize this.

137
00:08:34.590 --> 00:08:37.980
Notice you can change your line
spacing right here if you wanted to.

138
00:08:37.980 --> 00:08:42.418
And then you could also do like
individual measurements of like

139
00:08:42.418 --> 00:08:44.351
1.65 if you wanted to.

140
00:08:44.351 --> 00:08:47.580
We'll just keep it at 1.5 right now,
we'll click OK.

141
00:08:47.580 --> 00:08:53.970
And notice right there,
that's a big space after the paragraph.

142
00:08:53.970 --> 00:08:58.645
So that's really important to
understand those two key concepts

143
00:08:58.645 --> 00:09:01.875
of how your line and
paragraph spacing work.

144
00:09:01.875 --> 00:09:03.950
And as you can see, pretty simple, right?

145
00:09:05.160 --> 00:09:09.820
Along the same lines, if I started
a File > New and I decided control,

146
00:09:09.820 --> 00:09:14.232
sorry, command, I'm really on those
Windows shortcuts today, aren't I?

147
00:09:14.232 --> 00:09:17.620
[LAUGH] Cmd+N, that's for new.

148
00:09:17.620 --> 00:09:20.014
When you start a brand new file in Word,

149
00:09:20.014 --> 00:09:24.980
you're actually making a new file off
of what's known as the global template.

150
00:09:24.980 --> 00:09:29.680
The global template is something that
just says, here's my new blank document.

151
00:09:29.680 --> 00:09:35.510
In the normal template, you have something
known as the normal style, right here.

152
00:09:35.510 --> 00:09:38.605
We'll talk a lot about
styles a little bit later.

153
00:09:38.605 --> 00:09:40.740
But notice that that is on by default.

154
00:09:40.740 --> 00:09:45.470
This is the same for all Word programs,
it doesn't matter what platform.

155
00:09:45.470 --> 00:09:50.410
And that normal paragraph
style has certain paragraph

156
00:09:50.410 --> 00:09:54.929
level formattings which
includes line spacing.

157
00:09:54.929 --> 00:10:00.840
In PC world, if you start typing,
yeah, those make words, right?

158
00:10:00.840 --> 00:10:05.540
And you hit Enter, you would normally
get a little bit of space once

159
00:10:05.540 --> 00:10:07.550
you hit the enter, to your next paragraph.

160
00:10:07.550 --> 00:10:12.890
Because the normal style is set to have,
I think it's

161
00:10:12.890 --> 00:10:16.450
eight points after paragraph, it might
be a little more than that, maybe nine.

162
00:10:17.740 --> 00:10:19.470
For Mac, it doesn't do that.

163
00:10:19.470 --> 00:10:24.430
So see, when I type, type, type, type,
type, hit Enter, no space is happening.

164
00:10:24.430 --> 00:10:26.560
That's just the way it works.

165
00:10:26.560 --> 00:10:29.200
I just keep on, keep on,
keeping on, right.

166
00:10:29.200 --> 00:10:34.072
That's why I think people
are inclined to do Enter,

167
00:10:34.072 --> 00:10:37.050
Enter, right, cuz you need that space,
Enter, Enter.

168
00:10:37.050 --> 00:10:39.660
I need space between my paragraph.

169
00:10:39.660 --> 00:10:41.954
No, just don't do that.

170
00:10:41.954 --> 00:10:44.450
Go ahead and
change your paragraph spacing, okay.

171
00:10:44.450 --> 00:10:48.810
Know that you could type this all in and
format it afterwards, or

172
00:10:48.810 --> 00:10:53.750
when you first start, go ahead and,
you could even set it right before.

173
00:10:53.750 --> 00:10:55.770
You could go with a line spacing.

174
00:10:55.770 --> 00:11:01.770
Bump the space up to well, I've say 12
points and then type, type, type, Enter.

175
00:11:01.770 --> 00:11:04.420
Because every formatting that you do,

176
00:11:04.420 --> 00:11:09.560
it's gonna remember the next time
that you make a new paragraph.

177
00:11:09.560 --> 00:11:13.730
So that's what I will suggest you and
instead of a double enters.

178
00:11:13.730 --> 00:11:16.483
Even more so,
I would change the normal font style, and

179
00:11:16.483 --> 00:11:18.710
then I'll actually update on the template,

180
00:11:18.710 --> 00:11:22.301
that's going a little bit further
outside of this particular episode.

181
00:11:22.301 --> 00:11:25.716
But we will get into styles so
you'll know what I'm talking about there.

182
00:11:25.716 --> 00:11:28.725
I think templates,
I think that's in my advance series so,

183
00:11:28.725 --> 00:11:32.450
just finding your own template of finding
how you want your text be format.

184
00:11:32.450 --> 00:11:35.320
You can make your own, I think I would
actually go with that rather than

185
00:11:35.320 --> 00:11:37.880
modify the global, I would make my own.

186
00:11:37.880 --> 00:11:39.460
Again, I digress slightly,

187
00:11:39.460 --> 00:11:43.070
but giving you some foreshadowing
into other places you can go.

188
00:11:43.070 --> 00:11:46.240
>> So, Vonne, I just have to ask,
mainly because some

189
00:11:46.240 --> 00:11:51.880
individuals may be asking this, you seem
really been against the double enters.

190
00:11:51.880 --> 00:11:53.730
What's the impetus for that?

191
00:11:53.730 --> 00:11:58.750
For me, I'm just like, well, it achieves
the desired look, why does it matter?

192
00:11:58.750 --> 00:12:00.880
>> Wow, that's a really good question.

193
00:12:00.880 --> 00:12:03.430
I'm actually glad you asked that.

194
00:12:03.430 --> 00:12:10.435
Told you I'm a little bit of a font geek,
and I do a lot of work outside of Word and

195
00:12:10.435 --> 00:12:14.804
other products such InDesign and
Illustrator.

196
00:12:14.804 --> 00:12:18.660
And I do a lot of work for clients
freelancing and everything like that.

197
00:12:18.660 --> 00:12:21.938
So they'll send me a lot
of text in a Word document,

198
00:12:21.938 --> 00:12:25.084
here's all the text is
gonna go on our textbook.

199
00:12:25.084 --> 00:12:28.313
If I have a 195 pages of double enters,
the thing is,

200
00:12:28.313 --> 00:12:31.751
I'm gonna format cuz I'm gonna
stylized all your texts and

201
00:12:31.751 --> 00:12:35.570
gonna make it look good and
readable in a printed format.

202
00:12:35.570 --> 00:12:40.760
Well, I need to format
the paragraph with styles that say,

203
00:12:40.760 --> 00:12:44.310
I need this amount of space after
paragraphs cuz I can control that.

204
00:12:44.310 --> 00:12:46.578
But double enters, I can't control that.

205
00:12:46.578 --> 00:12:50.310
Because that's like a fixed space so
it starts to, if I change all paragraphs,

206
00:12:50.310 --> 00:12:52.162
it's gonna change the one in between.

207
00:12:52.162 --> 00:12:57.252
It's gonna make this all this other stuff,
so I want it to be a paragraph, paragraph,

208
00:12:57.252 --> 00:13:02.460
paragraph, nothing in between, that's
how it should be and that's what I want.

209
00:13:02.460 --> 00:13:04.390
>> Okay,
I can actually see the purpose here.

210
00:13:04.390 --> 00:13:07.480
It's kind of like, if you're in school and

211
00:13:07.480 --> 00:13:10.310
you have a particular project or maybe
you're submitting a proposal or something,

212
00:13:10.310 --> 00:13:13.720
a lot of times they have
formatting requirements.

213
00:13:13.720 --> 00:13:16.180
And let's say you submit it and
it get set back to you and

214
00:13:16.180 --> 00:13:20.730
one of those requirements is you
need 15 points after each paragraph.

215
00:13:20.730 --> 00:13:23.822
Readability, it needs to be one and
a half line spacing.

216
00:13:23.822 --> 00:13:26.881
If you have double enters,
you now gonna go fix all of those

217
00:13:26.881 --> 00:13:30.005
manually instead of just
selecting the entire document and

218
00:13:30.005 --> 00:13:34.396
saying, hey, I wanna change this space
after paragraph to blah, blah, blah so.

219
00:13:34.396 --> 00:13:36.016
>> Yes.
>> I can see it like,

220
00:13:36.016 --> 00:13:37.950
I don't do print layout.

221
00:13:37.950 --> 00:13:41.950
Well, you may have particular
things in what you do.

222
00:13:41.950 --> 00:13:46.020
They require you to just take it easy
on yourself, don't get crazy, right?

223
00:13:46.020 --> 00:13:49.985
>> Yeah, and I like where you're going
this because I'm definitely drown that

224
00:13:49.985 --> 00:13:51.710

00:25:39.980 --> 00:25:41.678
Little things, but again,

452
00:25:41.678 --> 00:25:45.440
little things can be really big
when you're somebody like me.

453
00:25:45.440 --> 00:25:49.746
[LAUGH] So your hypehnations, then the
last one that I'd like to cover in this

454
00:25:49.746 --> 00:25:54.850
particular episode is just gonna be a
little bit of stylistic stuff, drop caps.

455
00:25:54.850 --> 00:25:56.310
Drop caps, you're like what is that.

456
00:25:56.310 --> 00:25:58.862
You've seen this before,
you've seen it in a book.

457
00:25:58.862 --> 00:26:04.843
Maybe like a children's book or a fancy
book, the first letter of a line is,

458
00:26:04.843 --> 00:26:09.156
Justin went like this,
yeah, it's bigger, right?

459
00:26:09.156 --> 00:26:14.100
So you have a really big T for the word
the The, that's what a drop cap is.

460
00:26:14.100 --> 00:26:17.300
It's capitalizing and
dropping it down within the paragraph.

461
00:26:18.750 --> 00:26:24.150
It's in a space, it's a little funny,
so you have to know where to find it.

462
00:26:24.150 --> 00:26:28.019
If I'm selecting on the paragraph,
so I'm gonna just.

463
00:26:28.019 --> 00:26:29.110
Whoa sorry, what am I doing?

464
00:26:29.110 --> 00:26:30.130
Zooming, okay.

465
00:26:30.130 --> 00:26:33.667
I'm zooming in on here,
I've put my cursor in the paragraph,

466
00:26:33.667 --> 00:26:35.735
you go to the insert tab.

467
00:26:35.735 --> 00:26:39.420
Little strange, but insert drop cap and

468
00:26:39.420 --> 00:26:43.880
from drop cap you can go to drop and
it made up.

469
00:26:43.880 --> 00:26:50.370
It drop made it a big E, and how many
lines did that drop, this one did three.

470
00:26:50.370 --> 00:26:52.440
But maybe three,
in this one might be little too much.

471
00:26:52.440 --> 00:26:54.430
So, I don't only wanna be two.

472
00:26:54.430 --> 00:27:00.200
So if you go into your drop cap options,
notice if I click on dropped,

473
00:27:00.200 --> 00:27:03.180
I have an option of how many
lines I want it to drop down.

474
00:27:03.180 --> 00:27:07.540
So if I only chose two,
you could also say like,

475
00:27:07.540 --> 00:27:09.950
how much distance you want from your text.

476
00:27:09.950 --> 00:27:13.270
If you want it to have a little bit more,
and so on and so forth.

477
00:27:13.270 --> 00:27:18.150
In the margin, that would be like, well,
in the margin space and not in this area,

478
00:27:18.150 --> 00:27:21.220
I'd probably, I personally would
avoid that, because I would not want

479
00:27:21.220 --> 00:27:24.550
anything outside my margins, because
that's kind of why I have a margins.

480
00:27:24.550 --> 00:27:28.260
So I click okay, and notice that I
have a little bit more space and

481
00:27:28.260 --> 00:27:32.760
it dropped only two lines instead of
three, it has to be more than two.

482
00:27:32.760 --> 00:27:36.140
If you put one, it's not gonna happen,
because It's the same line.

483
00:27:36.140 --> 00:27:38.380
So you have to have two or more.

484
00:27:38.380 --> 00:27:41.860
So that's just a little fun thing that you
can do with paragraph level formatting.

485
00:27:41.860 --> 00:27:45.150
Like I said,
these are paragraph level formatting but

486
00:27:45.150 --> 00:27:46.210
we'll do it in another episode.

487
00:27:46.210 --> 00:27:50.340
So I think that covers just about
everything that I want to do in all

488
00:27:50.340 --> 00:27:51.370
those buttons.

489
00:27:51.370 --> 00:27:53.330
And yeah, there you go.

490
00:27:53.330 --> 00:27:56.860
>> Well, Vonne I will tell you,
you have made my day.

491
00:27:56.860 --> 00:28:00.770
I will no longer struggle with
those horrible indentation options,

492
00:28:00.770 --> 00:28:02.025
that I've become frustrated.

493
00:28:02.025 --> 00:28:06.110
The storm from my computer,
only to come back to get frustrated again.

494
00:28:06.110 --> 00:28:09.830
So thank you, and all of those of you out
there, you should definitely take heed

495
00:28:09.830 --> 00:28:13.750
of all this wonderful information
that Vonne has given us.

496
00:28:13.750 --> 00:28:16.270
As her title of paragraph phenom.

497
00:28:16.270 --> 00:28:18.570
And well, we are running out of time for
this episode.

498
00:28:18.570 --> 00:28:22.570
But definitely stay tuned for more
Microsoft Word 2016 Essentials for Mac.

499
00:28:22.570 --> 00:28:25.130
But for now, we're gonna go ahead and
sign off for Office Pro Tv.

500
00:28:25.130 --> 00:28:28.208
I've been your host Justin Dennison and
I'm Vaughn Smith, and

501
00:28:28.208 --> 00:28:29.467
we'll see you next time.

502
00:28:29.467 --> 00:28:34.249
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne demonstrate the format painter that copies formatting from one selection to another.
episodes.title: Format Painter
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.143 --> 00:00:15.309
Greetings, everyone, and welcome back to
another exciting episode of OfficePro.TV.

3
00:00:15.309 --> 00:00:20.171
I'm your host, Justin Dennison, and we're
coming back with, well, something that

4
00:00:20.171 --> 00:00:24.378
I'm not quite sure is going on in our
Microsoft Word 2016 Essentials for

5
00:00:24.378 --> 00:00:25.116
Mac series.

6
00:00:25.116 --> 00:00:27.930
We're gonna be talking
about the format painter.

7
00:00:27.930 --> 00:00:31.522
Luckily we have someone very special
in the studio to, well, reveal,

8
00:00:31.522 --> 00:00:33.635
to pull back the curtain, if you will.

9
00:00:33.635 --> 00:00:35.272
Ms Vonne Smith,
how you doing today, Vonne?

10
00:00:35.272 --> 00:00:38.007
>> I'm doing great, when you were
introducing, I was like, what?

11
00:00:38.007 --> 00:00:38.751
What's going on?

12
00:00:38.751 --> 00:00:40.809
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] You got me a little

13
00:00:40.809 --> 00:00:41.704
scared there.

14
00:00:41.704 --> 00:00:43.880
>> I know the title of the episode.

15
00:00:43.880 --> 00:00:46.680
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's the extent that I know.

16
00:00:46.680 --> 00:00:50.506
>> All right, well, luckily I'm here to
show you the way, just like you said.

17
00:00:50.506 --> 00:00:53.800
I'm gonna pull back that curtain and
tell you all about the format painter.

18
00:00:53.800 --> 00:00:56.300
I do love a format painter.

19
00:00:56.300 --> 00:00:59.177
It can be really handy, and a lot of times
when I first teached this to people,

20
00:00:59.177 --> 00:01:01.807
they were like, this is amazing,
I'm gonna use it all the time.

21
00:01:01.807 --> 00:01:04.162
And then I'm like, yeah, but
you really should use styles.

22
00:01:04.162 --> 00:01:07.293
And they're like, no, I don't wanna use
that, I wanna use the format painter.

23
00:01:07.293 --> 00:01:10.055
It's fun, and I'm like totally fine, so

24
00:01:10.055 --> 00:01:14.504
that's why I wanted to give it its own
episode to give it a little bit of

25
00:01:14.504 --> 00:01:18.820
a shout out there to see how
it could be pretty cool.

26
00:01:18.820 --> 00:01:21.070
So what is the format painter?

27
00:01:21.070 --> 00:01:24.890
It's the little paintbrush that's on your
ribbon that we'll look at in a second.

28
00:01:24.890 --> 00:01:31.300
But what it does is it will copy formats
to other location within your document.

29
00:01:32.790 --> 00:01:36.861
And this is how I, Justin's over there
going, hm, what are you talking about?

30
00:01:36.861 --> 00:01:41.198
It's probably easiest to demonstrate it,
so why don't we jump down in here,

31
00:01:41.198 --> 00:01:45.420
and I'll start talking about my analogy
that I have for the format painter?

32
00:01:46.420 --> 00:01:49.950
Now, this particular paragraph right here,
you could see that we have some

33
00:01:49.950 --> 00:01:52.520
character level formatting and
some paragraph level formatting.

34
00:01:52.520 --> 00:01:57.394
We have purple font that is 18 Calibri and
it's bold.

35
00:01:57.394 --> 00:02:02.150
We have it centered as a paragraph,
we also have some shading,

36
00:02:02.150 --> 00:02:04.951
and we also have some border on this.

37
00:02:04.951 --> 00:02:06.475
And so we've got all of that going on.

38
00:02:06.475 --> 00:02:11.795
Well, down here where it says,
well, I like purple, and me too,

39
00:02:11.795 --> 00:02:18.670
I wanna have both of these paragraphs
formatted the same way as this paragraph.

40
00:02:18.670 --> 00:02:22.281
Now I could go ahead and
do the long selection.

41
00:02:22.281 --> 00:02:25.571
Well, I could select both of those
with my command and then come up and

42
00:02:25.571 --> 00:02:27.232
do all the formats that I just did.

43
00:02:27.232 --> 00:02:31.860
But wouldn't it be nice to just copy
the formatting from here down to there?

44
00:02:31.860 --> 00:02:33.471
Well, that's what it does, okay?

45
00:02:33.471 --> 00:02:35.700
It's like painting a house, okay?

46
00:02:35.700 --> 00:02:39.428
And I also tell people about this
procedure to think about, well,

47
00:02:39.428 --> 00:02:43.223
your procedure of what you need to
do when you need to make the painter

48
00:02:43.223 --> 00:02:46.645
work because that's the biggest
problem that people have.

49
00:02:46.645 --> 00:02:50.195
It's like painting a house,
right, or painting the wall.

50
00:02:50.195 --> 00:02:52.314
You wanna put the wall,
you wanna put the wall on the paint.

51
00:02:52.314 --> 00:02:54.875
[LAUGH] You wanna put the paint-
>> [LAUGH] I will tell you, Vonne,

52
00:02:54.875 --> 00:02:56.181
that may be a difficult task.

53
00:02:56.181 --> 00:02:59.820
Look, I gotta cut this wall down and
stick it in this gallon of paint.

54
00:02:59.820 --> 00:03:00.370
Why?

55
00:03:00.370 --> 00:03:01.100
That's what I do.

56
00:03:01.100 --> 00:03:02.171
That's how I paint walls.

57
00:03:02.171 --> 00:03:04.580
>> [LAUGH] Exactly, yeah,
I got it a little backwards.

58
00:03:04.580 --> 00:03:06.660
And so don't be backwards.

59
00:03:06.660 --> 00:03:08.070
You need to make sure you
did it the right way.

60
00:03:08.070 --> 00:03:11.670
You have a campaign or a roller,
you put the roller in the paint, right?

61
00:03:11.670 --> 00:03:15.380
So that the paint gets on the roller,
and then you put it on the wall, right?

62
00:03:15.380 --> 00:03:18.560
So this is the paint that
needs to go over here, so

63
00:03:18.560 --> 00:03:22.750
you have to select the paint in
the bucket to put on the wall.

64
00:03:22.750 --> 00:03:28.032
Same idea if this is the paint
that I want to paint

65
00:03:28.032 --> 00:03:33.195
down here,
your cursor has to be in this area.

66
00:03:33.195 --> 00:03:35.315
Now whether you select the text, or

67
00:03:35.315 --> 00:03:39.484
you click once in the paragraph to
just get the paragraph formatting,

68
00:03:39.484 --> 00:03:43.174
that can get a little tricky,
I will let you know that, okay?

69
00:03:43.174 --> 00:03:48.169
I'm just gonna select all this text, cuz
I wanna make sure it understands that I

70
00:03:48.169 --> 00:03:53.530
want the character formatting and
the paragraph formatting all to be copied.

71
00:03:53.530 --> 00:03:58.330
So select it, you have a single use
paintbrush, if you wanna say, and

72
00:03:58.330 --> 00:04:01.250
you also could,
what I call turn on the gun.

73
00:04:01.250 --> 00:04:04.860
You know those paint guns that
you can spray everywhere?

74
00:04:04.860 --> 00:04:08.934
That would be dangerous for me, but
it's just like you turn on the nozzle, and

75
00:04:08.934 --> 00:04:10.640
it just keeps on going.

76
00:04:10.640 --> 00:04:11.950
That's the same concept that I have for

77
00:04:11.950 --> 00:04:17.260
if you wanna continually keep this on,
but single click once.

78
00:04:17.260 --> 00:04:21.650
Notice that my mouse comes down here, and
it looks like an I-beam with a paintbrush.

79
00:04:21.650 --> 00:04:25.637
So this is my can of paint,
click the button, click, hold,

80
00:04:25.637 --> 00:04:27.763
and drag, boop, there you go.

81
00:04:27.763 --> 00:04:28.830
Isn't that nice?

82
00:04:28.830 --> 00:04:31.380
So it just copied the formatting.

83
00:04:31.380 --> 00:04:33.200
Now that was a one time application.

84
00:04:33.200 --> 00:04:36.200
Notice that my I-beam just goes
right back to being an I-beam, so

85
00:04:36.200 --> 00:04:39.990
no more paint on my roller,
if you wanna say.

86
00:04:39.990 --> 00:04:40.870
I'm gonna undo that.

87
00:04:41.930 --> 00:04:44.290
What if I wanted to keep it on?

88
00:04:44.290 --> 00:04:46.860
That's where you still gotta go the same
procedure, you gotta start here.

89
00:04:46.860 --> 00:04:51.936
I'm just gonna single click on this one
and just so I can get everything in there,

90
00:04:51.936 --> 00:04:56.040
I'm going to double click
on the Format Paint tab.

91
00:04:56.040 --> 00:04:58.680
Double click, it's like the gun's on now.

92
00:04:58.680 --> 00:05:02.190
If I click hold and drag, there's that,

93
00:05:02.190 --> 00:05:08.160
my I-beam still looks like the paintbrush,
click, hold, and drag.

94
00:05:08.160 --> 00:05:09.700
But it's still on.

95
00:05:09.700 --> 00:05:12.310
So if you click here, oops, whoa, okay,

96
00:05:12.310 --> 00:05:14.990
and also notice one thing
really quickly there.

97
00:05:14.990 --> 00:05:18.860
Notice I single clicked one
word in that paragraph.

98
00:05:19.890 --> 00:05:24.045
It changed the word very to be bigger and
purple, but look at all the other text.

99
00:05:24.045 --> 00:05:25.270
It's not, is it, okay?

100
00:05:25.270 --> 00:05:28.350
So, single clicking versus
double clicking versus dragging,

101
00:05:28.350 --> 00:05:30.370
it can get a little weird sometimes.

102
00:05:30.370 --> 00:05:34.629
>> So, is this because it's applying the
paragraph level formatting to the entire

103
00:05:34.629 --> 00:05:36.946
paragraph that you've just selected, but

104
00:05:36.946 --> 00:05:40.597
only applying character level
formatting to the single click word?

105
00:05:40.597 --> 00:05:42.285
Do I have that wrong?

106
00:05:42.285 --> 00:05:44.055
>> That was perfect, honestly.

107
00:05:44.055 --> 00:05:45.355
Yeah, you said that perfectly.

108
00:05:45.355 --> 00:05:47.014
Cuz, yeah, cuz it's still on, right?

109
00:05:47.014 --> 00:05:49.955
The format painter's on,
look at my mouse cursor.

110
00:05:49.955 --> 00:05:52.277
If I click and hold and
drag on just those, yes,

111
00:05:52.277 --> 00:05:55.170
now that's an even weirder one, isn't it?

112
00:05:55.170 --> 00:05:58.740
It's like, wait, so
when I dragged across text,

113
00:05:58.740 --> 00:06:01.820
it only applied the character
level formatting, right?

114
00:06:01.820 --> 00:06:06.622
But if I single click,
it applied the paragraph level formatting,

115
00:06:06.622 --> 00:06:11.142
but then only the character level
formatting for that one part.

116
00:06:11.142 --> 00:06:12.360
That's weird.

117
00:06:12.360 --> 00:06:14.630
Let's go back, okay, let's try this again.

118
00:06:14.630 --> 00:06:16.690
I've gotta go back to my format painter.

119
00:06:16.690 --> 00:06:19.640
But if I click, hold, and drag across
everything, it gets the whole thing.

120
00:06:21.060 --> 00:06:23.180
Yeah, that's what will trip you up.

121
00:06:23.180 --> 00:06:27.463
It trips you up so much, and
that's what understanding character and

122
00:06:27.463 --> 00:06:29.357
paragraph level formatting.

123
00:06:29.357 --> 00:06:34.751
And what happens with the format painter
when you single click, click, hold, and

124
00:06:34.751 --> 00:06:40.010
drag over a couple words, or click, hold,
and drag over the entire paragraph.

125
00:06:40.010 --> 00:06:45.850
That's a big deal, it's tiny,
but it will mess you up.

126
00:06:45.850 --> 00:06:50.840
So that's why when I did my first
example of like, look, it worked.

127
00:06:50.840 --> 00:06:52.900
They're small lines, right?

128
00:06:52.900 --> 00:06:58.070
If I had single clicked on,
I like purple, look at even that one.

129
00:06:58.070 --> 00:06:59.470
It didn't even get even a single word.

130
00:06:59.470 --> 00:07:01.480
It just did the paragraph
level formatting.

131
00:07:01.480 --> 00:07:06.840
So single click, single click,
click, hold, drag, get it all, okay?

132
00:07:06.840 --> 00:07:11.518
So just know it's a little strange, but
I'm trying to give you those little

133
00:07:11.518 --> 00:07:15.478
nuances cuz I think that's one
where it will frustrate people.

134
00:07:15.478 --> 00:07:17.920
Cuz it's not giving them what they want.

135
00:07:19.080 --> 00:07:23.007
It's just the nature of the level
of format that you have, so

136
00:07:23.007 --> 00:07:24.402
be careful about it.

137
00:07:24.402 --> 00:07:28.190
And the single click versus double click,
let's go back one more.

138
00:07:29.410 --> 00:07:33.330
Double clicking, it's like you turn
the gun on, you gotta turn it off.

139
00:07:33.330 --> 00:07:38.908
If I start dragging here and then drag
there, and then okay, drag there,

140
00:07:38.908 --> 00:07:44.080
single click there, okay,
I'm just going all over the place, right?

141
00:07:45.150 --> 00:07:47.360
That button is pressed on,
you turn it off.

142
00:07:47.360 --> 00:07:49.053
And now it turns into a regular,

143
00:07:49.053 --> 00:07:52.020
you can always do your undo if
it gets a little too crazy.

144
00:07:53.090 --> 00:07:56.780
So that's why I tend to say,
just do maybe a single application,

145
00:07:56.780 --> 00:07:59.540
unless you know what it does and
you can go ahead and control it.

146
00:07:59.540 --> 00:08:02.350
So, good stuff to know about.

147
00:08:02.350 --> 00:08:07.660
And just one other little thing is that
you can go across multiple documents.

148
00:08:07.660 --> 00:08:12.098
So for example, let's go with,
I'll do the paragraph formatting.

149
00:08:12.098 --> 00:08:18.622
I'm just picking that particular file just
because if I take this file right here,

150
00:08:18.622 --> 00:08:24.129
my Format Painter, click here,
double click on the Format Painter.

151
00:08:24.129 --> 00:08:29.360
I can come over here to this document,
and then I can do the same thing.

152
00:08:29.360 --> 00:08:32.834
If I can click, hold, and drag, I could
go ahead and then single click there.

153
00:08:32.834 --> 00:08:36.840
Now it's back to the same idea,
what's being applied when.

154
00:08:36.840 --> 00:08:40.735
But you can go across multiple
documents if you wanted to.

155
00:08:40.735 --> 00:08:44.810
So it's like, I really like what they're
doing over here in this document.

156
00:08:44.810 --> 00:08:46.220
Just copy the formating.

157
00:08:46.220 --> 00:08:49.860
We're not copying text,
we're just copying the formatting.

158
00:08:49.860 --> 00:08:52.157
So that's why it's pretty handy.

159
00:08:52.157 --> 00:08:54.127
I like it, it can be a little wonky, so

160
00:08:54.127 --> 00:08:57.780
just be careful about all those
different levels that I talked about.

161
00:08:57.780 --> 00:09:04.030
And hopefully, you'll be able to paint
a bunch of purple on your files as well.

162
00:09:04.030 --> 00:09:06.670
>> Well, Vonne, I'm definitely glad
that we covered character level and

163
00:09:06.670 --> 00:09:07.980
paragraph level formatting.

164
00:09:07.980 --> 00:09:09.895
And if you haven't watched those,
definitely go check those out,

165
00:09:09.895 --> 00:09:10.440
rewatch this one.

166
00:09:10.440 --> 00:09:16.030
Because it'll probably make a little more
sense at that time, finding those nuances.

167
00:09:16.030 --> 00:09:18.600
And just like this episode,
a little bit shorter,

168
00:09:18.600 --> 00:09:22.170
I have a feeling we should probably use
the format painter in a very subtle,

169
00:09:22.170 --> 00:09:23.690
just a little sprinkle here and there.

170
00:09:24.948 --> 00:09:27.822
I get you.
I can see how this would be very difficult

171
00:09:27.822 --> 00:09:31.497
to keep replicate cuz you're
always opening a document, and

172
00:09:31.497 --> 00:09:33.910
it's hard to maintain what did I do.

173
00:09:33.910 --> 00:09:36.263
>> Yeah, and
that's where I'm telling you the styles.

174
00:09:36.263 --> 00:09:40.813
Once you get into knowing what a style
does, how to apply it and how they work,

175
00:09:40.813 --> 00:09:45.293
you're gonna be like no, this a way
better way that I can control things in

176
00:09:45.293 --> 00:09:48.032
how I'm formatting my
text if I use my styles.

177
00:09:48.032 --> 00:09:51.170
Because it's all connected
to one central place.

178
00:09:51.170 --> 00:09:53.288
And I can change that,
and it changes everything.

179
00:09:53.288 --> 00:09:57.720
That's even that much cooler, so.

180
00:09:57.720 --> 00:10:01.090
>> Yeah, I tend to like that one, but I
can see the utility of the format painter.

181
00:10:01.090 --> 00:10:05.110
So thank you so much, Vonne, for, well,
highlighting how to use that, but

182
00:10:05.110 --> 00:10:09.300
also describing some of those nuanced
minutia that may trip, well, me and

183
00:10:09.300 --> 00:10:10.500
you and everybody up.

184
00:10:10.500 --> 00:10:13.790
And luckily I know what the episode's
about now, so that's wonderful.

185
00:10:13.790 --> 00:10:15.620
But this episode is one and done.

186
00:10:15.620 --> 00:10:17.400
So we're gonna go ahead and wrap this up.

187
00:10:17.400 --> 00:10:20.450
Signing off for OfficeProTV,
I've been your host, Justin Dennison.

00:10:20.450 --> 00:10:20.991
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

189
00:10:20.991 --> 00:10:22.150
>> And we'll see you next time.

190
00:10:22.150 --> 00:10:24.647

episodes.description: In this episode, Zac and Vonne explore working with lists in Microsoft Word 2016 for Mac. Specific topics covered here include: bulleted lists, format bullet characters, size, color, and spacing, numbered lists, multi-level lists, continue numbering, and remove or stop lists.
episodes.title: Lists

I thought it was gonna be

I did not do a Shift+Tab right there.

It actually cycled me back.

00:08:52.860 --> 00:08:53.730

00:08:53.730 --> 00:08:57.560

you can kind of come in and

176

Cuz I've had people do that as well.

Me too, where I keep on going, I say five.

Okay, we'll go with fife.

And then I'm like okay, I'm done.

So Enter Enter and

183

And then I can keep on typing my regular

184
00:09:17.950 --> 00:09:22.060
So yeah, that double Enter,
doing the Enter twice is the same thing.

185

I tend to just use the Tab and

Shift+Tab cuz I feel like it's

You can always use these buttons
if you want to add your typing.

188
00:09:29.940 --> 00:09:32.610
But I feel like that's
just more jumping around,

189
00:09:32.610 --> 00:09:34.230
so-
>> So nested lists,

190
00:09:34.230 --> 00:09:36.190
that's what we're doing here.

191
00:09:36.190 --> 00:09:39.260
That's how we create this and

And that's important to remember.

193

00:09:45.550 --> 00:09:46.910

00:09:50.242 --> 00:09:50.866

remember that you did that.

437
00:21:35.376 --> 00:21:39.801
Okay, now it doesn't show a tab character,
so I don't want to confuse it with that.

438
00:21:39.801 --> 00:21:43.481
That's why I wanted to turn on this Hide
Characters, it's there is no tab there.

439
00:21:43.481 --> 00:21:45.955
I hit the Tab key, but it didn't do it.

440
00:21:45.955 --> 00:21:51.512
It didn't make a character, but it does
remember the indent levels that it did.

441
00:21:51.512 --> 00:21:55.894
So same thing here, if I took this and
also like well is this a Bulleted,

442
00:21:55.894 --> 00:21:59.445
a Multilevel, just click
whatever button and turn it off.

443
00:21:59.445 --> 00:22:04.068
Notice that it stays in that level,
so if you needed to bring

444
00:22:04.068 --> 00:22:09.540
everything back out to perfectly
flush against your left margin.

445
00:22:09.540 --> 00:22:12.660
You are gonna need to come into here
even though it's kind of ghost and

446
00:22:12.660 --> 00:22:14.640
you're like everything is over there,
but it's not.

447
00:22:14.640 --> 00:22:19.412
Just click this, and you see how as soon
as I click those triangles to line up.

448
00:22:19.412 --> 00:22:24.038
That becomes where all my indent levels
are gonna and everything's back to zero.

449
00:22:24.038 --> 00:22:29.448
So unformatting your Bulleted list
can be a little weird sometimes

450
00:22:29.448 --> 00:22:35.445
of how it uses the different Multilevels,
so just be careful about that.

451
00:22:35.445 --> 00:22:40.981
And then the last thing I'd like to show
is the continuing of your numbering,

452
00:22:40.981 --> 00:22:42.610
that's kind of nice.

453
00:22:42.610 --> 00:22:46.784
Let's select all of this, I'm gonna
delete everything to start from scratch.

454
00:22:46.784 --> 00:22:50.196
Let's go ahead and say Hello, Goodbye.

455
00:22:50.196 --> 00:22:51.331
[LAUGH]

456
00:22:51.331 --> 00:22:52.240
>> [LAUGH]
>> We will-

457
00:22:52.240 --> 00:22:52.952
>> How are you?

458
00:22:52.952 --> 00:22:53.704
>> [LAUGH] Right?

459
00:22:53.704 --> 00:22:54.539
>> How've you been?

460
00:22:54.539 --> 00:22:56.953
[LAUGH]
>> Good, we can continue on with that.

461
00:22:56.953 --> 00:23:00.769
So I'll select these two and I'll make
these 1 2, cuz that's what I want.

462
00:23:00.769 --> 00:23:04.714
I hit Enter twice to stop the numbering,

463
00:23:04.714 --> 00:23:09.230
maybe I'll say like Normal text here.

464
00:23:09.230 --> 00:23:12.984
And then I want to hit Enter, and
then I want to start numbering again.

465
00:23:12.984 --> 00:23:15.879
So if I go ahead and say, what do we say?

466
00:23:15.879 --> 00:23:16.575
>> How are you?

467
00:23:16.575 --> 00:23:17.230
>> How are you?

468
00:23:17.230 --> 00:23:21.532
>> [LAUGH]
>> Right, good to see you.

469
00:23:21.532 --> 00:23:23.240
>> Sure.

470
00:23:23.240 --> 00:23:25.902
>> If I select those,
come back up to numbering.

471
00:23:25.902 --> 00:23:29.952
Notice it's going back to 1,
2, but I don't want that.

472
00:23:29.952 --> 00:23:31.112
The smart tag.

473
00:23:31.112 --> 00:23:34.603
So good, 1 2, Normal text here.

474
00:23:34.603 --> 00:23:37.752
1, 2, now continue numbering.

475
00:23:37.752 --> 00:23:38.882
>> Yeah, it's so cool.

476
00:23:38.882 --> 00:23:39.901
>> Yeah, that's nice.

477
00:23:39.901 --> 00:23:40.840
So that's-
>> Perfect.

478
00:23:40.840 --> 00:23:43.835
>> Where I can say continue numbering-
>> That worked out well.

479
00:23:43.835 --> 00:23:47.321
>> And it keeps on going, and that's nice
because what if I came back up here and

480
00:23:47.321 --> 00:23:47.928
I hit Enter?

481
00:23:47.928 --> 00:23:50.292
Notice that my numbering re-numbers,

482
00:23:50.292 --> 00:23:53.423
there are times where you
don't want that to happen.

483
00:23:53.423 --> 00:23:55.238
I want 1, 2 paragraphs.

484
00:23:55.238 --> 00:23:58.953
1, 2 then just ignore the smart tag.

485
00:23:58.953 --> 00:24:00.223
>> The smart tag, yeah.

486
00:24:00.223 --> 00:24:01.725
>> Yeah, you don't need to answer it.

487
00:24:01.725 --> 00:24:06.830
You don't need to say that's okay,
just stop and ignore and keep on going.

488
00:24:06.830 --> 00:24:11.766
Cuz I do a lot of step by step tutorials,
and a lot of times I need to

489
00:24:11.766 --> 00:24:16.443
put in a little note or something,
but I wanna keep my steps.

490
00:24:16.443 --> 00:24:21.933
I used this continue numbering quite
frequently, and it's pretty, pretty nice.

491
00:24:21.933 --> 00:24:22.900
>> Very nice.

492
00:24:22.900 --> 00:24:25.384
>> So I wanted to let you know that, and
you know I did forget one little thing.

493
00:24:25.384 --> 00:24:26.812
>> Neat trick.

494
00:24:26.812 --> 00:24:29.155
>> That I'd like to do, all I did was,

495
00:24:29.155 --> 00:24:33.152
notice I formatted this with
bullets then I unformatted it.

496
00:24:33.152 --> 00:24:36.796
It's kind of like,
it's a little trick to like just stop it,

497
00:24:36.796 --> 00:24:38.981
cuz it was numbered and renumbered.

498
00:24:38.981 --> 00:24:42.665
I wanted all my paragraphs just to
be back the way that they were.

499
00:24:42.665 --> 00:24:45.050
Let's go ahead and
apply a bullet right here.

500
00:24:45.050 --> 00:24:48.780
Because I was showing you that you
could select the paragraphs and

501
00:24:48.780 --> 00:24:50.150
your bullets don't get selected.

502
00:24:51.410 --> 00:24:54.075
It doesn't happen,
the bullet is part of the paragraph.

503
00:24:54.075 --> 00:24:56.132
So if you've got that paragraph,
you're gonna change it.

504
00:24:56.132 --> 00:24:59.121
We talked about this when we were
changing the font color and the size.

505
00:24:59.121 --> 00:25:04.070
But you can,
if I click on the bullet character itself.

506
00:25:04.070 --> 00:25:09.060
Notice how it grays all of the bullets
within these paragraphs even though like

507
00:25:09.060 --> 00:25:11.563
that first one is probably hard to see.

508
00:25:11.563 --> 00:25:15.181
That first one has got like
the blue selection highlight and

509
00:25:15.181 --> 00:25:16.997
the rest of them are all gray.

510
00:25:16.997 --> 00:25:20.300
And it doesn't maybe feel like you
have all the bullets selected.

511
00:25:20.300 --> 00:25:23.526
But I could change the bullet
character right from here.

512
00:25:23.526 --> 00:25:27.829
And just skip that whole dialog box
that I had gone to from down in here.

513
00:25:27.829 --> 00:25:32.420
Select the bullets,
come into like the purple.

514
00:25:32.420 --> 00:25:36.857
And you see how that is
changing the bullet formating,

515
00:25:36.857 --> 00:25:40.341
not the paired after the text formatting.

516
00:25:40.341 --> 00:25:44.064
So that's a cute little trick in case
you dont wanna have to go down in here.

517
00:25:44.064 --> 00:25:48.112
Selecting the text versus
selecting the bullet character.

518
00:25:48.112 --> 00:25:48.837
>> Right, right.

519
00:25:48.837 --> 00:25:51.262
>> And doing the formatting from there.

520
00:25:51.262 --> 00:25:55.516
So it's just kind of coming back around
to where we had done the formatting of

521
00:25:55.516 --> 00:25:58.055
the bullets and
numbering in the dialog box.

522
00:25:58.055 --> 00:26:02.888
Just do it right here, and I believe,
if I'm looking at my list right now of my-

523
00:26:02.888 --> 00:26:03.529
>> [LAUGH]

524
00:26:03.529 --> 00:26:04.794
>> Notes, I think I've covered

525
00:26:04.794 --> 00:26:06.319
everything that I needed to cover.

526
00:26:06.319 --> 00:26:07.141
>> Great job, Vonne.

527
00:26:07.141 --> 00:26:11.026
Wonderful episode, and
this is Word 2016 Essentials for Mac.

528
00:26:11.026 --> 00:26:15.341
You wanna make sure you watch every single
episode of Word 2016 Essentials for Mac.

529
00:26:15.341 --> 00:26:18.462
You'll be glad you did, help you with
exams and it's good for your mind.

530
00:26:18.462 --> 00:26:21.800
And make sure you visit our course
library, it's hundreds of videos there.

531
00:26:21.800 --> 00:26:24.638
They're all designed to
help you go further.

532
00:26:24.638 --> 00:26:27.227
And make sure you tell everybody
you know about OfficeProTV.

533
00:26:27.227 --> 00:26:28.837
They'll be glad you did,
thanks for watching.

534
00:26:28.837 --> 00:26:29.676
I'm Zach Memos.

535
00:26:29.676 --> 00:26:30.361
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

536
00:26:30.361 --> 00:26:39.620

episodes.description: In this episode, Zac and Vonne explore working with tabs in Microsoft Word 2016. They demonstrate how tabs work by default in Word, then  they show how to add, remove, move, and format tab stops.
episodes.title: Tabs
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.861 --> 00:00:13.793
>> Hello and thank you for
choosing OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:13.793 --> 00:00:15.571
Helping you learn wherever you go.

4
00:00:15.571 --> 00:00:21.010
I'm your host, Zach Memos, and
this is Word 2016, Essentials for Mac.

5
00:00:21.010 --> 00:00:24.990
Tabs, I'm gonna hover on that, tabs.

6
00:00:24.990 --> 00:00:27.260
And who's gonna teach us and
show us the way?

7
00:00:27.260 --> 00:00:28.020
It is Vonne Smith.

8
00:00:28.020 --> 00:00:29.480
Vonne, so nice to have you back.

9
00:00:29.480 --> 00:00:30.300
Thank you so much.

10
00:00:30.300 --> 00:00:33.128
>> I really like the way
you just introduced that,

11
00:00:33.128 --> 00:00:36.925
[LAUGH] because tabs are very
much like that, God, tabs.

12
00:00:36.925 --> 00:00:39.790
>> [LAUGH]
>> Some people kinda get a little scared

13
00:00:39.790 --> 00:00:42.740
when they start talking about tabs,
cuz I think it's cuz they

14
00:00:42.740 --> 00:00:45.930
don't really understand them, and they
don't really know how to work with them.

15
00:00:45.930 --> 00:00:49.524
And what can I do to make it
actually line up all the right way?

16
00:00:49.524 --> 00:00:51.290
>> You're gonna do it Vonne,
I know you are.

17
00:00:51.290 --> 00:00:54.822
>> I'm glad you introduced it a little
bit with that ominous characteristic.

18
00:00:54.822 --> 00:00:56.559
>> [LAUGH]
>> This kinda has that.

19
00:00:56.559 --> 00:01:01.180
That's okay, like you said, I'm here
to help you really understand tabs.

20
00:01:01.180 --> 00:01:01.793
>> Yes.

21
00:01:01.793 --> 00:01:03.637
>> I love tab stops.

22
00:01:03.637 --> 00:01:05.470
I love formatting tabs.

23
00:01:05.470 --> 00:01:06.740
I think they're so much fun.

24
00:01:06.740 --> 00:01:07.630
>> Really useful.

25
00:01:07.630 --> 00:01:09.790
>> But I didn't like them at first, okay?

26
00:01:09.790 --> 00:01:13.755
I was like, no these things,
cuz I didn't understand it.

27
00:01:13.755 --> 00:01:16.537
>> Okay.
>> I didn't understand how they worked, so

28
00:01:16.537 --> 00:01:18.207
I just cursed at them a lot.

29
00:01:18.207 --> 00:01:19.740
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

30
00:01:19.740 --> 00:01:21.350
>> But now that I know what they do and

31
00:01:21.350 --> 00:01:25.320
how to format them,
I've really kind of adapted them and

32
00:01:25.320 --> 00:01:27.487
love to teach people about tab stops.

33
00:01:27.487 --> 00:01:28.339
>> Very nice.

34
00:01:28.339 --> 00:01:33.710
>> So I have a file that I've got open
right now called tabs, I know, crazy.

35
00:01:33.710 --> 00:01:34.945
>> Hey, I don't believe it.

36
00:01:34.945 --> 00:01:36.660
>> [LAUGH]
>> It doesn't make sense.

37
00:01:36.660 --> 00:01:37.880
>> Nope, not at all.

38
00:01:37.880 --> 00:01:38.747
>> Stop.

39
00:01:38.747 --> 00:01:40.923
>> [LAUGH] So we have some here.

40
00:01:40.923 --> 00:01:44.280
And this is just giving me
something to get us started with.

41
00:01:44.280 --> 00:01:49.460
And we have talked about default
tab stops in some other episodes,

42
00:01:49.460 --> 00:01:52.610
cuz it's one of those things
when we're stating to type.

43
00:01:52.610 --> 00:01:54.810
What does it mean when
you hit the tab key?

44
00:01:54.810 --> 00:01:57.750
It is not that you go over five spaces.

45
00:01:57.750 --> 00:02:01.520
Yes, in the olden days with typewriters,
it did have a fixed amount of space that

46
00:02:01.520 --> 00:02:04.830
any time no matter where you hit the tab
it's gonna go over that many spaces.

47
00:02:04.830 --> 00:02:05.790
>> Right.

48
00:02:05.790 --> 00:02:08.205
>> Totally fine, but
that was the old days.

49
00:02:08.205 --> 00:02:11.130
>> Mm-hm.
>> This is the virtual days.

50
00:02:11.130 --> 00:02:13.024
I don't know where I'm
going with this [LAUGH].

51
00:02:13.024 --> 00:02:13.640
>> [LAUGH]
>> Anyways,

52
00:02:13.640 --> 00:02:18.660
it doesn't work that way because how tabs
word in Word is it's going to stop on

53
00:02:18.660 --> 00:02:21.150
every half inch on the ruler.

54
00:02:21.150 --> 00:02:24.070
So having this ruler up is going
to be very important when we're

55
00:02:24.070 --> 00:02:25.240
formatting tab stops.

56
00:02:25.240 --> 00:02:28.470
And just to remind you, that's on that
view tab and you go over to that ruler.

57
00:02:28.470 --> 00:02:32.490
>> So this is very much like
the tabs that used to be on the old

58
00:02:32.490 --> 00:02:34.520
typewriters if people might remember them.

59
00:02:34.520 --> 00:02:36.775
I know I do cuz I'm 150 years old.

60
00:02:36.775 --> 00:02:38.440
>> [LAUGH]
>> But this is a digital version of

61
00:02:38.440 --> 00:02:39.080
it, isn't it?

62
00:02:39.080 --> 00:02:40.160
If you will.

63
00:02:40.160 --> 00:02:41.670
>> Yeah, and I think, if I can remember,

64
00:02:41.670 --> 00:02:45.575
cuz I do have memories of typing on
the typewriter when I was a child.

65
00:02:45.575 --> 00:02:47.290
>> Mm-hm.
>> There are these little

66
00:02:47.290 --> 00:02:48.290
buttons that you would move, right?

67
00:02:48.290 --> 00:02:50.138
>> Right.
They're little sliders and

68
00:02:50.138 --> 00:02:53.188
you'd slide them over to
wherever you wanted to stop at.

69
00:02:53.188 --> 00:02:54.558
>> Yes.
>> And it would stop.

70
00:02:54.558 --> 00:02:56.510
>> Yes.
>> It was automatic.

71
00:02:56.510 --> 00:02:58.240
>> That's exactly what we're doing here,
Zach.

72
00:02:58.240 --> 00:02:58.740
>> Really?
>> Yes.

73
00:02:58.740 --> 00:02:59.240
>> Okay, wonderful.

74
00:02:59.240 --> 00:03:00.328
>> So you can relate!

75
00:03:00.328 --> 00:03:01.450
>> [LAUGH]
>> I can.

76
00:03:01.450 --> 00:03:04.710
>> So yes, that's definitely how it works.

77
00:03:04.710 --> 00:03:07.098
But the default, like I said,
is every half inch on the ruler.

78
00:03:07.098 --> 00:03:12.110
But we wanna take those sliders and say
hey, instead of doing what you normally

79
00:03:12.110 --> 00:03:17.290
do and stopping on that half inch mark,
I want you when you hit the tab or

80
00:03:17.290 --> 00:03:22.290
see a tab character to go to
this particular space and stop.

81
00:03:22.290 --> 00:03:26.350
And then I'm going to tell you how to
align yourself at that stopping point

82
00:03:26.350 --> 00:03:31.410
whether you left justify, or
left align, center align, right align.

83
00:03:31.410 --> 00:03:34.865
Or if I'm working with decimal points,
I want to line up the decimal points.

84
00:03:34.865 --> 00:03:36.220
So lots of cool stuff that you can do.

85
00:03:36.220 --> 00:03:38.890
>> Awesome
>> Definitely have your ruler on,

86
00:03:38.890 --> 00:03:40.020
that's one.

87
00:03:40.020 --> 00:03:43.340
Go back over to your home tab,
turn on your show high characters,

88
00:03:43.340 --> 00:03:44.919
because I did this on purpose.

89
00:03:46.100 --> 00:03:49.750
Cuz tabs can be kind of sneaky in there.

90
00:03:49.750 --> 00:03:52.230
We said that every half inch on the ruler,
so

91
00:03:52.230 --> 00:03:56.265
you can see that on
the ruler there's the stop.

92
00:03:56.265 --> 00:03:57.630
>> Mm-hm.
>> There's that one.

93
00:03:57.630 --> 00:03:59.520
>> Mm-hm.
>> There's another one.

94
00:03:59.520 --> 00:04:05.346
There is another tab in here,
you just don't see it.

95
00:04:05.346 --> 00:04:06.454
>> Very very tricky.

96
00:04:06.454 --> 00:04:09.496
So right in here,
notice it looks like a space.

97
00:04:09.496 --> 00:04:14.266
But if I select this text just to make
it a little bit bigger, there you go.

98
00:04:14.266 --> 00:04:15.770
They can lurk in there.

99
00:04:15.770 --> 00:04:16.450
>> He's lurking.

100
00:04:16.450 --> 00:04:21.060
>> Yes, and where you can't really see it,
but it is doing the formatting.

101
00:04:21.060 --> 00:04:23.840
And it was stopping on the next half inch.

102
00:04:23.840 --> 00:04:27.100
But it is so right up next to where
the half inch was in the ruler

103
00:04:27.100 --> 00:04:29.500
that you didn't even see any
of the physical space, and

104
00:04:29.500 --> 00:04:32.430
you didn't even see the special
character with that show hide item.

105
00:04:32.430 --> 00:04:33.780
And I've had this happen to me.

106
00:04:33.780 --> 00:04:38.410
I was like, why is this text moving
around the way it's doing it?

107
00:04:38.410 --> 00:04:42.750
It's because there's usually really
sneaky, hidden tabs in there.

108
00:04:42.750 --> 00:04:46.730
And just know that's something
you need to always look for

109
00:04:46.730 --> 00:04:48.370
when you're looking at your text.

110
00:04:48.370 --> 00:04:50.290
>> Hm.
>> So we've got on these,

111
00:04:50.290 --> 00:04:54.880
notice that this is a paragraph and
I don't have anything on this ruler.

112
00:04:54.880 --> 00:04:58.020
Just giving you something to look for
in a little bit.

113
00:04:58.020 --> 00:05:01.870
Because how you're going to move those
sliders that you were talking about.

114
00:05:01.870 --> 00:05:03.350
>> Yes.
>> Like on the old typewriters.

115
00:05:03.350 --> 00:05:06.290
You're gonna have to use this
ruler to tell it where that

116
00:05:06.290 --> 00:05:08.640
slider if you wanna say needs to stop.

117
00:05:08.640 --> 00:05:12.750
So right here, I have this particular
paragraph of use the ruler.

118
00:05:12.750 --> 00:05:16.590
And I have a tab character right there,
I hit the tab key.

119
00:05:17.790 --> 00:05:19.450
I don't want it to stop here.

120
00:05:19.450 --> 00:05:22.270
I want it to stop way out here.

121
00:05:22.270 --> 00:05:25.570
It's very small and
I can't really zoom in on it

122
00:05:25.570 --> 00:05:29.150
because I don't have that functionality
on my computer right this moment.

123
00:05:29.150 --> 00:05:33.130
But in the top left hand corner
where the two rulers intersect,

124
00:05:33.130 --> 00:05:35.780
there's a very small little button up
there that looks like there's like

125
00:05:35.780 --> 00:05:37.120
a little arrow going this way.

126
00:05:37.120 --> 00:05:44.870
And if I single click on it, all I'm doing
is I am cycling through that little thing.

127
00:05:44.870 --> 00:05:46.435
And do you see, it's very small.

128
00:05:46.435 --> 00:05:48.110
>> Mm-hm.
>> So I know you guys can

129
00:05:48.110 --> 00:05:48.950
hopefully see it.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zac and Vonne introduce working with styles in Microsoft Word 2016 for Mac. They discuss the importance of using styles, identify types of default styles including the normal paragraph style, indicate style overrides and created styles, and show the location of different style panes for more options.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zac and Vonne continue to explore styles in Microsoft Word 2016 for Mac. They show how to apply default styles from the style gallery, then how to modify styles and update style to match selected formatting. They also demonstrate how to create a new custom style as well as clear overrides.
episodes.title: Styles: Apply

00:19:21.654 --> 00:19:23.704
Forwards, backwards, backwards, forwards,

00:19:23.704 --> 00:19:25.810
it all gets to the same place,

00:19:25.810 --> 00:19:31.546
So, I usually do that, because I like to

I want to see it on the page, do all the
formatting, and then say, yep I like that.

356
00:19:36.410 --> 00:19:41.194
Let's make that the new formatting for
this particular style that I have.

00:19:41.194 --> 00:19:44.549
>> Once again, just because I

00:19:44.549 --> 00:19:48.882
You did say, it's good to put it all

00:19:48.882 --> 00:19:51.956
as normal and then go back in and
do modifications.

00:19:51.956 --> 00:19:54.603
>> Correct, and it's always going to be
normal, no matter what you start with.

361
00:19:54.603 --> 00:19:56.124
>> That's the default.

362
00:19:56.124 --> 00:19:56.728
>> The default style.

363
00:19:56.728 --> 00:19:57.471
>> The default setting.

364
00:19:57.471 --> 00:20:02.392
>> Correct, yes, so if I took this and
went to that other, the File, New, yes,

00:20:02.392 --> 00:20:04.868
normal is always your starting point.

366
00:20:04.868 --> 00:20:06.424
>> All right.
>> Always, always, always.

367
00:20:06.424 --> 00:20:09.907
So that's where you type everything

368
00:20:09.907 --> 00:20:13.316
And yeah, we did talk about those
style overrides, now, another thing,

00:20:13.316 --> 00:20:15.006

00:20:15.006 --> 00:20:21.793
What if I went to here and here's
this heading 1, and I highlighted it,

00:20:21.793 --> 00:20:26.930

00:20:26.930 --> 00:20:33.600
That is a style override, but I don't

00:20:33.600 --> 00:20:36.792
The easiest way to clear an override,

00:20:36.792 --> 00:20:41.058
Notice I can see all of that,
just apply the same heading, or

the same style, sorry, this is

00:20:46.426 --> 00:20:49.180
If I just click on this,
do you see how it, notice it says,

No, do you want to reapply the formatting

00:20:54.236 --> 00:20:55.691
Yes, that's what I want.

And notice that, well, it didn't do that,

00:21:00.390 --> 00:21:01.899
okay, there we go.

00:21:01.899 --> 00:21:05.360
I know why it wasn't doing it,

00:21:05.360 --> 00:21:09.627
The highlighting gets you every time, you

00:21:09.627 --> 00:21:13.515
But, what I was trying to get at
is that I really just wanted to

00:21:13.515 --> 00:21:15.201
apply the regular style.

386
00:21:15.201 --> 00:21:19.520
For example, if I took this and centered

00:21:19.520 --> 00:21:20.695
We go back up to here.

388
00:21:20.695 --> 00:21:25.035
We click title again, it's trying to do
the same thing, reapply the formatting and

00:21:25.035 --> 00:21:27.123
establish the selection, there we go.

390
00:21:27.123 --> 00:21:31.115
And so now it went back to the way it
was supposed to go, so just go ahead and

391
00:21:31.115 --> 00:21:31.973
take that off.

00:21:31.973 --> 00:21:34.748
Or the other thing is,
you could just clear it all together.

00:21:34.748 --> 00:21:38.436
You could just clear the whole thing,

Like it's not letting go completely,

396

All right, now,
what if l wanted to make my own style?

00:21:50.053 --> 00:21:54.579
l don't like the whole,
let's just use heading 1, and

I can make a style called Vonne,

Everybody wants their own stuff, and this

00:22:09.550 --> 00:22:11.214
So what if I take this this text, and

I just did an enter just

00:22:13.437 --> 00:22:17.091
I want this to be,

Let's go with some pink,

00:22:20.624 --> 00:22:21.158

>> [LAUGH] Nope, there we go.

Let's go pink, and we'll make it bold.

We'll make it Apple Chancery, just cuz I

00:22:34.732 --> 00:22:38.285
Beautiful, this needs to be its own style.

00:22:38.285 --> 00:22:41.331
So select the text, do your formatting,

come over here to New Style

416
00:22:45.081 --> 00:22:48.518
And now we get this dialog

417
00:22:48.518 --> 00:22:52.024
So now let's give it a name,
let's go with Vonne.

418
00:22:52.024 --> 00:22:52.639
>> Vonne's style.

419
00:22:52.639 --> 00:22:55.786
>> Vonne's style, there we go, yeah.

420
00:22:55.786 --> 00:22:57.504
What type do you want it to be?

421
00:22:57.504 --> 00:23:01.509
Do you want it to be a paragraph or

00:23:01.509 --> 00:23:03.065
I would just keep it as paragraph.

00:23:03.065 --> 00:23:05.402
Cuz remember that whole
you can break the rule and

you can still just select

00:23:08.258 --> 00:23:11.370
So I would go ahead and keep it this way.

I get a little bit more specific if I know
I'm only gonna ever use it as a character

00:23:15.473 --> 00:23:18.305
style, I'll go ahead and
change it, but it's okay.

We could take that, now,
these next two, Styles based on and

Styles following, they're important.

And a lot of people overlook them, and

I think it's why people

Notice it says, Styles based on normal.

433
00:23:36.135 --> 00:23:42.634
Okay, if I keep that,
what that means is that if normal changes,

00:23:42.634 --> 00:23:46.305
this has the potential of changing.

435
00:23:48.755 --> 00:23:49.858
>> It has the potential.

436
00:23:49.858 --> 00:23:51.785
>> Yes, very, yes, it's.

00:23:51.785 --> 00:23:52.482
>> It could possibly do it?

438
00:23:52.482 --> 00:23:55.663
>> Yes, definitely, so
it's like, eh, okay.

439
00:23:55.663 --> 00:23:59.359
Let me try to demonstrate this, so

00:24:02.054 --> 00:24:05.391
So let's just click OK Everything's great.

00:24:05.391 --> 00:24:09.981
All right, so if I change the normal

00:24:09.981 --> 00:24:12.592
it could potentially change this.

00:24:12.592 --> 00:24:13.300
Let me show you.

00:24:13.300 --> 00:24:17.971
I'm going to right click, go to Modify,

00:24:17.971 --> 00:24:21.713

We'll make it Center.

00:24:26.495 --> 00:24:29.540
Look at how that centered itself too,

00:24:29.540 --> 00:24:30.340
Why?

00:24:30.340 --> 00:24:36.793
Because the Vonne style is
based off of the normal style.

00:24:36.793 --> 00:24:44.430
Now that's not Bold, notice the B is not

00:24:44.430 --> 00:24:48.050
And that's why I'm saying it's not

00:24:48.050 --> 00:24:51.380
Because in the Vonne style,
let me go up to Modify,

I didn't specify whether it was Left,

455
00:24:56.250 --> 00:24:59.170
If I had specified that

00:24:59.170 --> 00:25:03.950
then when I went to the normal and

00:25:03.950 --> 00:25:09.435
Because it was like two competing

00:25:09.435 --> 00:25:15.650
The alignment well I specifically

00:25:15.650 --> 00:25:18.250
So change the normal to center

00:25:18.250 --> 00:25:19.660
Just like the font right?

00:25:19.660 --> 00:25:25.300
I said, the font in here is

00:25:25.300 --> 00:25:28.340
So by me making normal Bold,

00:25:28.340 --> 00:25:32.580
So it has to be where if there

00:25:32.580 --> 00:25:38.989
almost like a line item, if it's on the
same line or the same type of formatting,

00:25:38.989 --> 00:25:43.922
that has a specific thing,
here in the cell not gonna change.

00:25:43.922 --> 00:25:48.910
If it's left open, if it's left blank

00:25:48.910 --> 00:25:53.990

00:25:53.990 --> 00:25:56.000
So that's where it can get a little weird.

469
00:25:56.000 --> 00:25:57.000
Some people like this.

00:25:57.000 --> 00:25:59.890
Some people say, yes,
I want it to be when I change the normal,

00:26:02.420 --> 00:26:05.140
There's other times that was like,
I don't want you to have any,

00:26:05.140 --> 00:26:07.150
I don't have anything to do with that,

00:26:07.150 --> 00:26:11.080
I want absolutely no connection
to any other style so

00:26:11.080 --> 00:26:14.035

00:26:14.035 --> 00:26:19.620
Anything that changes somewhere else is

477
00:26:19.620 --> 00:26:24.580
That tends to be how I go

00:26:24.580 --> 00:26:27.270
so just letting you know

00:26:27.270 --> 00:26:31.740
Let me go ahead and just Undo back

00:26:31.740 --> 00:26:36.315
if I come back up into the Vonne style and

481
00:26:36.315 --> 00:26:41.544
Let's go with

482
00:26:41.544 --> 00:26:46.360
[LAUGH]
I forgot where I was going honestly.

483
00:26:46.360 --> 00:26:49.920
[LAUGH] I wanna make this

00:26:49.920 --> 00:26:52.928
No style at all, click OK.

485
00:26:52.928 --> 00:26:58.740
And one other thing that I needed to point
out that I didn't really tell you about

00:26:58.740 --> 00:27:04.746

It's weird, when you go ahead and

it doesn't apply the style to itself.

00:27:13.457 --> 00:27:14.520
It's a weird thing.

So you have to come back and make sure
that you click on the style itself and

00:27:18.790 --> 00:27:19.639

00:27:19.639 --> 00:27:23.719
Now that's permanently attached to
the Vonne style not the normal plus

00:27:23.719 --> 00:27:27.010

494
00:27:27.010 --> 00:27:28.957
You make it then you apply it.

495
00:27:28.957 --> 00:27:32.314
All right, so now coming back here to

00:27:32.314 --> 00:27:33.240

00:27:33.240 --> 00:27:35.590
But that is how you can

00:27:35.590 --> 00:27:39.490
If I right click go to

00:27:42.160 --> 00:27:44.700
Nope, because it's not

00:27:44.700 --> 00:27:46.540
So that's why it didn't change.

502
00:27:46.540 --> 00:27:52.069
Just trying to again demonstrate,

00:27:52.069 --> 00:27:57.869
important to understand the concept of it

00:27:57.869 --> 00:28:01.790
I mean, that's up to you but

505

The other one that's in that style

What about the next style?

This is kind of the big one, because

If I hit, Enter and I start typing,

I really wanna be when I type

Do you want it to continue on

00:28:47.398 --> 00:28:54.090

00:28:54.090 --> 00:28:57.990
Then you click OK, type, type,

00:28:57.990 --> 00:28:58.786
type, type, type, type.

Back to normal [LAUGH].

I'll go ahead and type, use a keyboard

00:29:22.200 --> 00:29:24.030

526
00:29:24.030 --> 00:29:27.780
And just to show you where that assigning
keyboard shortcuts in case you're like,

00:29:27.780 --> 00:29:28.620

00:29:28.620 --> 00:29:29.410
It's down here.

Notice there is a shortcut key that

00:29:34.230 --> 00:29:38.040
So that way, if you are a formatting

00:29:38.040 --> 00:29:39.852

00:29:45.491 --> 00:29:50.380

534
00:29:50.380 --> 00:29:54.710
And as you go, and it's pretty,
pretty nice that way.

535
00:29:54.710 --> 00:29:55.620

00:29:55.620 --> 00:30:00.879

The heading1 is back to

My normal paragraph style does

So any New Document,

542
00:30:27.580 --> 00:30:32.200

543
00:30:32.200 --> 00:30:36.400
But if you can just start

00:30:36.400 --> 00:30:37.957
You know how to modify the defaults.

00:30:37.957 --> 00:30:39.710
You know how to make your own.

00:30:39.710 --> 00:30:40.990
You know how to apply them.

00:30:40.990 --> 00:30:43.190
You know the whole concept of it.

548
00:30:44.810 --> 00:30:47.560
You're sitting there going,
this is really cool.

549
00:30:47.560 --> 00:30:49.950
>> It is really cool.
>> I'm gonna totally use this.

550
00:30:49.950 --> 00:30:55.530
And you start going and stylizing your
documents, and it's good stuff so.

551
00:30:55.530 --> 00:30:57.920
>> Fantastic,
wonderful job Vonne, as usual.

She got me excited about doing this,

00:31:05.440 --> 00:31:08.030

episodes.description: In this episode, Zac and Vonne demonstrate style sets and themes in Microsoft Word 2016. They review the different style sets, paragraph spacing styles, and how to modify the components of a theme.
episodes.title: Style Sets and Themes
