00:15:49.933 --> 00:15:53.293
you have gone through and
changed your colors.

286
00:15:53.293 --> 00:15:56.098
You could, if you wanted to,

287
00:15:56.098 --> 00:16:01.269
you could save your own theme,
based on what you have.

288
00:16:01.269 --> 00:16:03.649
And that would also carry
over into PowerPoint.

289
00:16:03.649 --> 00:16:07.134
So you could either start in Word and
carry it over to PowerPoint, start in

290
00:16:07.134 --> 00:16:10.923
PowerPoint, save your themes and colors,
then come over and apply it in Word.

291
00:16:10.923 --> 00:16:16.368
Whichever way you want to go,
I'm not going to go, actually save it.

292
00:16:16.368 --> 00:16:20.999
But I wanna bring this into this dialogue
box because I wanted to show you

293
00:16:20.999 --> 00:16:22.243
where you're at.

294
00:16:22.243 --> 00:16:25.923
You're way down in here to
where I have the different,

295
00:16:25.923 --> 00:16:29.604
that's why I was trying to
go back over into my themes.

296
00:16:29.604 --> 00:16:32.995
I'm in my user content down in
my group containers libraries.

297
00:16:32.995 --> 00:16:38.288
You're in the themes folder in
your application of Office,

298
00:16:38.288 --> 00:16:42.146
so that's where it goes
across all of them.

299
00:16:42.146 --> 00:16:46.327
It's not just particularly
one application.

300
00:16:46.327 --> 00:16:50.428
So if you wanted and you go through all of
your different changes, you can do that.

301
00:16:50.428 --> 00:16:53.960
You can also save your own style sets.

302
00:16:53.960 --> 00:16:57.570
That's where if I really wanted to,

303
00:16:57.570 --> 00:17:03.167
I could take all of that fancy
stuff that I did here, yes.

304
00:17:03.167 --> 00:17:06.490
Where I did my heading ones and
headings twos and

305
00:17:06.490 --> 00:17:10.576
all my different styles,
I could save that as a style set.

306
00:17:10.576 --> 00:17:15.115
Style sets, themes, they are a little,
they are separate, okay?

307
00:17:15.115 --> 00:17:19.656
So you could go through and change that
because that might be something good where

308
00:17:19.656 --> 00:17:23.813
you want to be able to quickly apply
that style set to multiple documents.

309
00:17:23.813 --> 00:17:28.725
So you could save it there but just to let
you know that those options are there,

310
00:17:28.725 --> 00:17:33.714
saving your own style sets And, and or
saving your custom themes, which is your

311
00:17:33.714 --> 00:17:38.500
colors, fonts and your effects that go
across all of your Office programs.

312
00:17:38.500 --> 00:17:40.357
So fun stuff, cool.

313
00:17:40.357 --> 00:17:43.532
Use the default settings in the sense
of like headings one, two and threes,

314
00:17:43.532 --> 00:17:44.383
and all that stuff.

315
00:17:44.383 --> 00:17:46.032
Come in here, click a button.

316
00:17:46.032 --> 00:17:47.530
And then poof, look at that.

317
00:17:47.530 --> 00:17:48.981
I made this amazing looking document.

318
00:17:48.981 --> 00:17:52.349
A Mary Kay document, right,
with all of our pink.

319
00:17:52.349 --> 00:17:56.098
And you can go ahead and just, with
a single click and a couple color changes.

320
00:17:56.098 --> 00:17:58.568
>> Well, Vonne, once again,
you got me very excited about all of this.

321
00:17:58.568 --> 00:18:04.199
And that was style sets and themes
within Word 2016 Essentials for Mac.

322
00:18:04.199 --> 00:18:05.476
Great job, Vonne.

323
00:18:05.476 --> 00:18:07.950
Thank you so very much and
I guess I do like Mary Kay pink.

324
00:18:07.950 --> 00:18:08.856
It's nice.

325
00:18:08.856 --> 00:18:09.557
And listen,

326
00:18:09.557 --> 00:18:13.836
you should watch every single episode
of our Word 2016 Essentials for Mac.

327
00:18:13.836 --> 00:18:17.539
Great series and also check out
the other videos in our course library.

328
00:18:17.539 --> 00:18:21.209
Hundreds of them and they're all designed
to do one thing, help you go further.

329
00:18:21.209 --> 00:18:23.345
And tell everybody you
know about OfficeProTV.

330
00:18:23.345 --> 00:18:24.947
They'll be very glad you did.

331
00:18:24.947 --> 00:18:26.317
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

332
00:18:26.317 --> 00:18:27.118
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

333
00:18:27.118 --> 00:18:29.255
>> And we will see you soon.

334
00:18:29.255 --> 00:18:33.039
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Zac and Vonne dive into the different elements of keep options (pagination options), breaks and columns. Vonne demonstrates the different pagination options in the format paragraph dialog box such as widow and orphan control, keep lines together, and keep with next. She also describes the importance of section and page breaks to control page layout options. Lastly, they explore formatting pages/sections in columns and column breaks.
episodes.title: Keep Options, Breaks and Columns
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:09.278
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.009 --> 00:00:12.622
Thank you for

3
00:00:12.622 --> 00:00:16.319
choosing OfficePro.TV, empowering
the world through engaging learning.

4
00:00:16.319 --> 00:00:20.805
I'm your host, Zach Memos, as we continue
on with Word 2016 Essentials for Mac.

5
00:00:20.805 --> 00:00:25.253
And this is going to be,
keep options, breaks, and columns.

6
00:00:25.253 --> 00:00:28.127
And Vonne Smith is here, once again,
to help us out with that information.

7
00:00:28.127 --> 00:00:29.353
Vonne, good to see you.

8
00:00:29.353 --> 00:00:30.622
>> Good to see you, too.

9
00:00:30.622 --> 00:00:33.349
Yes, this is one of my,
my episodes, [LAUGH].

10
00:00:33.349 --> 00:00:34.295
>> My!

11
00:00:34.295 --> 00:00:37.312
>> Keep options, breaks, and columns, my!

12
00:00:37.312 --> 00:00:40.239
So that's just one of those-
>> [LAUGH]

13
00:00:40.239 --> 00:00:41.103
>> Yeah, you got it?

14
00:00:41.103 --> 00:00:41.655
>> I get the gist.

15
00:00:41.655 --> 00:00:44.296
>> [LAUGH]
>> Options, breaks, and columns, my!

16
00:00:44.296 --> 00:00:45.087
>> Yeah.

17
00:00:45.087 --> 00:00:46.095
>> Breaks and columns, my!

18
00:00:46.095 --> 00:00:47.056
>> Yeah, exactly.

19
00:00:47.056 --> 00:00:49.365
So I like to keep things
in threes too sometimes.

20
00:00:49.365 --> 00:00:54.222
So this is actually really
important concepts in

21
00:00:54.222 --> 00:00:58.374
Word that I think it a little passed over.

22
00:00:58.374 --> 00:01:02.737
But it is so
essential to understanding all sorts of

23
00:01:02.737 --> 00:01:05.687
different things in page layout.

24
00:01:05.687 --> 00:01:09.511
Because that's the topic that we're in
right now, is page layout, and how to,

25
00:01:09.511 --> 00:01:11.042
well, lay out your page [LAUGH].

26
00:01:11.042 --> 00:01:13.505
And understanding section breaks,

27
00:01:13.505 --> 00:01:17.800
especially continuous section breaks,
and why you want them.

28
00:01:17.800 --> 00:01:22.390
When to use them, and
how to put them in is pretty important,

29
00:01:22.390 --> 00:01:25.721
just like I think everything is important.

30
00:01:25.721 --> 00:01:29.218
And I think everything's fun and
amazing and so

31
00:01:29.218 --> 00:01:33.778
essential to what you need to
know in Word, so let me show you.

32
00:01:33.778 --> 00:01:35.805
All right, so why don't we go ahead and
open up the file?

33
00:01:35.805 --> 00:01:39.528
I have a file called,
Keep Options Custom Headings,

34
00:01:39.528 --> 00:01:42.351
now why did I call them custom headings?

35
00:01:42.351 --> 00:01:48.513
Well, because I needed to override
some of the default settings.

36
00:01:48.513 --> 00:01:54.083
So we can go ahead and talk about
the concepts of keep options, all right?

37
00:01:54.083 --> 00:01:57.541
So there's my little disclaimer right now,

38
00:01:57.541 --> 00:02:03.093
is that these are custom headings that
I have turned off these features.

39
00:02:03.093 --> 00:02:07.927
That will be on by default in a new file,
and so on and so forth, which, of course,

40
00:02:07.927 --> 00:02:10.116
you know I'll demonstrate for you.

41
00:02:10.116 --> 00:02:14.028
But that's the reason why I
have this file named this.

42
00:02:14.028 --> 00:02:18.610
Keep options, widows and orphans,
that sounds so depressing,

43
00:02:18.610 --> 00:02:21.622

44
00:02:21.622 --> 00:02:25.528
And this is in the sense of how
it's treating lines within your

45
00:02:25.528 --> 00:02:26.894
paragraphs, okay?

46
00:02:26.894 --> 00:02:30.829
So, let's scroll on down,
for example, right here,

47
00:02:30.829 --> 00:02:34.866
notice that in this paragraph,
Alice was not a bit hurt.

48
00:02:34.866 --> 00:02:39.788
It's just a single sentence that's
just kinda hanging out by itself on

49
00:02:39.788 --> 00:02:41.520
the bottom of this page.

50
00:02:41.520 --> 00:02:44.588
And then rest of the paragraph, here,
let's turn on that show hide paragraph

51
00:02:44.588 --> 00:02:46.458
just so
we can see that it's all one paragraph.

52
00:02:46.458 --> 00:02:50.365
The rest of it's down here,
that's not the best break point.

53
00:02:50.365 --> 00:02:52.044
>> Is that what you call an orphan?

54
00:02:52.044 --> 00:02:55.906
>> That would be a widow,
I had to look it up [LAUGH].

55
00:02:55.906 --> 00:03:01.237
>> Yes, the widow, the widow is when
the last, wait, no, you're right.

56
00:03:01.237 --> 00:03:03.799
Okay, the orphan is the first, yep,

57
00:03:03.799 --> 00:03:07.092
the first line at the bottom of the page,
sorry.

58
00:03:07.092 --> 00:03:11.297
And a widow is the last line of
the paragraph on the top of the next page,

59
00:03:11.297 --> 00:03:12.184
so yes.

60
00:03:12.184 --> 00:03:12.748
>> Okay.

61
00:03:12.748 --> 00:03:16.269
>> This would be an orphan, this would be,

62
00:03:16.269 --> 00:03:21.564
there's one down somewhere,
where, well, it went away.

63
00:03:21.564 --> 00:03:26.271
So that would be, [LAUGH] the other
one would be a widow, right?

64
00:03:26.271 --> 00:03:31.181
So, it just doesn't really make sense, or
it just doesn't look good, personally,

65
00:03:31.181 --> 00:03:32.573
to have-
>> No it doesn't, it doesn't.

66
00:03:32.573 --> 00:03:37.343
>> A single sentence on the top of the
page is just kinda, if you had like two.

67
00:03:37.343 --> 00:03:39.265
Or maybe two or three together,

68
00:03:39.265 --> 00:03:43.121
that would be a little bit better
of this is one whole paragraph.

69
00:03:43.121 --> 00:03:46.723
So that's what they mean by widow and
orphan control.

70
00:03:46.723 --> 00:03:50.466
This is on, I'm using a normal style,
like I said,

71
00:03:50.466 --> 00:03:55.073
that I turned it off, cuz it is on

72
00:03:55.073 --> 00:03:57.800
Now I'm going to go into

73
00:03:57.800 --> 00:03:59.653
I think you should always use files.

74
00:03:59.653 --> 00:04:02.342
And that's where you should control
every bit of your formatting from.

75
00:04:02.342 --> 00:04:07.075
But you can go and format this
individually, like per paragraph, or

76
00:04:07.075 --> 00:04:09.449
do individual overrides on this.

77
00:04:09.449 --> 00:04:12.677
So, I just wanted to show you
that to format paragraphs,

78
00:04:12.677 --> 00:04:15.184
we're going to go into the Line and
Breaks.

79
00:04:15.184 --> 00:04:19.045
Or Line and Page Breaks to talk about
this particular type of pagination or

80
00:04:19.045 --> 00:04:19.866
keep options.

81
00:04:19.866 --> 00:04:23.549
So it's here, I'm just gonna do
it through the style definition.

82
00:04:23.549 --> 00:04:28.636
So let's get into the Normal style and
modify down at the bottom.

83
00:04:28.636 --> 00:04:33.146
We're gonna come into the Paragraph
right here and right there,

84
00:04:33.146 --> 00:04:34.956
Widow/orphan control.

85

What that means, when you check that on,
or if it's already on,

86
00:04:39.420 --> 00:04:43.738
that it's going to try to avoid
giving you widows and orphans.

87
00:04:43.738 --> 00:04:45.490
>> So it'll do it automatically, Vonne?

88
00:04:45.490 --> 00:04:46.354
>> Yes, yes.

89
00:04:46.354 --> 00:04:47.194
>> That's fantastic.

90
00:04:47.194 --> 00:04:54.011
>> It understands where it wants or
where it should break your pages up.

91
00:04:54.011 --> 00:04:57.243
So let's turn this on and just,
just to kinda remind us, remember,

92
00:04:57.243 --> 00:04:58.935
there was that one line right here.

93
00:04:58.935 --> 00:05:04.063
But I click OK, and then click OK again,
notice that, where did it go?

94
00:05:04.063 --> 00:05:06.584
It was two by itself-
>> It was adopted!

95
00:05:06.584 --> 00:05:08.335
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, right, yes.

96
00:05:08.335 --> 00:05:11.299
It was adopted into the rest of the
paragraph, I like the way you said that!

97
00:05:11.299 --> 00:05:12.763
>> That's right, it's what happens!

98
00:05:12.763 --> 00:05:17.378
>> So it determined that that was not
a good break point of that particular

99
00:05:17.378 --> 00:05:18.249

100
00:05:18.249 --> 00:05:21.971
So to change the pagination across pages,
it went ahead and

101
00:05:21.971 --> 00:05:25.702
forced that line down,
because that's how it needs to go.

102
00:05:25.702 --> 00:05:29.585
So that's what that means with widow and
orphan control.

103
00:05:29.585 --> 00:05:33.333
Now I'm doing a command N, for
file new, so I have a new document.

104
00:05:33.333 --> 00:05:37.577
And if you look at the normal style,
notice that in the paragraph formatting,

105
00:05:37.577 --> 00:05:40.747
that's already gone, so
it's gonna do that by default.

106
00:05:40.747 --> 00:05:44.307
And some people are like, I started
typing and the line just jumped down.

107
00:05:44.307 --> 00:05:49.999
Or it went ahead and put the second
sentence back up on the other page,

108
00:05:49.999 --> 00:05:54.923
because it'll do two lines and
then it'll break the page.

109
00:05:54.923 --> 00:05:57.930
But if it determines that's not
enough space, it'll take that one and

110
00:05:57.930 --> 00:05:59.044
bring it all the way down.

111
00:05:59.044 --> 00:06:03.667
And the same for the bottom of the page,
like it has to be two or

112
00:06:03.667 --> 00:06:06.408
more to go ahead and stay together.

113
00:06:06.408 --> 00:06:11.743
Now, I say that, that's different
than this, Keep lines together.

114
00:06:11.743 --> 00:06:16.274
Keep lines together means
that it will keep the whole

115
00:06:16.274 --> 00:06:21.325
paragraph intact and
it will not jump across paragraphs.

116
00:06:21.325 --> 00:06:26.526
For example right here, see, right here,
this paragraph, it went ahead and did two.

117
00:06:26.526 --> 00:06:29.673
Remember, l was looking for this before,
because once l turned the widow and

118
00:06:29.673 --> 00:06:30.504
orphan control on.

119
00:06:30.504 --> 00:06:35.689
It said, to help break up the pages,
l can put two more sentences down here,

120
00:06:35.689 --> 00:06:39.272
or two more lines of this
paragraph on the next page.

121
00:06:39.272 --> 00:06:42.298
I don't have the keep it
all on the other one, so

122
00:06:42.298 --> 00:06:45.503
that was that widow and
orphan control in effect.

123
00:06:45.503 --> 00:06:49.627
But if I took in, going into
the style definition for this one.

124
00:06:49.627 --> 00:06:54.476
If I went back into the Paragraph
formatting and the Line and

125
00:06:54.476 --> 00:06:56.223
Page Break options.

126
00:06:56.223 --> 00:07:01.888
If I chose Keep lines together, watch

127
00:07:01.888 --> 00:07:07.414
It all jumped, it said, I'm saying,
in this paragraph style,

128
00:07:07.414 --> 00:07:11.537
keep them together,
do not break across pages.

129
00:07:11.537 --> 00:07:13.134
>> Reunited and it feels so good.

130
00:07:13.134 --> 00:07:14.717
>> [LAUGH] Yes.

131
00:07:14.717 --> 00:07:16.037
I feel like I need to start swaying now,
[LAUGH].

132
00:07:16.037 --> 00:07:18.687
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yes, so that's what

133
00:07:18.687 --> 00:07:23.600
it means by Keep lines together,
which, again, it's a personal choice.

134
00:07:23.600 --> 00:07:25.831
But it does sometimes tend to create,

135
00:07:25.831 --> 00:07:29.816

136
00:07:29.816 --> 00:07:32.863
If that's something that you're just like,
ooh,

137
00:07:32.863 --> 00:07:36.895
that's bothering me,
then don't keep the lines together, okay?

138
00:07:36.895 --> 00:07:39.405
And that's not on by default, but

139
00:07:39.405 --> 00:07:44.002
it is something that it's good
to understand what that means.

140
00:07:44.002 --> 00:07:46.179
To go ahead and
keep all the lines together.

141
00:07:46.179 --> 00:07:51.102
Now there's another one that says,
Keep with next.

142
00:07:51.102 --> 00:07:55.772
I wouldn't necessarily choose
this particular option on

143
00:07:55.772 --> 00:07:58.161
the normal paragraph style.

144
00:07:58.161 --> 00:08:02.916
Where I'd really put the keep with
next would be on a heading and

145
00:08:02.916 --> 00:08:04.629
that's back up here.

146
00:08:04.629 --> 00:08:09.814
This Ace of Hearts, you don't want
a heading at the bottom of the page and

147
00:08:09.814 --> 00:08:14.574
then the next paragraph that it's
associated with like a normal,

148
00:08:14.574 --> 00:08:16.622
they're separated apart.

149
00:08:16.622 --> 00:08:21.611
That's where I would say,
keep with the next paragraph.

150
00:08:21.611 --> 00:08:27.163
This heading needs to always be
connected to the next paragraph.

151
00:08:27.163 --> 00:08:28.438
That's where I would use that one.

152
00:08:28.438 --> 00:08:31.883
So, I'm putting my cursor
here on Ace of Hearts,

153
00:08:31.883 --> 00:08:35.668
right clicking up on the Heading 2,
modifying that.

154
00:08:35.668 --> 00:08:39.810
Going into the Paragraph,
formatting and keeping, nope.

155
00:08:39.810 --> 00:08:41.306
Keep with Next, that's what I just said.

156
00:08:41.306 --> 00:08:42.747
[LAUGH] So we'll take that.

157
00:08:42.747 --> 00:08:46.864
We'll click OK, and see, jumps down, okay?

158
00:08:46.864 --> 00:08:50.633
So all of these I would
set in your styles, okay?

159
00:08:50.633 --> 00:08:54.926
I would probably put at all of my
headings as keep with next because I want

160
00:08:54.926 --> 00:08:59.434
to make sure that it keeps next,
I would always keep the, we don't know for

161
00:08:59.434 --> 00:09:01.384
orphan controls on the normal.

162
00:09:01.384 --> 00:09:06.096
If it was something that I just
never wanted my paragraphs to

163
00:09:06.096 --> 00:09:07.799
break across pages.

164
00:09:07.799 --> 00:09:12.936
Then I would choose that keep lines
together within the style definitions,

165
00:09:12.936 --> 00:09:16.398
and everything will stay
together pretty nicely.

166
00:09:16.398 --> 00:09:21.736
Now there's one that I didn't
review right at this moment,

167
00:09:21.736 --> 00:09:24.674
and that was adding a page break.

168
00:09:24.674 --> 00:09:26.642
The reason why is cuz well,
I didn't talk about page breaks [LAUGH].

169
00:09:26.642 --> 00:09:29.029
>> No, we haven't.

170
00:09:29.029 --> 00:09:29.744
>> No, we haven't.

171
00:09:29.744 --> 00:09:34.511
But just notice that there is
an option in your keep options,

172
00:09:34.511 --> 00:09:40.689
I call them keep options where it says,
page break before, keep that in mind.

173
00:09:40.689 --> 00:09:43.892
And also that I would be doing
this in a style definition.

174
00:09:43.892 --> 00:09:46.270
You're like all right,
got that in my brain.

175

00:23:31.970 --> 00:23:33.727
I know you wanna go there, at least I do.

406
00:23:33.727 --> 00:23:37.107
[LAUGH] I go into a column break, and

407
00:23:37.107 --> 00:23:42.014
then it [SOUND] forces that
up into the next column.

408
00:23:42.014 --> 00:23:45.180
So that's what we would do for
column breaks.

409
00:23:46.560 --> 00:23:47.780
And there we go.

410
00:23:47.780 --> 00:23:48.720
Perfect.
Now it does kind

411
00:23:48.720 --> 00:23:51.350
of throw off my spacing in here.

412
00:23:51.350 --> 00:23:53.240
So I might wanna get ahead and
get rid of that.

413
00:23:53.240 --> 00:23:57.050
If I don't want that there, again,
put in your cursor in the front.

414
00:23:57.050 --> 00:23:58.188
Forward delete.

415
00:23:58.188 --> 00:23:59.828
Okay, get rid of that.

416
00:23:59.828 --> 00:24:02.813
And so we can take that off.

417
00:24:02.813 --> 00:24:04.140
Pretty cool.

418
00:24:04.140 --> 00:24:08.020
So you can see where sections
can do a lot for you.

419
00:24:08.020 --> 00:24:12.610
You can start changing the layout
of your pages in different places.

420
00:24:12.610 --> 00:24:16.469
Removing them, that's always
an important thing to say, hey,

421
00:24:16.469 --> 00:24:20.483
I want to get rid of that,
putting it in front and forward deleting.

422
00:24:20.483 --> 00:24:23.004
Notice that all my columns went away too.

423
00:24:23.004 --> 00:24:24.235
Wait, I was in the wrong section.

424
00:24:24.235 --> 00:24:26.710
[LAUGH] Making sure you're
in the right section.

425
00:24:26.710 --> 00:24:27.740
That's always important.

426
00:24:27.740 --> 00:24:30.470
But you can go ahead and
format that differently.

427
00:24:30.470 --> 00:24:36.010
And again, just to say that if you
wanted to put this on to the next page,

428
00:24:36.010 --> 00:24:43.670
you could go ahead and make a section,
a continuous section break.

429
00:24:43.670 --> 00:24:49.964
And then do a page break, but
then you're double breaking.

430
00:24:49.964 --> 00:24:53.927
You don't really need to,
there's nothing wrong with this,

431
00:24:53.927 --> 00:24:58.887
it's just you can go ahead and accomplish
it all in one with doing a next break.

432
00:24:58.887 --> 00:25:03.952
And then using all of those options within
a style can even make it a little bit more

433
00:25:03.952 --> 00:25:09.040

orphans and the keep lines together.

434
00:25:09.040 --> 00:25:12.639
To me, as somebody that

435
00:25:12.639 --> 00:25:16.429
this is the be all and
end all of everything that I do.

436
00:25:16.429 --> 00:25:23.154
Because the flow of your text, the
readability of the book that I lay out,

437
00:25:23.154 --> 00:25:28.049
making sure that this all
flows nicely is important.

438
00:25:28.049 --> 00:25:33.665
And it might be things that you don't
even really notice as a normal person.

439
00:25:33.665 --> 00:25:37.253
Now that you're taking all my classes,
you're not normal, you're gonna be like

440
00:25:37.253 --> 00:25:40.788
me where you're going to start looking at
every single piece of literature you get

441
00:25:40.788 --> 00:25:43.790

the spacing of everything.

442
00:25:43.790 --> 00:25:46.520
And you're gonna be like, wow,
this is really hard to read.

443
00:25:46.520 --> 00:25:49.769
They really need to increase
their leading, line spacing.

444
00:25:49.769 --> 00:25:54.181
So you're gonna start seeing
the same things that I do, and

445
00:25:54.181 --> 00:25:58.870
hopefully that way it is not even
noticeable to normal people.

446
00:25:58.870 --> 00:26:00.442
It just reads beautifully.

447
00:26:00.442 --> 00:26:05.306
But how to control your pagination,
where things break, how things flow

448
00:26:05.306 --> 00:26:10.719
throughout your document, and how to apply
those different types of page layouts

449
00:26:10.719 --> 00:26:16.536
to different parts of your documents, the
sections that's so very important in Word.

450
00:26:16.536 --> 00:26:21.638
And hopefully, this is kind of like
sometimes kinda the boring stuff,

451
00:26:21.638 --> 00:26:23.516
or at least people [NOISE].

452
00:26:23.516 --> 00:26:24.917
I don't think it's boring.

453
00:26:24.917 --> 00:26:26.812
I hope you don't think it's boring.

454
00:26:26.812 --> 00:26:32.648
I hope, again, you're getting those
now I know why Word keeps doing that,

455
00:26:32.648 --> 00:26:36.673
and where I can go to control it,
and with my styles.

456
00:26:36.673 --> 00:26:38.861
And hopefully you've learned a few things.

457
00:26:38.861 --> 00:26:41.762
And I think I'm gonna go ahead and
apply the brakes right now and

458
00:26:41.762 --> 00:26:43.240
say that we're done.

459
00:26:43.240 --> 00:26:45.195
>> Wonderful, well,
it's very artistic, isn't it?

460
00:26:45.195 --> 00:26:46.650
It's not just literary.

461
00:26:46.650 --> 00:26:50.300
It becomes artistic when you're really
working on styles and formats and layouts.

462
00:26:50.300 --> 00:26:52.010
So keep options, breaks, columns.

463
00:26:52.010 --> 00:26:53.000
Wonderful episode.

464
00:26:53.000 --> 00:26:57.190
Make sure you see everything in the Word
2016 Essentials for Mac series.

465
00:26:57.190 --> 00:26:59.810
Check out all the other

466

all of Vonne's great videos

467
00:27:02.640 --> 00:27:05.885
You'll be glad you did, and
it's designed to help you go further.

468
00:27:05.885 --> 00:27:07.840
And tell everybody you
know about OfficeProTV.

469
00:27:07.840 --> 00:27:09.120
They'll be very glad you did.

470
00:27:09.120 --> 00:27:10.510
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

00:27:10.510 --> 00:27:11.110
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

472
00:27:11.110 --> 00:27:13.153
>> And we'll see you soon.

473
00:27:13.153 --> 00:27:18.447

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne continue with more page layout options by demonstrating how to insert blank pages and a cover page. They explore how a cover page use document fields connected to defined document properties, if present, as well as formatting content generated by the cover page.
episodes.title: Blank Page and Cover Page
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:09.756
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.954 --> 00:00:14.185
Hello, and thank you for
choosing OfficeProTV,

3
00:00:14.185 --> 00:00:16.900
empowering the world
through engaging learning.

4
00:00:16.900 --> 00:00:21.590
I'm your host, Zach Memos, as we continue
on with Word 2016 Essentials for Mac.

5
00:00:21.590 --> 00:00:24.310
Little look at blank page and
cover page and

6
00:00:24.310 --> 00:00:28.780
Von Smith I'm gonna help you again

00:00:28.780 --> 00:00:31.160

have you here, thank so very much.

8

I do care and so much so

Blank pages and cover pages.

14

[LAUGH]
>> Very good.

15

>> Imagine that, right?

16
00:00:51.643 --> 00:00:52.175
[LAUGH]
>> Mm hm.

>> But it is all part of the layout and

how to control, how the flow of your

So that's why it is part of this topic,

But I wanted to keep it

>> Wonderful.
Well, how do we get started and

what are we gonna be looking at?

>> Well let's jump on down.

>> Let's look through
the looking glass actually it's

just because that's one

[LAUGH] in a file called brakes.docx.

All right so, yes, I could go ahead and

If I put my cursor in front

That is not the same as

Now inserting a blank page

[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

It is going to do that double breaking,

Well, this is where if I put my cursor in

It broke the page.

But then it put a whole other blank page,

00:02:44.120 --> 00:02:46.500
So that's where it is a double page break.

And if you think about, we'll insert

[LAUGH] It's a full blank page, and

it will make a difference of how much

I just did a command Z for undo.

For example, if I had it here,

what should I do here for this Alice in

But if I came here in

You're getting large sheets of paper and

on one sheet of paper then sending it

and [INAUDIBLE] in positioning and
then going ahead and

So I know about all stuff, you be like I

And for cost effectiveness depending

It's usually four, eight,
16 or some type of four or

eight type stuff of how much they put on

You can get it into a certain

00:05:34.343 --> 00:05:38.308
Well, let's say you have 80 and

Wow, I'm doing really bad at math, but you

That's why you might want to go ahead and

00:05:53.110 --> 00:05:57.630

99
00:05:57.630 --> 00:06:02.340
it could be for your cost effectiveness

00:06:02.340 --> 00:06:04.890
So just throwing in

101
00:06:04.890 --> 00:06:08.000

>> So that's what a blank page does.

It was,

So back on the same document

It does not matter where you're at.

I am clicking in the middle

I can come up to insert, go to cover page.

Now I choose the drop down, look at

So I click on this and

Notice, it did not add the cover page

It does do a page break right here, so

it gives me some default pieces

00:07:49.990 --> 00:07:54.000

You're like, sorry, I'm trying to

00:07:57.030 --> 00:07:58.400
There we go,

00:07:59.430 --> 00:08:01.320
More like,

And let me turn this off just so

00:08:08.915 --> 00:08:13.430
Well, this is tied into something

I did this one specifically because

That makes you think, well,

But for now I don't have it but

I don't want a subtitle, just click

Since it's, these are known as

153
00:08:56.780 --> 00:09:00.010
Maybe you don't want the company name and

154
00:09:00.010 --> 00:09:02.190
And why is it saying Lance Bass there?

155
00:09:02.190 --> 00:09:04.540
That's just because of, whoops sorry.

00:09:04.540 --> 00:09:10.650
That's the name of the person that is
attached to this particular file that was

157
00:09:10.650 --> 00:09:14.300
made because that's the, it's the account
that I made it under in this [INAUDIBLE].

158
00:09:14.300 --> 00:09:15.150
>> Right, I remember that.

159
00:09:15.150 --> 00:09:18.650
>> So I just actually took that
whole thing and deleted it.

160
00:09:18.650 --> 00:09:23.310
This does get into, notice up here,
shapes and picture formats.

161
00:09:23.310 --> 00:09:28.630
So in the word advanced, we talk a lot
about being able to format all of this.

162
00:09:28.630 --> 00:09:34.140
So I don't want you to get too confused or
like, this isn't exactly what I want.

163
00:09:34.140 --> 00:09:39.890
It is meant to pretty much be how it is,
like you like the feathers.

164
00:09:39.890 --> 00:09:44.540
You could go ahead and change maybe the
fill color of this particular shape, but

165
00:09:44.540 --> 00:09:48.890
then sometimes it's like there's
multiple shapes that are combined

166
00:09:48.890 --> 00:09:50.470
in together to make one.

167
00:09:50.470 --> 00:09:52.850
So sometimes you're like I'm trying
to change the color of it, but

168
00:09:52.850 --> 00:09:54.320
it's not actually applying.

169
00:09:54.320 --> 00:09:56.840
It's just the nature of how it's created.

170
00:09:56.840 --> 00:09:59.930
And the more you know about shapes and

171
00:09:59.930 --> 00:10:02.790
formatting them in words
gonna get a little easier.

172
00:10:02.790 --> 00:10:06.740
So you can see I think you can
change it from blue to green and

173
00:10:06.740 --> 00:10:07.900
I can do some other things.

174
00:10:07.900 --> 00:10:11.900
This is a whole picture that I can
do some formatting things to it.

175
00:10:11.900 --> 00:10:13.620
And so I can change some colors.

176
00:10:13.620 --> 00:10:18.520
I'm getting into more things
that are in other shows, but

177
00:10:18.520 --> 00:10:21.630
this is fully customizable
if you wanted to.

178
00:10:21.630 --> 00:10:23.900
It's nice that it has a lot of
things that to start with and

179
00:10:23.900 --> 00:10:25.320
you can kind of play around with it.

180
00:10:25.320 --> 00:10:27.940
>> Now just a silly little question but,
this is all open source right?

181
00:10:27.940 --> 00:10:31.940
You can use this material without fear of,
hey you can't use that.

182
00:10:31.940 --> 00:10:35.145
>> Like copyrights and things like that
>> I would say yes.

183
00:10:35.145 --> 00:10:36.670
[LAUGH]
>> I would think it is.

184
00:10:36.670 --> 00:10:40.720
>> Well it's also part of Office so
like this whatever graphic this is,

185
00:10:40.720 --> 00:10:44.760
I mean if it's being used in like
a general format, it'll fine.

186
00:10:44.760 --> 00:10:46.090
So I don't think it would work.

187
00:10:46.090 --> 00:10:49.440
Now if you put your company logo on it and
things like that and then brand it for

188
00:10:49.440 --> 00:10:53.520
yourself, in a sense,
I could put the ITProTV logo down there.

189
00:10:53.520 --> 00:10:55.920
That gives into inserting more
pictures and so on and so forth.

190
00:10:55.920 --> 00:10:56.616
>> Right, right.
>> But [CROSSTALK]

191
00:10:56.616 --> 00:10:57.552
>> That's residual.

192
00:10:57.552 --> 00:11:02.029
>> The nice thing is that it does
have a nice gallery of pretty

193
00:11:02.029 --> 00:11:06.060
decent looking things to
pick from in your Insert.

194
00:11:06.060 --> 00:11:07.450
Sorry, I forgot where I was going.

195
00:11:07.450 --> 00:11:09.930
Now if I am back here,
let me just zoom out so

196
00:11:09.930 --> 00:11:11.920
we can see this a little bit better.

197
00:11:11.920 --> 00:11:14.860
Hm, maybe I don't like that
particular cover page.

198
00:11:14.860 --> 00:11:19.440
If I go into here and go to cover page,
I could pick this badge one.

199
00:11:19.440 --> 00:11:21.850
You're thinking,
does that mean I'm gonna get a double?

200
00:11:21.850 --> 00:11:25.410
Nope, it just goes ahead changes whatever

201
00:11:25.410 --> 00:11:28.550
layout of that current
cover page that you have.

202
00:11:28.550 --> 00:11:31.310
It doesn't add a second cover page.

203
00:11:31.310 --> 00:11:35.830
So, just in case you were wondering that
and maybe I'll go over to this one, or

204
00:11:35.830 --> 00:11:39.810
let's go over to this one, so on and so
forth, you can see that it replaces.

205
00:11:39.810 --> 00:11:41.880
But now maybe I don't
want a cover page at all.

206
00:11:41.880 --> 00:11:44.450
Let's just take this off.

207
00:11:44.450 --> 00:11:49.930
You could take it from here and
just go down to remove cover page.

208
00:11:49.930 --> 00:11:51.190
Take it all out, and

209
00:11:51.190 --> 00:11:56.180
now Alice in Wonderland is the very
first page of that particular document.

210
00:11:56.180 --> 00:12:00.420
That's where adding in say,
a cover page, and then a blank page,

211
00:12:00.420 --> 00:12:04.780
because in a regular book,
if you look at any of your books,

212
00:12:04.780 --> 00:12:09.220
you don't start If I'm looking at a page,
you don't start the page over here,

213
00:12:09.220 --> 00:12:12.300
you always start the text on
the right side of a book.

214
00:12:12.300 --> 00:12:14.190
It's very rare that you
start it on the left side.

215
00:12:14.190 --> 00:12:17.760
>> I would say just about every hardcover
book I have, the very first page is blank.

216
00:12:17.760 --> 00:12:19.280
>> Right?
Yeah, yeah, and

217
00:12:19.280 --> 00:12:23.020
it's just the way of pagination, and
starting the text from the right-hand

218
00:12:23.020 --> 00:12:27.762
side, it's just It's just the you
know convention of books I guess.

219
00:12:27.762 --> 00:12:29.680
[LAUGH] You can start on left if you want.

220
00:12:29.680 --> 00:12:30.580
>> Sure.
>> But that's why

221
00:12:30.580 --> 00:12:35.170
using a cover page understand like
inserting blank pages can be really handy.

222
00:12:35.170 --> 00:12:39.120
Now back over to those fields,
those document properties.

223
00:12:39.120 --> 00:12:44.070
Now we get in the document properties
in the expert level of Word.

224
00:12:44.070 --> 00:12:48.660
But I have one called
Welcome to Word here.

225
00:12:48.660 --> 00:12:51.650
And at first glance you're like
there's not any different.

226
00:12:51.650 --> 00:12:53.794
But if I go in to insert the cover page.

227
00:12:53.794 --> 00:12:59.220
And let's choose let's choose this one,
okay?

228
00:12:59.220 --> 00:13:02.530
If I click on that,
notice it puts in the date,

229
00:13:02.530 --> 00:13:05.010
it also welcome to word
document properties.

230
00:13:05.010 --> 00:13:07.700
Wow, look at that Justin Timberlake,
OfficePro TV,

231
00:13:07.700 --> 00:13:12.220
all of those different things
were added automatically

232
00:13:12.220 --> 00:13:17.210
because I have document properties
in this particular fields, okay?

233
00:13:17.210 --> 00:13:23.270
If I go into File and
I go to Properties, I can

234
00:13:23.270 --> 00:13:30.720
add in a whole bunch of meta data into my
document that's not just like the file

235
00:13:30.720 --> 00:13:35.150
name, the title and
the file name are not the same thing.

236
00:13:35.150 --> 00:13:37.570
Notice they're totally different here.

237
00:13:37.570 --> 00:13:41.640
And the subject and the author,
I can also add in custom fields.

238
00:13:41.640 --> 00:13:45.630
They're not necessarily being pulled
from in this particular template

239
00:13:45.630 --> 00:13:48.930
of the cover page, but
these are all things that you can

240
00:13:48.930 --> 00:13:51.980
add into your document that's not
necessarily in the surface level,

241
00:13:51.980 --> 00:13:57.260
that's what they call metadata that can be
pulled, but it is using this information

242
00:13:57.260 --> 00:14:01.750
to pull in things like
Justin Timberlake as the author,

243
00:14:01.750 --> 00:14:07.280
Office Pro TV as the company,
Introduction to MS Word as the subject,

244
00:14:07.280 --> 00:14:13.890
and so that's why you get
pre-populated information when I add

245
00:14:13.890 --> 00:14:18.980
the cover page to this particular document
as opposed to The Alice in Wonderland.

246
00:14:18.980 --> 00:14:20.670
Let's just zoom in a little bit.

247
00:14:20.670 --> 00:14:26.490
If I added that cover page, the same one,
same one, it just has the field.

248
00:14:26.490 --> 00:14:30.460
And I put Alice in Wonderland from
the last one so that's why it's pulling.

249
00:14:30.460 --> 00:14:33.540
But document, subtitle,
company name, company address.

250
00:14:33.540 --> 00:14:38.620
None of those fields in the documents
properties are populated.

251
00:14:38.620 --> 00:14:40.670
So that's why the title is right there.

252
00:14:40.670 --> 00:14:43.870
But that's why they're different.

253
00:14:43.870 --> 00:14:47.280
You have to have the properties
to make it do that so.

254
00:14:47.280 --> 00:14:48.970
But again you could delete all of them.

255
00:14:48.970 --> 00:14:52.800
Even in this one maybe I don't want
to have this just select it and

256
00:14:52.800 --> 00:14:56.780
hit delete Again getting into the shapes
versus the text and the shapes.

257
00:14:56.780 --> 00:15:01.270
That can get a little wonky for
people if you don't understand how to even

258
00:15:01.270 --> 00:15:04.530
work with that particular type
of content then your document.

259
00:15:04.530 --> 00:15:08.230
Then I say hey just use the template,
fill in the pieces that you want,

260
00:15:08.230 --> 00:15:09.750
delete the parts you don't want.

261
00:15:09.750 --> 00:15:15.270
Come over here and figure out that you
can change the fill color of them.

262
00:15:15.270 --> 00:15:17.650
Notice it does both cuz it's grouped.

263
00:15:17.650 --> 00:15:19.050
Okay, but anyways, we can get into that.

264
00:15:19.050 --> 00:15:21.950
But anyways, pretty cool stuff,
pretty easy to do too.

265
00:15:21.950 --> 00:15:24.600
You just add a cover page,
add a blank page and

266
00:15:24.600 --> 00:15:28.500
have your document flow however you so
desire.

267
00:15:28.500 --> 00:15:29.780
>> Fantastic work Yvonne.

268
00:15:29.780 --> 00:15:32.220
Thanks so very much, and so excited now.

269
00:15:32.220 --> 00:15:34.850
You can do all these things that
you might not known before and

270
00:15:34.850 --> 00:15:38.420
I'm one of those people, so
I'm actually gonna explore more that.

271
00:15:38.420 --> 00:15:45.180
This has been blank page and cover page
inside of the Word 2016 essentials or Mac.

272
00:15:45.180 --> 00:15:47.840
Make sure you watch every single episode,
you'll be glad you did.

273
00:15:47.840 --> 00:15:49.810
Take a look at the other
videos in our course library.

274
00:15:49.810 --> 00:15:53.030
They're all designed to
help you go further.

275
00:15:53.030 --> 00:15:56.070
And tell everybody you know about
OfficeProTV, they'll be very glad you did.

276
00:15:56.070 --> 00:15:57.610
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach memos.

277
00:15:57.610 --> 00:15:58.420
>> And I'm Von Smith.

278
00:15:58.420 --> 00:16:01.309
>> We will see you again very soon.

279
00:16:01.309 --> 00:16:06.294
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Zac and Vonne dive into working with margins. Vonne shows how to control margins using preset options, individual adjustments in the dialog box, and the ruler. She also shows how to add headers and footers and explore the different options of different first page, even / odd pages, and link to previous.
episodes.title: Margins, Headers and Footers
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.913 --> 00:00:14.245
Hello and thank you for
choosing OfficePro.tv,

3
00:00:14.245 --> 00:00:17.000
empowering the world
through engaging learning.

4
00:00:17.000 --> 00:00:22.010
I'm your host Zach Memos as we continue
on with Word 2016 Essentials for Mac.

5
00:00:22.010 --> 00:00:25.310
We're gonna be looking at margins,
headers, and footers.

6
00:00:25.310 --> 00:00:28.580
And we've asked Vonne Smith once again to
come on in here and help us out with that,

7
00:00:28.580 --> 00:00:31.050
because she knows what we need to know.

8
00:00:31.050 --> 00:00:33.240
We have Vonne,
glad to have you here, thank you.

9
00:00:33.240 --> 00:00:34.580
>> Thank you, thank you.

10
00:00:34.580 --> 00:00:37.170
Yes, I do know a little bit about
headers and footers, and margins.

11
00:00:37.170 --> 00:00:37.780
>> She does.
>> [LAUGH]

12
00:00:37.780 --> 00:00:38.670
>> And we were talking.

13
00:00:38.670 --> 00:00:42.300
This is another one of those my episodes,
cuz I like to keep things in threes.

14
00:00:42.300 --> 00:00:43.770
>> Margins and headers and footers, my.

15
00:00:43.770 --> 00:00:45.960
>> Yes.
>> Margins and headers and footers.

16
00:00:45.960 --> 00:00:48.000
>> Well it's kind of a half my.

17
00:00:48.000 --> 00:00:49.930
>> Half?
>> I don't know if we can half a third.

18
00:00:49.930 --> 00:00:54.150
>> Now we're getting into math,
I'm getting scared, [LAUGH] but.

19
00:00:54.150 --> 00:00:58.380
As you can see with the punctuation
it's margins comma headers and footers.

20
00:00:58.380 --> 00:00:59.030
>> Headers and footers.

21
00:00:59.030 --> 00:01:00.820
>> Yeah so headers and
footers we kinda keep together.

22
00:01:00.820 --> 00:01:02.980
They're not necessarily
two separate entities.

23
00:01:02.980 --> 00:01:08.060
It goes back to another one of my favorite
sayings is the together yet separate.

24
00:01:08.060 --> 00:01:11.880
But we'll get to what a header and
footer is really all about.

25
00:01:11.880 --> 00:01:14.570
Because this is all about page layout.

26
00:01:14.570 --> 00:01:16.690
How do I want my pages to look like?

27
00:01:16.690 --> 00:01:20.530
>> and we've talked a little bit about
keep options and we did some columns.

28
00:01:20.530 --> 00:01:24.678
We talked about the all-important section,
very very important there.

29
00:01:24.678 --> 00:01:28.710
And we're gonna be hitting up
some sections again today because

30
00:01:28.710 --> 00:01:31.105
changing the margins of your page.

31
00:01:31.105 --> 00:01:32.845
So let's talk about that first.

32
00:01:32.845 --> 00:01:33.915
What is the margin?

33
00:01:33.915 --> 00:01:38.145
The margin is the white
area around your page.

34
00:01:38.145 --> 00:01:40.195
Like if we have this,
my little show notes,

35
00:01:40.195 --> 00:01:43.465
all this white area around the sides,
that would be the margin.

36
00:01:43.465 --> 00:01:47.815
And you can control that and depending on
whether you have a larger margin, that

37
00:01:47.815 --> 00:01:52.260
would make more white space, or you have
a smaller margin, has less white space.

38
00:01:52.260 --> 00:01:55.640
You can fit more content on the page.

39
00:01:55.640 --> 00:01:57.420
So that really kind of determines how,

40
00:01:57.420 --> 00:02:01.430
it's a part of how we have our
text flow through our document.

41
00:02:01.430 --> 00:02:05.070
And there's a lot of times I tend
to like to put on narrow margins,

42
00:02:05.070 --> 00:02:08.050
cuz I wanna try to get more
on a page then those things.

43
00:02:08.050 --> 00:02:11.760
And I also remember
writing papers in school.

44
00:02:11.760 --> 00:02:14.940
It was always that you have to
have a one-inch margin all around.

45
00:02:14.940 --> 00:02:17.850
It had to be like a 12 point,
Times New Roman, double spaced,

46
00:02:17.850 --> 00:02:21.563
all those kind of specific requirements
that you would need to have for

47
00:02:21.563 --> 00:02:23.610
how you would turn in your paper.

48
00:02:23.610 --> 00:02:26.550
And luckily, now if you just want
a one-inch margin, you just click a little

49
00:02:26.550 --> 00:02:29.440
button because we have a bunch of presets,
which is always very nice.

50
00:02:29.440 --> 00:02:34.000
So why don't we go ahead and
jump in to a file called Page Layout.

51
00:02:34.000 --> 00:02:35.140
I've already got it opened up.

52
00:02:35.140 --> 00:02:40.060
And again we're not concentrating on
the text, so if you can't see it too well,

53
00:02:40.060 --> 00:02:41.610
you can't read it, that's all right.

54
00:02:41.610 --> 00:02:46.960
We're really gonna be concentrating
on the edges of the paper.

55
00:02:46.960 --> 00:02:49.790
And what we're going to do is,
well, change our margins.

56
00:02:49.790 --> 00:02:56.590
Now there's a couple different ways that
you can get to modifying your margins.

57
00:02:56.590 --> 00:02:58.740
So let me show you
a couple different places.

58
00:02:58.740 --> 00:03:02.000
Since this is page layout,
we have the layout tab on the ribbon.

59
00:03:02.000 --> 00:03:04.740
So on this layout tab, you can see right
over here, on the left, we have, Margins.

60
00:03:05.895 --> 00:03:09.005
And that whole just click to find
that one-inch margin all around?

61
00:03:09.005 --> 00:03:10.475
Well, there you go.

62
00:03:10.475 --> 00:03:14.385
Mine's actually on it right now and
they are calling this preset Normal.

63
00:03:14.385 --> 00:03:20.445
And you can notice right here that it has
the specific measurements on all the top,

64
00:03:20.445 --> 00:03:24.510
bottom, left, right, for
you to go and find right there.

65
00:03:24.510 --> 00:03:27.870
And this last Custom setting,
that's always gonna be there.

66
00:03:27.870 --> 00:03:33.300
It's gonna change to the last
setting you had, kind of apropo-ly.

67
00:03:33.300 --> 00:03:35.570
Apropoly, is apropoly a word?

68
00:03:35.570 --> 00:03:37.370
>> Well, let's have a consent.

69
00:03:37.370 --> 00:03:38.870
Apropoly?

70
00:03:38.870 --> 00:03:40.960
Yeah!
Yeah, they said yes, no.

71
00:03:40.960 --> 00:03:44.520
>> Well, in my vocabulary, I make up
all sorts of wonderful words, so.

72
00:03:44.520 --> 00:03:46.790
[LAUGH] I don't know if they're wonderful,
but they're interesting.

73
00:03:46.790 --> 00:03:48.390
So you can see how it will change.

74
00:03:48.390 --> 00:03:51.380
Now let's go and change some of
these presets really quickly, so

75
00:03:51.380 --> 00:03:52.980
we can see how it adjusts.

76
00:03:52.980 --> 00:03:55.370
If I go to a narrow margin,
watch all the content.

77
00:03:55.370 --> 00:04:00.580
You see how now, less whitespace around
the edges, so I can get more words.

78
00:04:00.580 --> 00:04:06.438
If I go into a wider margin,
that means the margin is wide so

79
00:04:06.438 --> 00:04:10.158
you have less area for your content.

80
00:04:10.158 --> 00:04:14.356
So, all right sometimes for
me it like it's almost backwards cuz

81
00:04:14.356 --> 00:04:19.334
I'm thinking narrow, this to me would
be narrow and then this would be wide.

82
00:04:19.334 --> 00:04:22.448
Cuz I'm looking more at
the content of what's being fit.

83
00:04:22.448 --> 00:04:24.518
But no, we're talking about
white space with margins.

84
00:04:24.518 --> 00:04:29.400
>> And so, Vonne, when you're do that, are
you changing the size of your text or no?

85
00:04:29.400 --> 00:04:30.330
>> No!

86
00:04:30.330 --> 00:04:34.720
That's a good point,
all the content, the font size,

87
00:04:34.720 --> 00:04:37.560
the spacing, all of that stays the same.

88
00:04:37.560 --> 00:04:40.750
It's really just the space
around it that is adjusting.

89
00:04:42.100 --> 00:04:45.750
Cuz you might kind of see a change in that
way, but all the content stays the same.

90
00:04:45.750 --> 00:04:47.230
>> I think it's just
a trick of the eye too.

91
00:04:47.230 --> 00:04:50.880
I mean, it looks like the text might
be changing size, but it's not.

92
00:04:50.880 --> 00:04:54.070
>> Yeah, no, it is one of those things,
like, is that the same?

93
00:04:54.070 --> 00:04:55.530
So, good point, very good point.

94
00:04:55.530 --> 00:04:58.580
So, we have the layout tab and
our margins for our presets right there.

95
00:04:58.580 --> 00:05:03.030
There's a couple other places you
can get to changing your margins.

96
00:05:03.030 --> 00:05:06.526
You can go into the Format menu and
then go to Document.

97
00:05:06.526 --> 00:05:09.980
This is actually a place that we're going

00:29:49.450 --> 00:29:56.050
people up a lot, but if you just check
that box off, understand sections,

547
00:29:56.050 --> 00:30:00.490
and those different check boxes on
the tabs, it will get a lot easier.

548
00:30:00.490 --> 00:30:02.110
I fight with this sometimes and

I really fight with page
numbers in the next episode.

550
00:30:04.980 --> 00:30:08.990
So if it's kind of a little

551

This is where my where sections are,

these are the check boxes and

554
00:30:15.720 --> 00:30:17.240
>> Margins, headers and footers.

555
00:30:17.240 --> 00:30:21.740
And what's great about this episode, and

There's all kinds of videos all
designed to help you go further.

559
00:30:33.020 --> 00:30:36.460
And tell everybody you know about Office
ProTV they'll be really glad you did.

560

Thanks for watching I'm Zack Memos.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zac and Vonne continue working with header and footers by adding page numbers. Vonne demonstrates how to renumber pages for different sections as well as how to use the chapter page numbering options.
episodes.title: Add and Format Page Numbers
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.926
[MUSIC]

And if you go ahead and add four pages,

What you manually said is, this is page

28
00:01:31.746 --> 00:01:37.422
So, you really want to have it

And that's why we have the insert page

it gets more into the sessions, but yes,

Because a lot of times, you're gonna

is to go ahead and

Like I said, the weird part is when

Nope, not gonna type it manually,
I'm gonna go ahead and

On any content that I was adding

So, if you wanted to go this way,

It's the same thing as if you had gone

Because yes, one, two,

So I tend to like this particular

There, and I'll make it, let's make it

If I don't like that particular

I turn this on, and people are like,

Not really, okay, because that

That's the only way that you

So you do have to be,

I know sometimes like, well I don't

Just keep that in mind,

00:09:51.400 --> 00:09:55.290
That's why I was trying to say

00:09:57.020 --> 00:09:58.656

It that what you're gonna,

00:10:07.560 --> 00:10:09.030
>> Definitely.
>> Yeah.

>> And it's hard, just like anything,
get it all in there and

00:10:12.390 --> 00:10:14.350

179
00:10:14.350 --> 00:10:19.179
This would be one,
cuz what I'm gonna have to do to say that

00:10:19.179 --> 00:10:23.724
this is page one,

00:10:23.724 --> 00:10:28.242
And on this particular paragraph we're

And the other thing is you probably

00:10:34.925 --> 00:10:39.398

that's where the flow of your content.

185
00:10:39.398 --> 00:10:41.860
You really need to be aware of it to say,

I don't really want a paragraph to be

188
00:10:52.400 --> 00:10:57.490
So the way I have my document set up

00:10:59.660 --> 00:11:03.030
That's gonna be ideal

00:11:06.375 --> 00:11:09.420
Cuz right here, this is where I

00:11:09.420 --> 00:11:12.280

We go to layout, we go to breaks,

00:11:16.000 --> 00:11:20.500

This is where if I come

Going a different way rather

427
00:25:01.310 --> 00:25:03.820
there's a lot of working parts here,
but this is a video,

428
00:25:03.820 --> 00:25:07.010
you can watch it a million times,
and also your show notes, too.

429
00:25:07.010 --> 00:25:07.550
>> Yeah.

430
00:25:07.550 --> 00:25:08.990
>> You're very fortunate, guys.

431
00:25:08.990 --> 00:25:12.480
>> And circling back around to some of the
other concepts that are in other episodes

432
00:25:12.480 --> 00:25:18.220
if I wanted this I have to unlink it,
turn off the link to previous.

433
00:25:18.220 --> 00:25:25.060
Now this can be cat and
see now section 3 needs to be pig, right?

434
00:25:25.060 --> 00:25:30.290
So come and, again another one,
make sure your cursor's in the right spot

435
00:25:30.290 --> 00:25:32.990
before you go and
start clicking on buttons, okay?

436
00:25:32.990 --> 00:25:35.320
Always gotta stop, think, what am I doing?

437
00:25:35.320 --> 00:25:36.333
Where do I need to be?

438
00:25:36.333 --> 00:25:40.810
Be in Section 3, turn off the link,
change this to pig.

439
00:25:42.360 --> 00:25:44.380
And then, you can see pig.

440
00:25:44.380 --> 00:25:48.190
So, that way you could have the titles,

441
00:25:48.190 --> 00:25:51.990
if you want to say,
on all the different sections.

442
00:25:51.990 --> 00:25:55.974
You can make sure that the headers have
different content, unique content.

443
00:25:55.974 --> 00:25:57.960
You gotta turn it to unlink.

444
00:25:57.960 --> 00:25:59.440
These are same with previous,

445
00:25:59.440 --> 00:26:02.840
because I want to keep it
going with the page number.

446
00:26:02.840 --> 00:26:08.770
So, I didn't have to turn off the linking
for changing the page numbers, that's

447
00:26:08.770 --> 00:26:13.220
okay to be connected but it is flowing
through the different page numbers.

448
00:26:13.220 --> 00:26:17.940
It's when I want the words
to be different,

449
00:26:17.940 --> 00:26:21.760
that's where you might want to go
ahead and unlink to the previous.

450
00:26:21.760 --> 00:26:27.700
So that's another thing of why it happens,
when you wanna turn it on and off.

451
00:26:27.700 --> 00:26:32.000
And notice that I can have, and this is
something I didn't emphasize in the last

452
00:26:32.000 --> 00:26:37.060
episode, is that I can have my
headers not linked together,

453
00:26:37.060 --> 00:26:42.748
the linking previous from the sections,
but my footers can be linked to previous.

454
00:26:42.748 --> 00:26:47.489
So they're their own entities of how they

455
00:26:47.489 --> 00:26:52.365
connect into the other sections right, so

456
00:26:52.365 --> 00:26:55.627
just throwing all that out.

457
00:26:55.627 --> 00:26:59.497
A lot of information,
this part tripped me up for,

458
00:26:59.497 --> 00:27:04.260
I don't even want to admit,
this tripped me up for years.

459
00:27:04.260 --> 00:27:05.699
I mean, this took me a long time.

460
00:27:05.699 --> 00:27:06.588
>> I don't feel so bad now.

461
00:27:06.588 --> 00:27:10.297
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] This whole thing took me a long

462
00:27:10.297 --> 00:27:15.290
time to wrap my head around because
I was probably just like you,

463
00:27:15.290 --> 00:27:19.542
I fought with this so hard and
it would get me so upset and

464
00:27:19.542 --> 00:27:22.140
I could never make it work right.

465
00:27:22.140 --> 00:27:24.390
And I would watch tutorials,
and I'm like, I got it.

466
00:27:24.390 --> 00:27:27.940
It was when I didn't use that one piece.

467
00:27:27.940 --> 00:27:30.560
I didn't use the multi level lists or
the outlined lists and

468
00:27:30.560 --> 00:27:31.850
that's why it's not working.

469
00:27:31.850 --> 00:27:38.140
So if you've fought with this I have
to still fight with it sometimes.

470
00:27:38.140 --> 00:27:41.562
Even during these demonstrations,
I'm like, wait.

471
00:27:41.562 --> 00:27:45.890
That's why I have to kind of write it out,
think about it, and really stop.

472
00:27:45.890 --> 00:27:49.425
And sometimes it's like, stop,
scrap, let me start over.

473
00:27:49.425 --> 00:27:54.726
Back up, always make copies of things
just in case you need to get back.

474
00:27:54.726 --> 00:27:55.661
>> More important, yeah.

475
00:27:55.661 --> 00:27:59.640
>> Yeah, cuz sometimes you can get down
a hole and and you can't get back out.

476
00:28:00.760 --> 00:28:05.370
Just kind of helping you all out
if you've struggled with it.

477
00:28:05.370 --> 00:28:06.050
I have too.

478
00:28:06.050 --> 00:28:07.010
I feel your pain.

479
00:28:07.010 --> 00:28:12.140
Hopefully, this will alleviate some of
your pain and Yeah, I think I'm done.

480
00:28:12.140 --> 00:28:12.955
[LAUGH]
>> Well very good, and

481
00:28:12.955 --> 00:28:14.465
it will alleviate some of our pain, Vonne.

482
00:28:14.465 --> 00:28:16.155
You did a wonderful job as always.

483
00:28:16.155 --> 00:28:17.315
And this was add and

484
00:28:17.315 --> 00:28:21.325
format page numbers inside of
the Word 2016 Essentials for Mac.

485
00:28:21.325 --> 00:28:23.775
Make sure you watch every single episode.

486
00:28:23.775 --> 00:28:25.015
Cuz you'll be glad you did.

487
00:28:25.015 --> 00:28:26.985
And remember there's notes and
everything there.

488
00:28:26.985 --> 00:28:28.075
You can read.
Rewatch them.

489
00:28:28.075 --> 00:28:30.040
Because you're very lucky in that respect.

490
00:28:30.040 --> 00:28:32.920
In fact, our course library has
hundreds of other videos and

491
00:28:32.920 --> 00:28:36.030
they're all designed to
help you go further.

492
00:28:36.030 --> 00:28:39.090
Hey, tell everybody you know about Office
Pro TV, they'll be very glad you did.

493
00:28:39.090 --> 00:28:40.390
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

494
00:28:40.390 --> 00:28:41.230
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

495
00:28:41.230 --> 00:28:43.534
>> And we will see you soon.

496
00:28:43.534 --> 00:28:48.493
[NOISE]

episodes.description: In this episode, Zac and Vonne show how to apply additional page formatting elements. Vonne begins with demonstrating the difference between portrait and landscape orientation.  She continues with demonstrating page color and borders, vertical justification, watermarks, and line numbers.
episodes.title: Orientation and Decoration
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:08.871
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.878 --> 00:00:14.274
Hello, and thank you for
choosing OfficeProTV,

3
00:00:14.274 --> 00:00:16.734
empowering the world
through engaging learning.

4
00:00:16.734 --> 00:00:21.392
I'm your host Zach Memos, as we continue
on with Word 2016 Essentials for Mac.

5
00:00:21.392 --> 00:00:24.598
And this is orientation and decoration!

6
00:00:24.598 --> 00:00:26.750
What could that possibly mean?

7
00:00:26.750 --> 00:00:28.761
Well, Vonne Smith is here
to help us out as usual.

8
00:00:28.761 --> 00:00:30.073
Vonne, thanks so very much.

9
00:00:30.073 --> 00:00:31.443
>> It's time for sparkles!

10
00:00:31.443 --> 00:00:32.852
>> Hey [LAUGH!

11
00:00:32.852 --> 00:00:34.838
>> Well, kind of [LAUGH].

12
00:00:34.838 --> 00:00:35.363
>> A little bit.

13
00:00:35.363 --> 00:00:35.912
>> Glitter!

14
00:00:35.912 --> 00:00:37.008
>> Yes, yes, yes.

15
00:00:37.008 --> 00:00:40.761
We're going to be adding some
decorations to our pages.

16
00:00:40.761 --> 00:00:44.538
And then we're also going
to talk about orientation,

17
00:00:44.538 --> 00:00:48.242
which that one is pretty simple,
honestly, [LAUGH].

18
00:00:48.242 --> 00:00:53.116
So orientation would be how
the page is orientated,

19
00:00:53.116 --> 00:00:56.510
meaning this way versus this way.

20
00:00:56.510 --> 00:00:57.903
>> Horizontal or vertical.

21
00:00:57.903 --> 00:01:00.072
>> Yes, or also known as portrait.

22
00:01:00.072 --> 00:01:01.954
>> Or portrait landscape, yeah.

23
00:01:01.954 --> 00:01:05.790
>> But anyway, it's the same,
horizontal, vertical, same idea.

24
00:01:05.790 --> 00:01:11.414
So how do I want my text designated on
the page or the orientation of my page?

25
00:01:11.414 --> 00:01:16.090
Let me show you,
I have a file called certificate layout.

26
00:01:16.090 --> 00:01:20.057
We have the most team spirit, I'm going to
turn this off because we don't need it.

27
00:01:20.057 --> 00:01:24.060
I decided to nominate Ronnie Wong for the
most, I probably should actually put you.

28
00:01:24.060 --> 00:01:25.732
>> Actually, Ronnie likes sparkles.

29
00:01:25.732 --> 00:01:26.460
>> [LAUGH]
>> He just told me.

30
00:01:26.460 --> 00:01:27.280
>> And he has his own shirt.

31
00:01:27.280 --> 00:01:30.229
>> He does.
>> So I've got this, but on a certificate,

32
00:01:30.229 --> 00:01:33.128
like a certificate of completion or
something,

33
00:01:33.128 --> 00:01:37.260
it's not normally in portrait,
it's normally in landscape.

34
00:01:37.260 --> 00:01:38.081
So how do you change that?

35
00:01:38.081 --> 00:01:40.953
You go over to your layout and
it's right there, and so

36
00:01:40.953 --> 00:01:43.020
those are your only two options.

37
00:01:43.020 --> 00:01:46.457
And watch if I'm gonna magically change,
boom, there we go.

38
00:01:46.457 --> 00:01:47.645
Yes, I did this on purpose.

39
00:01:47.645 --> 00:01:52.621
All right, and I am making our
own certificate, just an FYI,

40
00:01:52.621 --> 00:01:55.720
this is this not the gonna be the best.

41
00:01:55.720 --> 00:01:56.399
>> Not the official one.

42
00:01:56.399 --> 00:01:59.250
>> No, and
it's not going to look very pretty.

43
00:01:59.250 --> 00:02:03.211
I would highly suggest using some of the
templates that they have for certificates.

44
00:02:03.211 --> 00:02:05.662
Just, might as well just
show you really quickly,

45
00:02:05.662 --> 00:02:08.220
even though this is not
an episode about templates.

46
00:02:08.220 --> 00:02:09.065
>> Right.

47
00:02:09.065 --> 00:02:11.682
>> But if you go from New,
from Template, and

48
00:02:11.682 --> 00:02:16.140
if you're connected to the Internet,
if you just type in certificate.

49
00:02:18.040 --> 00:02:20.544
There we go, there are some pretty ones.

50
00:02:20.544 --> 00:02:26.160
>> Yeah, right, there's some much
nicer ones that are pretty cute.

51
00:02:26.160 --> 00:02:29.883
You could also probably go online and
consult the Oracle, or

52
00:02:29.883 --> 00:02:32.737
just type in certificate templates for
Word.

53
00:02:32.737 --> 00:02:34.338
And maybe even throw it in for

54
00:02:34.338 --> 00:02:38.690
Mac, but I don't really think that's
gonna matter, cuz it's just a DOCX.

55
00:02:38.690 --> 00:02:40.483
And you can find some much nicer ones.

56
00:02:40.483 --> 00:02:43.098
Now, I didn't want to go all the way here,

57
00:02:43.098 --> 00:02:46.845
because this does get into
talking about shapes and colors.

58
00:02:46.845 --> 00:02:51.479
And the graphical elements that is
in our advanced word series, but

59
00:02:51.479 --> 00:02:54.091
just throwing that out there for you.

60
00:02:54.091 --> 00:02:57.990
This is just about orientation and
decoration, there we go.

61
00:02:57.990 --> 00:03:01.759
Now it is landscape,
let's zoom in just a little bit here.

62
00:03:01.759 --> 00:03:05.893
So now I want to kind of
gussy it up a little bit,

63
00:03:05.893 --> 00:03:10.036
let's go over to our
Design tab on our ribbon.

64
00:03:10.036 --> 00:03:13.319
Cuz over here,
cuz we've been to this Design tab before,

65
00:03:13.319 --> 00:03:16.337
but we didn't really talk
too much about these guys.

66
00:03:16.337 --> 00:03:22.300
We have our page color, changes the color

67
00:03:22.300 --> 00:03:25.368
And I could make this yellow, goodness.

68
00:03:25.368 --> 00:03:26.296
>> I told you it wasn't
going to look pretty.

69
00:03:26.296 --> 00:03:28.506
>> [LAUGH] Maybe a light grey.

70
00:03:28.506 --> 00:03:29.895
>> That's okay.

71
00:03:29.895 --> 00:03:33.386
>> Okay, now when you print this,
just to let you know, it doesn't,

72
00:03:33.386 --> 00:03:37.090
it's not going to print the color
all the way to the edge of the page.

73
00:03:37.090 --> 00:03:37.798
That just doesn't work.

74
00:03:37.798 --> 00:03:38.526
>> So there will be a border.

75
00:03:38.526 --> 00:03:43.544
There will,
border in a sense that that's just how

76
00:03:43.544 --> 00:03:49.470
desktop printers,
it can't print to the edge of the page.

77
00:03:49.470 --> 00:03:53.411
The only way to get to printing to the
edge of the page is you have to go into

78
00:03:53.411 --> 00:03:56.392
commercial printing and
then have bleeds and trims.

79
00:03:56.392 --> 00:04:01.369
And yes, there are some photo
printers that do print to the edge of

80
00:04:01.369 --> 00:04:04.820
your papers that you can buy for
your own use.

81
00:04:04.820 --> 00:04:09.057
But generally speaking,
your printer normally will adjust and

82
00:04:09.057 --> 00:04:11.497
create white space around the page.

83
00:04:11.497 --> 00:04:12.001
>> Mm-hm.

84
00:04:12.001 --> 00:04:15.535
>> The reason why I add borders is because
we're gonna add a page border, and

85
00:04:15.535 --> 00:04:16.960
that's a little different.

86
00:04:16.960 --> 00:04:17.639
>> Right, different deal.

87
00:04:17.639 --> 00:04:19.180
>> I know what you're talking about, but

88
00:04:19.180 --> 00:04:22.830
it's all about that terminology that
we can get a little tripped up on.

89
00:04:22.830 --> 00:04:29.146
So back over here on this page color,
if you're used to PC, Word.

90
00:04:29.146 --> 00:04:31.984
In the page color,
they also have things like gradients and

91
00:04:31.984 --> 00:04:34.000
they also have fill effects.

92
00:04:34.000 --> 00:04:38.240
It’s not available in the Mac version,
it just isn’t.

93
00:04:38.240 --> 00:04:41.946
If you want a gradient, or
some type of picture background,

94
00:04:41.946 --> 00:04:45.590
you’re going to have to add it
as like a graphical element.

95
00:04:45.590 --> 00:04:48.853
Like a photograph, an image, and
then send it to the back, again,

96
00:04:48.853 --> 00:04:50.242
more stuff in our advanced.

97
00:04:50.242 --> 00:04:54.580
So it's not that it's not possible,
just not through this

98
00:04:54.580 --> 00:05:00.230
particular drop down and
this command of changing the page color.

99
00:05:00.230 --> 00:05:04.801
So let's move on to borders,
let's come over here to Page Borders.

100
00:05:04.801 --> 00:05:08.550
Now, just to let you know,
I did click on this button right here, and

101
00:05:08.550 --> 00:05:10.240
it brought up this dialog box.

102
00:05:10.240 --> 00:05:13.170
This is the Borders and Shading,
now this is where some are like, well,

103
00:05:13.170 --> 00:05:14.333
this looks kinda familiar.

104
00:05:14.333 --> 00:05:17.908
Because we've been here before when
we did our paragraph formatting and

105
00:05:17.908 --> 00:05:20.200
we did borders and
shadings for my paragraph.

106
00:05:20.200 --> 00:05:24.704
You might have noticed, in that episode,
there is another option,

107
00:05:24.704 --> 00:05:27.434
right here in the middle for Page Border.

108
00:05:27.434 --> 00:05:31.175
And, so,
here I can designate my different styles,

109
00:05:31.175 --> 00:05:35.677
I could have a double outline,
maybe I'll do a triple outline.

110
00:05:35.677 --> 00:05:40.653
Watching this little button over here or
this graphic to tell you where its

111
00:05:40.653 --> 00:05:43.711
actually applying is
a good thing to look at.

112
00:05:43.711 --> 00:05:49.150
I could change the color,
maybe I want to make this Purple.

113
00:05:49.150 --> 00:05:53.303
Change the point size, and then you also
have some different settings over here.

114
00:05:53.303 --> 00:05:57.200
Maybe I want to add a shadow,
have a little 3D on there.

115
00:05:57.200 --> 00:06:00.888
Sometimes you might throw a 3D on it and
be like, that didn't do anything.

116
00:06:00.888 --> 00:06:04.273
It's just the nature
of maybe the style and

117
00:06:04.273 --> 00:06:10.630
the point size that the 3D aspect
isn't going to really look that 3D.

118
00:06:10.630 --> 00:06:13.549
I'm purposely not going down here for
just a little bit.

119
00:06:13.549 --> 00:06:16.360
I am going to apply this
to the whole document.

120
00:06:16.360 --> 00:06:19.454
Yep, that's what I want, so
I click OK, and all right.

121
00:06:19.454 --> 00:06:21.231
>> Voila!

122
00:06:21.231 --> 00:06:22.694
>> Yes, I'm really not liking this.

123
00:06:22.694 --> 00:06:27.123
But [LAUGH] you get the idea here of,
wow, that is not any better,

124
00:06:27.123 --> 00:06:30.830
[LAUGH] that I could go ahead and
change the border now.

125
00:06:30.830 --> 00:06:35.782
But notice where the border is sitting
in relationship to the whole page.

126
00:06:35.782 --> 00:06:40.653
And if I had multiple pages,
this is gonna go to all the pages,

127
00:06:40.653 --> 00:06:44.040
it's kind of setting in that margin area.

128
00:06:45.040 --> 00:06:51.748
If I come back over here, I have an option
of where the border is going to sit.

129
00:06:51.748 --> 00:06:56.436
If I click in here, notice it's
like measuring from the margin,

130
00:06:56.436 --> 00:06:59.140
measuring from the edge of the page.

131
00:06:59.140 --> 00:07:02.152
And you also have some
different options here.

132
00:07:02.152 --> 00:07:06.913
Align paragraph borders to with the page
borders, so if you had actual borders and

133
00:07:06.913 --> 00:07:10.330
shadings in paragraphs,
that's what that for.

134
00:07:10.330 --> 00:07:12.721
Surrounding the header and footer,

135
00:07:12.721 --> 00:07:16.973
that's another thing that you
need to take into consideration.

136
00:07:16.973 --> 00:07:20.060
I'm gonna cancel all this out for
now because I have another file.

137
00:07:20.060 --> 00:07:24.987
I'm just using my command tool bay as
my shortcut to cycle me through my open

138
00:07:24.987 --> 00:07:25.857
documents.

139
00:07:25.857 --> 00:07:30.040
I have a couple open documents, so it just
lets you know that that's what I'm doing.

140
00:07:30.040 --> 00:07:33.260
I could always come up
here to my Window menu and

141
00:07:33.260 --> 00:07:37.485
change what document I want in
the foreground by going here.

142
00:07:37.485 --> 00:07:41.968
I'm just using my shortcut,
let's come back over here to this example.

143
00:07:41.968 --> 00:07:46.040
And I'm gonna, oops, sorry, I'm gonna
zoom this out a little bit more, so

144
00:07:46.040 --> 00:07:48.747
we can see where this border
is going to be sitting.

145
00:07:48.747 --> 00:07:49.548
Let me turn this off too.

146
00:07:49.548 --> 00:07:52.509
So let's go back over into, you know what?

147
00:07:52.509 --> 00:07:54.529
Let's go to a different place.

148
00:07:54.529 --> 00:07:59.225
Let's go to the Format menu and
let's go to Borders and Shading.

149
00:07:59.225 --> 00:08:01.865
Cuz I can get to the same place from here.

150
00:08:01.865 --> 00:08:06.938
So now that I have my borders and
shading and I'm in my page border here,

151
00:08:06.938 --> 00:08:12.270
let's just throw on a quick border just so
we can get a visual on it.

152
00:08:12.270 --> 00:08:15.620
Let's make this green, and

153
00:08:15.620 --> 00:08:20.440
click OK, it does go around
the whole header and footer.

154
00:08:20.440 --> 00:08:25.640
But going back into those same options,
if I turn these off and

155
00:08:25.640 --> 00:08:31.460
click OK, and click OK again,
do you see it cuts that off.

156
00:08:31.460 --> 00:08:36.620
Which is something you might want to do,
maybe you want the page numbers to

157
00:08:36.620 --> 00:08:42.132
